original: Updating the diagnostic criteria of COVID-19 “suspected case” and “confirmed case” is necessary
simplification: Updating the diagnostic criteria of COVID-19 “suspected case” and “confirmed case” is necessary

original: On 6 February 2020, our team had published a rapid advice guideline for diagnosis and treatment of 2019 novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) infection, and this guideline provided our experience and make well reference for fighting against this pandemic worldwide.
simplification: On 6 February 2020, our team had published a rapid advice guideline for diagnosis and treatment of 2019 novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) infection. This guideline provided our experience and make well reference for fighting against this pandemic worldwide.

original: However, the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is a new disease, our awareness and knowledge are gradually increasing based on the ongoing research findings and clinical practice experience; hence, the strategies of diagnosis and treatment are also continually updated.
simplification: The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is a new disease, but our awareness and knowledge are gradually increasing based on the ongoing research findings and clinical practice experience. Therefore, the strategies of diagnosis and treatment are also continually updated.

original: In this letter, we answered one comment on our guideline and provided the newest diagnostic criteria of “suspected case” and “confirmed case” according to the latest Diagnosis and Treatment Guidelines for COVID-19 (seventh version) that issued by the National Health Committee of the People’s Republic of China.
simplification: In this letter, we answered one comment on our guideline and provided the newest diagnostic criteria of “suspected case” and “confirmed case”. This is according to the latest Diagnosis and Treatment Guidelines for COVID-19 (seventh version) that issued by the National Health Committee of the People’s Republic of China.

original: In December 2019, the 2019 novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) has caused an outbreak, which is now officially named as the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) and the virus has been named severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2).
simplification: In December 2019, the novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) has caused an outbreak, which is now officially named as the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19). The virus has been named severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2).

original: On 11 March 2020, WHO characterized COVID-19 as a pandemic.
simplification: On 11 March 2020, WHO declared COVID-19 as a pandemic.

original: In order to fight against the SARS-CoV-2 infection, our team has developed a rapid advice guideline and that has been published online in Military Medical Research on 06 February 2020.
simplification: In order to fight against the SARS-CoV-2 infection, our team has developed a rapid advice guideline and that has been published online in Military Medical Research on 06 February 2020.

original: It has attracted a great attention since published.
simplification: It has attracted great attention since being published.

original: Note however that COVID-19 is a new disease, our awareness and knowledge is gradually increasing based on the ongoing research findings and clinical practice experience; hence, the strategies of diagnosis and treatment are also continually updated.
simplification: COVID-19 is a new disease, so our awareness and knowledge is gradually increasing based on the ongoing research findings and clinical practice experience. Therefore, the strategies of diagnosis and treatment are also continually updated.

original: For instance the Diagnosis and Treatment Guidelines for COVID-19 issued by the National Health Committee of the People’s Republic of China (http://www.nhc.gov.cn/), among 16 January 2020 to 3 March 2020, has issued a total of seven editions with some contexts being substantively changed.
simplification: the Diagnosis and Treatment Guidelines for COVID-19 issued by the National Health Committee of the People’s Republic of China (http://www.nhc.gov.cn/), among 16 January 2020 to 3 March 2020, has issued a total of seven editions with some contexts being substantively changed.

original: Now our guideline received a comment by Zhou et al., they introduced a simple scoring proposal based on their clinical experience.
simplification: Our guideline received a comment by Zhou et al., they introduced a simple scoring proposal based on their clinical experience.

original: Their work added new evidence for our guideline and also make valuable reference for this pandemic worldwide.
simplification: Their work added new evidence for our guideline and also make valuable reference for this pandemic.

original: We endorse their significant work and express our thanks.
simplification: We endorse their significant work and express our thanks.

original: However, their work also needs update according to the latest Diagnosis and Treatment Guidelines for COVID-19 (Trial seventh version) and recently studies.
simplification: Their work also needs update according to the latest Diagnosis and Treatment Guidelines for COVID-19 (Trial seventh version) and recent studies.

original: According to the seventh edition (3 March 2020), to confirm the suspected case needs to combine any one item of epidemiological history features with two items of clinical manifestations to make a comprehensive analysis, or needs to meet three items of clinical manifestations if without clear epidemiological history:
simplification: According to the seventh edition (3 March 2020), to confirm a suspected case it needs to combine any one item of epidemiological history features with two items of clinical manifestations to make a comprehensive analysis, or needs to meet three items of clinical manifestations if without clear epidemiological history:

original: Epidemiological history: (1) a history of travel or residence in Wuhan city and surrounding areas, or other communities where COVID-19 cases had been reported in the last 14 days before symptom onset; (2) a history of contact with SARS-CoV-2 infectious cases (with positive nucleic acid test); (3) a history of contacting with patients with fever or respiratory symptoms from Wuhan city and surrounding areas, or other communities where COVID-19 had been reported in the last 14 days before symptom onset; (4) a history of contacting with cluster of confirmed cases (≥ 2 cases with fever and/or respiratory symptoms occurred within 2 weeks in small areas, such as home, office, class of school, etc).
simplification: Epidemiological history: (1) a history of travel or residence in Wuhan city and surrounding areas, or other communities where COVID-19 cases had been reported in the last 14 days before symptoms start; (2) a history of contact with SARS-CoV-2 infectious cases (with positive antibody test); (3) a history of contacting with patients with fever or respiratory symptoms from Wuhan city and surrounding areas, or other communities where COVID-19 had been reported in the last 14 days before symptom onset; (4) a history of contacting with cluster of confirmed cases (≥ 2 cases with fever and/or respiratory symptoms occurred within 2 weeks in small areas, such as home, office, etc).

original: Clinical manifestations: (1) fever and/ or respiratory symptoms; (2) with imaging features of COVID-19 infection; (3) total white blood cell counts showing normal, decreased, or reduced lymphocyte count in the early onset stage.
simplification: Clinical manifestations: (1) fever and/ or respiratory symptoms; (2) with imaging features of COVID-19 infection; (3) total white blood cell counts showing normal, decreased, or reduced lymphocyte count in the early onset stage.

original: Diagnosing the confirmed case should base on suspected case with any one item of pathogenic or serological evidence as following: (1) real-time PCR test positive for SARS-CoV-2; (2) viral whole genome sequencing showing high homogeneity to the known novel coronaviruses; (3) positive for the specific IgM antibody and IgG antibody to SARS-CoV-2 in serum test; or a change of the SARS-CoV-2-specific IgG antibody from negative to positive, or titer rising ≥4 times in the recovery phase above that in the acute phase.
simplification: Diagnosing the confirmed case should base on suspected case with any one item of medical evidence as following: (1) real-time PCR test positive for SARS-CoV-2; (2) viral whole genome sequencing showing high similarity to the known novel coronaviruses; (3) positive for the specific IgM antibody and IgG antibody to SARS-CoV-2 in serum test; or a change of the SARS-CoV-2-specific IgG antibody from negative to positive, or titer rising ≥4 times in the recovery phase above that in the acute phase.

original: We can see that the real-time PCR test for nucleic acid in respiratory tract or blood samples was added to the second (18 January 2020) and third (22 January 2020) editions.
simplification: We can see that the real-time PCR test  in respiratory tract or blood samples was added to the second (18 January 2020) and third (22 January 2020) editions.

original: The pathogenic detection of blood sample was added to the fourth (27 January 2020) and fifth (8 February 2020) editions; and then the serological evidence was added to the seventh edition.
simplification: The viral detection of blood sample was added to the fourth (27 January 2020) and fifth (8 February 2020) editions; and then the serological evidence was added to the seventh edition.

original: These modifications based on the researchers continued work that to search for an optimal nucleic acid detection kit for rapid diagnosis, as well as the samples from respiratory tract including blood sampling, which increased the availability of different specimens, and supported bringing the specific antibody positive result into the confirmed criteria.
simplification: These changes, based on researchers, continued work that to search for an optimal nucleic acid detection kit for rapid diagnosis. Also, samples from respiratory tract including blood sampling, which increased the availability of different specimens, and supported bringing the specific antibody positive result into the confirmed criteria.

original: Besides, there are more and more evidence that remind us to caution with the atypical symptomatic and asymptomatic patients.
simplification: There is increasing evidence that remind us to caution with the atypical symptomatic and asymptomatic patients.

original: Hence, the flow chart of Zhou et al. should be updated, as they classified the person without clinical symptoms as “low risk”.
simplification: The flow chart of Zhou et al. should be updated, as they classified the person without clinical symptoms as “low risk”.

original: The score system also needs to be verified in further clinical practice and studies.
simplification: The score system also needs to be verified in further clinical practice and studies.

original: To conclude, we hope more direct evidence coming up and call for readers to provide their comments.
simplification: We hope more direct evidence is emerging, and call for readers to provide their comments.

original: For the diagnosis of “suspected case” and “confirmed case”, we suggest to trace and obey the newest guidelines of their home countries.
simplification: For the diagnosis of “suspected case” and “confirmed case”, we suggest to trace and obey the newest guidelines of their countries.

original: Our team will also timely update our guideline to offer help.
simplification: Our team will also regularly update our guideline to offer help.

original: Rapidly increasing cumulative incidence of coronavirus disease (COVID-19) in the European Union/European Economic Area and the United Kingdom, 1 January to 15 March 2020
simplification: There has been a rapid increase of coronavirus (COVID-19) cases in the Europena Union and United Kingdom between 1st January and 15th March 2020.

original: The cumulative incidence of coronavirus disease (COVID-19) cases is showing similar trends in European Union/European Economic Area countries and the United Kingdom confirming that, while at a different stage depending on the country, the COVID-19 pandemic is progressing rapidly in all countries.
simplification: The increasing amount of coronavirus cases (COVID-19) in the European Union is showing a similar trend to those in the United Kingdom. This confirms that the COVID-19 pandemic is quickly progressing at different rates in all countries.

original: Based on the experience from Italy, countries, hospitals and intensive care units should increase their preparedness for a surge of patients with COVID-19 who will require healthcare, and in particular intensive care.
simplification: Hospitals across the world should be more prepared for an increase of COVID-19 patients who will require healthcare, and intensive care in particular.

original: On 31 December 2019, a cluster of pneumonia cases of unknown aetiology was reported in Wuhan, Hubei Province, China.
simplification: A group of pneumonia cases of unknown origin were reported in Wuhan, China, on the 31st December 2019.

original: On 9 January 2020, the China Center for Disease Control and Prevention reported the causative agent as being a novel coronavirus now referred to as severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2).
simplification: The China Centre for Disease Control and Prevention reported on 9th January 2020 that a novel coronavirus, now referred to as severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), caused the illnesses.

original: Since, the illness resulting from SARS-CoV-2 infection has been named coronavirus disease (COVID-19).
simplification: The illness resulting from SARS-CoV-2 infection has been named coronavirus disease (COVID-19)

original: Evidence to date is that ca 80% of individuals with COVID-19 have a mild disease, i.e. a respiratory tract infection with or without pneumonia, and most of these recover.
simplification: It has been reported that about 80% of people with COVID-19 have mild disease, i.e. a respiratory infection with or without pneumonia. Most of these patients recover.

original: In ca 14% cases, COVID-19 develops into a more severe disease requiring hospitalisation while the remaining 6% cases experience critical illness requiring intensive care.
simplification: In approximately 40% of cases, COVID-19 develops into a more severe disease that requires hospitalisation. The remaining 6% of cases experience critical illness requiring intensive care.

original: The mortality of patients hospitalised due to COVID-19 is ca 4%.
simplification: Approximately 4% of patients hospitalised due to COVID-19 do not survive.

original: In this study, we assess the trends in the cumulative incidence of COVID-19 in each European Union/European Economic Area (EU/EEA) country and the United Kingdom (UK) and compare them to that of Hubei Province, China.
simplification: In this study, we look at the trends in COVID-19 cases in each European Union/European Economic Area (EU/EEA) country and the United Kingdon (UK) and compare these to Hubai Province, China.

original: We also compare the current number of COVID-19 cases in EU/EEA countries and the UK with that in Italy during 31 January–15 March 2020.
simplification: Also, we compare the current number of COVID-19 cases in EU/EAA countries and the UK with that of Italy between 31st January - 15th March 2020

original: COVID-19 cases in EU/EEA countries and the UK
simplification: COVID-19 cases in EU/EEA countries and the UK

original: Subsequent to China, COVID-19 underwent further geographical spread and the dynamic of the COVID-19 pandemic in the rest of the world currently follows that of this country.
simplification: COVID-19 spread from China to the rest of the world. The dynamic of the COVID-19 pandemic follows that of China.

original: On 11 March 2020, the Director General of the World Health Organization (WHO) declared COVID-19 a pandemic.
simplification: The World Health Organisation (WHO) declared COVID-19 a pandemic on 11th March, 2020.

original: In the 5 March issue of Eurosurveillance 2020, Spiteri et al. reported on the first European confirmed COVID-19 cases according to the WHO case definition.
simplification: In the 5th March issue of Eusosurveillance 2020, Spiteri and collegues reported on the first confirmed COVID-19 cases in Europe.

original: In the EU/EEA, the first three confirmed cases were reported by France on 24 January 2020 in persons returning from Wuhan, Hubei Province, China.
simplification: The first three confirmed cases in the EU/EAA were reported by France on the 24th January 2020. The three people who tested positive had returned from Wuhan, China.

original: As at 15 March 2020, COVID-19 cases had been detected in all 30 EU/EEA countries and the United Kingdom (UK), whereby between 31 December 2019 and that date included, 39,768 cases and 1,727 deaths had been reported, with 17,750 cases and 1,441 deaths from Italy alone.
simplification: As of 15th March 2020, COVID-19 cases had been detected in all 30 EU/EEA countries and the United Kingdom (UK). Between 31st December 2019 and 15th March 2020, 39,768 cases and 1,727 deaths had been reported. 17,750 cases and 1,441 deaths were from Italy alone.

original: A study performed in 2010–11 showed a large variation in the availability of intensive care and intermediate care beds in Europe, ranging from 29.2 in Germany to 4.2 beds per 100,000 population in Portugal.
simplification: A study performed in 2010–11 showed a large variation in the availability of intensive care and intermediate care beds in Europe. This ranged from 29.2 in Germany to 4.2 beds per 100,000 population in Portugal

original: This means that countries may have more or less resources than Italy (12.5 intensive care and intermediate care beds per 100,000 population in 2010–11).
simplification: This means that countries may have more or less resources than Italy. Italy had 12.5 intensive care and intermediate care beds per 100,000 population in 2010–11.

original: Modelling scenarios related to healthcare capacity saturation, with estimates for each EU/EEA country and the UK of the prevalence of hospitalised COVID-19 cases associated with a > 90% risk of exceeding intensive care bed capacity, are provided in the sixth update of the ECDC rapid risk assessment on COVID-19.
simplification: Modelling scenarios related to healthcare capacity saturation are provided in the sixth update of the ECDC rapid risk assessment on COVID-19.

original: Since cases have so far clustered in certain regions in EU/EEA countries and the UK, and hospitals and intensive care units usually serve a defined regional catchment population, information about cases and intensive care beds should preferably be made available at the Nomenclature of territorial units for statistics 2 (NUTS-2) level.
simplification: Since cases have so far clustered in certain regions in EU/EEA countries and the UK,  information about cases and intensive care beds should  be made available at the Nomenclature of territorial units for statistics 2 (NUTS-2) level.

original: The experience from Italy and the current trends in other countries show that the COVID-19 pandemic is progressing rapidly in the EU/EEA and the UK.
simplification: The experience from Italy and the current trends in other countries show that the COVID-19 pandemic is progressing quiclkly in the EU/EEA and the UK.

original: Countries, hospitals and intensive care units should thus prepare themselves for a scenario of sustained community transmission of SARS-CoV-2 and an increase in the number of patients with COVID-19 requiring healthcare, and in particular intensive care, such as the one occurring in the affected regions of Italy.
simplification: Countries, hospitals and intensive care units should therefore prepare themselves for a scenario of sustained community transmission of SARS-CoV-2 and an increase in the number of patients with COVID-19 requiring healthcare, and in particular intensive care.

original: As pointed out in the recent ECDC rapid risk assessment, a rapid, proactive and comprehensive approach is essential to delay the spread of SARS-COV-2, with a shift from a containment to a mitigation approach, as the anticipated rapid increase in the number of cases may not provide decision makers and hospitals enough time to comprehend, accept and adapt their response accordingly if not implemented ahead of time.
simplification: As pointed out in the recent ECDC rapid risk assessment, a rapid, proactive and comprehensive approach is essential to delay the spread of SARS-COV-2 with a shift from a containment to a mitigation approach. The anticipated rapid increase in the number of cases may not provide decision makers and hospitals enough time to comprehend, accept and adapt their response accordingly if not applied ahead of time.

original: The rapid risk assessment also lists the public health measures to mitigate the impact of the pandemic.
simplification: The rapid risk assessment also lists the public health measures to reduce the impact of the pandemic.

original: There is a short window of opportunity during which countries have the possibility to further increase their control efforts to slow down the spread of SARS-CoV-2 and decrease the pressure on healthcare.
simplification: There is a short time frame in which countries have the possibility to further increase their control efforts to reduce the spread of SARS-CoV-2, and decrease the pressure on healthcare.

original: Failing this, it is likely that the healthcare systems of other EU/EEA countries will face a surge of patients that require intensive care within the coming days or weeks.
simplification: Failing this, it is likely that the healthcare systems of other EU/EEA countries will face a rapid increase in patients that require intensive care within the coming days or weeks.

original: The outbreak of Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), has thus far killed over 3,000 people and infected over 80,000 in China and elsewhere in the world, resulting in catastrophe for humans.
simplification: The outbreak of Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), has so far killed over 3,000 people and infected over 80,000 around the world. This has resulted in catastrophe for humans.

original: Similar to its homologous virus, SARS-CoV, which caused SARS in thousands of people in 2003, SARS-CoV-2 might also be transmitted from the bats and causes similar symptoms through a similar mechanism.
simplification: Similar to SARS-CoV, which caused SARS in thousands of people in 2003, SARS-CoV-2 might also be transmitted from the bats and causes similar symptoms through a similar mechanism.

original: However, COVID-19 has lower severity and mortality than SARS but is much more transmissive and affects more elderly individuals than youth and more men than women.
simplification: However, COVID-19 has lower severity and mortality than SARS but is much more transmissive and affects more elderly individuals than youth. It also affects more men than women.

original: In response to the rapidly increasing number of publications on the emerging disease, this article attempts to provide a timely and comprehensive review of the swiftly developing research subject.
simplification: In response to the rapidly increasing number of publications on the emerging disease, this article attempts to provide a comprehensive review of the quickly developing research subject.

original: We will cover the basics about the epidemiology, etiology, virology, diagnosis, treatment, prognosis, and prevention of the disease.
simplification: We will cover the basics about the epidemiology, etiology, virology, diagnosis, treatment, prognosis, and prevention of the disease.

original: Although many questions still require answers, we hope that this review helps in the understanding and eradication of the threatening disease.
simplification: Although many questions still require answers, we hope that this review helps in the understanding and elimination of the disease.

original: The Spring Festival on January 25, 2020 has become an unprecedented and unforgettable memory to all Chinese who were urged to stay indoors for all the holiday and for many weeks after due to the outbreak of a novel viral disease.
simplification: The Spring Festival on January 25, 2020 has become an unforgettable memory to all Chinese who were urged to stay indoors for the holiday and for many weeks after, due to the outbreak of a novel viral disease.

original: The virus is highly homologous to the coronavirus (CoV) that caused an outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in 2003; thus, it was named SARS-CoV-2 by the World Health Organization (WHO) on February 11, 2020, and the associated disease was named CoV Disease-19 (COVID-19).
simplification: The virus is highly related to the coronavirus (CoV) that caused an outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in 2003; so, it was named SARS-CoV-2 by the World Health Organization (WHO) on February 11, 2020. The associated disease was named CoV Disease-19 (COVID-19).

original: The epidemic started in Wuhan, China, and quickly spread throughout the entire country and to near 50 others all over the world.
simplification: The epidemic started in Wuhan, China, and quickly spread throughout the entire country. It also spread to near 50 others all over the world.

original: As of March 2, 2020, the virus has resulted in over 80,000 confirmed cases of COVID-19, with more than 40,000 patients discharged and over 3,000 patients who died.
simplification: As of March 2, 2020, the virus has resulted in over 80,000 confirmed cases of COVID-19. More than 40,000 patients were discharged and over 3,000 patients died.

original: WHO warns that COVID-19 is “public enemy number 1” and potentially more powerful than terrorism.
simplification: WHO warns that COVID-19 is “public enemy number 1” and potentially more powerful than terrorism.

original: According to PubMed (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/), in less than two months, over 200 papers have been published on COVID-19 including its virology, epidemiology, etiology, diagnosis, and treatment since the first report on January 7, 2020 that determined the sequence of the virus isolated from multiple patients.
simplification: According to PubMed (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/), in less than two months, over 200 papers have been published on COVID-19. The papers include its virology, epidemiology, etiology, diagnosis, and treatment since the first report on January 7, 2020. This report determined the sequence of the virus isolated from multiple patients.

original: This review attempts to summarize the research progress in the new and swiftly developing subject area.
simplification: This review attempts to summarize the research progress in the new and quickly developing subject area.

original: Whenever possible, we will try to compare COVID-19 with SARS and another CoV-caused disease, Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS, an outbreak in 2012).
simplification: Whenever possible, we will try to compare COVID-19 with SARS and another CoV-caused disease, Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS, an outbreak in 2012).

original: We will also discuss what we have learned so far regarding the prevention and prognosis of the disease as well as some remaining yet urgent questions.
simplification: We will also discuss what we have learned so far regarding the prevention and prognosis of the disease, as well as some remaining questions.

original: CoVs have been traditionally considered nonlethal pathogens to humans, mainly causing approximately 15% of common colds 4.
simplification: CoVs have been traditionally considered nonlethal pathogens to humans, causing approximately 15% of common colds.

original: However, in this century, we have encountered highly pathogenic human CoVs twice, i.e., SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV, which caused an outbreak originally in China in 2003 and Saudi Arabia in 2012, respectively, and soon spread to many other countries with horrible morbidity and mortality.
simplification: However, in this century, we have encountered highly pathogenic human CoVs twice, i.e., SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV. These CoVs caused outbreaks originally in China in 2003 and Saudi Arabia in 2012, respectively. They soon spread to many other countries with high rates of illness and death.

original: Therefore, the current COVID-19 is the third CoV outbreak in the recorded history of humans.
simplification: Therefore, the current COVID-19 is the third CoV outbreak in the recorded history of humans.

original: As shown in Fig. ​Fig.1,1, clusters of pneumonia that had unknown origins were first reported from Wuhan on December 31, 2019 to the China National Health Commission.
simplification: As shown in ​Fig.1,1, groups of pneumonia that had unknown origins were first reported from Wuhan on December 31, 2019 to the China National Health Commission.

original: Seven days later the sequence of the CoV was released.
simplification: Seven days later the sequence of the CoV was released.

original: On January 15, 2020 the first fatal case from Wuhan was reported.
simplification: On January 15, 2020 the first death from Wuhan was reported.

original: Meanwhile, the epidemic rapidly spread to the neighboring cities, provinces, and countries.
simplification: Meanwhile, the epidemic rapidly spread to the neighboring cities, provinces, and countries.

original: On January 20, the infection of health-care providers was reported, suggesting that human-to-human transmission was possible.
simplification: On January 20, the infection of health-care providers was reported. This suggested that human-human trnsmission was possible.

original: On January 23, the city of Wuhan was locked down with all its public transportation stopped.
simplification: On January 23, the city of Wuhan went into a lock down with all its public transportation stopped.

original: On January 24 the first clinical study on the disease reported that, out of 41 patients with confirmed cases, only 21 had direct contact with the Wuhan seafood market that was considered the starting site of the infection from an unknown animal source.
simplification: On January 24 the first clinical study on the disease reported that, out of 41 patients with confirmed cases, only 21 had direct contact with the Wuhan seafood market that was considered the starting site of the infection.

original: On January 30, WHO declared the outbreak a global health emergency.
simplification: On January 30, WHO declared the outbreak a global health emergency.

original: By the time of this report, the disease has already spread throughout China and near 50 other countries all over the world (Fig. ​(Fig.2).2).
simplification: By the time of this report, the disease has already spread throughout China and to near 50 other countries throughout the world (Fig. ​(Fig.2).2).

original: As the situation is rapidly evolving, the final scope and severity of the outbreak remain to be determined.
simplification: As the situation is rapidly evolving, the severity of the outbreak is yet to be determined.

original: On February 11, 2020, a multi-center study on 8,866 patients including 4,021 confirmed COVID-19 patients presented a more updated illustration of the epidemic as follows (https://mp.weixin.qq.com/s/UlBi-HX_rHPXa1qHA2bhdA).
simplification: On February 11, 2020, a multi-center study on 8,866 patients including, 4,021 confirmed COVID-19 patients, presented a more updated illustration of the epidemic (https://mp.weixin.qq.com/s/UlBi-HX_rHPXa1qHA2bhdA).

original: Thus, we can only refer to previous studies on other CoVs, especially SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV (Fig. ​(Fig.4).4).
simplification: Therefore, we can only refer to previous studies on other CoVs.

original: In general, after a virus invades the host, it is first recognized by the host innate immune system through pattern recognition receptors (PRRs) including C-type lectin-like receptors, Toll-like receptor (TLR), NOD-like receptor (NLR), and RIG-I-like receptor (RLR).
simplification: After a virus invades a host, generally it is first recognised by the host's innate immune system through pattern recognition receptors (PRRs).

original: Through different pathways, the virus induces the expression of inflammatory factors, maturation of dendritic cells, and synthesis of type I interferons (IFNs) which limit the spreading of the virus and accelerate macrophage phagocytosis of viral antigens.
simplification: The virus induces the expression of inflammator factors, maturation of dendritic cells, and synthesis of type I interferons (IFNs). These limit the spread of the virus and speed up macrophage phagocytosis of viral antigens.

original: However, the N protein of SARS-CoV can help the virus escape from the immune responses.
simplification: The N protein of SARS-CoV can help the virus escapes from the immune responses.

original: Soon, the adaptive immune response joins the fight against the virus.
simplification: Soon, the adaptive immune response joins the fight against the virus.

original: T lymphocytes including CD4+ and CD8+ T cells play an important role in the defense.
simplification: T lymphocytes play an important role in the defense.

original: CD4+ T cells stimulate B cells to produce virus-specific antibodies, and CD8+ T cells directly kill virus-infected cells.
simplification: CD4+ T cells stimulate B cells to produce virus-specific antibodies. CD8+ T cells directly kill virus-infected cells

original: T helper cells produce proinflammatory cytokines to help the defending cells.
simplification: T helper cells produce proinflammatory cytokines. These help the defending cells.

original: However, CoV can inhibit T cell functions by inducing apoptosis of T cells.
simplification: However, CoV can inhibit T cell functions by inducing cell death in T cells.

original: The humoral immunity including complements such as C3a and C5a and antibodies is also essential in combating the viral infection.
simplification: The humoral immunity, including complements and antibodies, is also essential in combating the viral infection.

original: For example, antibodies isolated from a recovered patient neutralized MERS-CoV.
simplification: For example, antibodies isolated from a recovered patient fought against MERS-CoV.

original: On the other hand, an overreaction of the immune system generates a large number of free radicals locally that can cause severe damages to the lungs and other organs, and, in the worst scenario, multi-organ failure and even death.
simplification: On the other hand, an overreaction of the immune system generates a large number of free radicals locally that can cause severe damages to the lungs and other organs. In the worst scenario, this can lead to multi-organ failure and even death.

original: The SARS-CoV-2 infection, featured by clustering onset, is more likely to affect elderly people with comorbidities and pregnant women.
simplification: The SARS-CoV-2 infection is more likely to affect elderly people with comorbidities and pregnant women.

original: It is common that for people who are exposed to a large number of viruses or whose immune functions are compromised, they have higher chance to be infected than others.
simplification: It is common that for people whose immune functions are compromised to have a higher chance of being infected than others.

original: The estimated mean incubation period of SARS-CoV-2 is 1-14 days, mostly 3-7 days based on a study of the first 425 cases in Wuhan.
simplification: The estimated mean incubation period of SARS-CoV-2 is 1-14 days. Most often, incubation period is 3-7 days, based on a study of the first 425 cases in Wuhan

original: However, a study on 1,099 cases demonstrates that the incubation period was 3 days on average and ranged from 0 to 24 days.
simplification: However, a study on over 1000 cases demonstrates that the incubation period was 3 days on average, and ranged from 0 to 24 days

original: A more recent study, as described above, demonstrates that the incubation period was 4.8 (3.0-7.2) days based on the demography of 8,866 cases.
simplification: A more recent study demonstrates that the incubation period was 4.8 (3.0-7.2) days based on the demography of around 9,000 cases.

original: It is very important for health authorities to adjust the effective quarantine time based on the most accurate incubation period, thus preventing infected but symptomless people from transmitting the virus to others.
simplification: It is very important for health authorities to adjust the effective quarantine time based on the most accurate incubation period. Therefore, this prevents infected but symptomless people from giving the virus to others.

original: As a common practice, individuals exposed to, or infected by, the virus are usually required to be quarantined for 14 days.
simplification: Individuals exposed to, or infected by, the virus are usually required to be quarantined for 14 days.

original: Should the quarantine time be extended to 24 days?
simplification: Should the quarantine time be increased to 24 days?

original: Fever is often the major and initial symptom of COVID-19, which can be accompanied by no symptom or other symptoms such as dry cough, shortness of breath, muscle ache, dizziness, headache, sore throat, rhinorrhea, chest pain, diarrhea, nausea, and vomiting.
simplification: Fever is often the major and first symptom of COVID-19, which can be accompanied by no symptoms or other symptoms, such as a dry cough.

original: Some patients experienced dyspnea and/or hypoxemia one week after the onset of the disease.
simplification: Some patients experienced shortness of breath and/or low levels of oxygen in the blood. These symptoms occurred one week after the onset of the disease.

original: In severe cases, patients quickly progressed to develop acute respiratory syndrome, septic shock, metabolic acidosis, and coagulopathy.
simplification: In severe cases, patients quickly progressed to develop acute respiratory syndrome, septic shock, metabolic acidosis, and coagulopathy.

original: Patients with fever and/or respiratory symptoms and acute fever, even without pulmonary imaging abnormalities, should be screened for the virus for early diagnosis.
simplification: Patients with fever and/or respiratory symptoms and acute fever should be screened for the virus for early diagnosis.

original: A demographic study in late December of 2019 showed that the percentages of the symptoms were 98% for fever, 76% for dry cough, 55% for dyspnea, and 3% for diarrhea; 8% of the patients required ventilation support.
simplification: A demographic study in December 2019 showed that the percentages of the symptoms were 98% for fever, 76% for dry cough, 55% for dyspnea, and 3% for diarrhea. 8% of the patients required ventilation support.

original: Similar findings were reported in two recent studies of a family cluster and a cluster caused by transmission from an asymptomatic individual.
simplification: Similar findings were reported in two recent studies of a family group, and a group caused by transmission from an infected person with no symptoms

original: Comparably, a demographic study in 2012 showed that MERS-CoV patients also had fever (98%), dry cough (47%), and dyspnea (55%) as their main symptoms.
simplification: A demographic study in 2012 showed that MERS-CoV patients also had fever (98%), dry cough (47%), and shortness of breath (55%) as their main symptoms.

original: However, 80% of them required ventilation support, much more than COVID-19 patients and consistent with the higher lethality of MERS than of COVID-19.
simplification: However, 80% of them required ventilation support. This number is much higher than COVID-19 patients and consistent with the higher death rate of MERS than of COVID-19.

original: Diarrhea (26%) and sore throat (21%) were also observed with MERS patients.
simplification: Diarrhea and sore throat were also observed in MERS patients.

original: In SARS patients, it has been demonstrated that fever (99%-100%), dry cough (29%-75%), dyspnea (40%-42%), diarrhea (20-25%), and sore throat (13-25%) were the major symptoms and ventilation support was required for approximately 14%-20% of the patients.
simplification: In SARS patients, it has been demonstrated that fever (99%-100%), dry cough (29%-75%), dyspnea (40%-42%), diarrhea (20-25%), and sore throat (13-25%) were the major symptoms. Ventilation support was required for approximately 14%-20% of the patients.

original: By February 14, the mortality of COVID-19 was 2% when the confirmed cases reached 66,576 globally.
simplification: By February 14, the death rate of COVID-19 was 2% when the confirmed cases exceeded 66,000 globally.

original: Comparably, the mortality of SARS by November 2002 was 10% of 8,096 confirmed cases.
simplification: Comparably, the death rate of SARS by November 2002 was 10% of over 8,000 confirmed cases.

original: For MERS, based on a demographic study in June 2012, the mortality was 37% of 2,494 confirmed cases.
simplification: For MERS, based on a study in 2012, the mortality was 37% of 2,494 confirmed cases.

original: An earlier study reported that the R0 of SARS-CoV-2 was as high as 6.47 with a 95% confidence interval (CI) of 5.71-7.23, whereas the R0 of SARS-CoV only ranged from 2 to 4.
simplification: An earlier study reported that the R0 of SARS-CoV-2 was as high as 6.47 with a 95% confidence interval (CI) of 5.71-7.23. The R0 of SARS-CoV only ranged from 2 to 4.

original: A comparison of SARS-CoV-2 with MERS-CoV and SARA-CoV regarding their symptoms, mortality, and R0 is presented in Table ​Table1.1.
simplification: A comparison of SARS-CoV-2 with MERS-CoV and SARA-CoV regarding their symptoms, mortality, and R0 is presented in Table 1.1.

original: The above figures suggest that SARS-CoV-2 has a higher ability to spread than MERS-CoV and SARS-CoV, but it is less lethal than the latter two.
simplification: The above figures suggest that SARS-CoV-2 has more of an ability to spread than MERS-CoV and SARS-CoV, but it is less lethal than the latter two.

original: Clustered onset often happens in the same family or from the same gathering or vehicle such as a cruise ship.
simplification: Clustered onset often happens in the same family. Or, it may happen from the same gathering or vehicle.

original: Patients often have a history of travel or residence in Wuhan or other affected areas or contact with infected individuals or patients in the recent two weeks before the onset.
simplification: Patients often have a history of travel or residence in Wuhan, or other affected areas, or have had contact with infected individuals within two weeks before the onset.

original: However, it has been reported that people can carry the virus without symptoms longer than two weeks and cured patients discharged from hospitals can carry the virus again, which sends out an alarm to increase the time for quarantine.
simplification: However, it has been reported that people can carry the virus without symptoms longer than 2 weeks and cured patients discharged from hospitals can carry the virus again. This sends out an alarm to increase the time for quarantine.

original: Patients have normal or reduced number of peripheral white blood cells (especially lymphocytes) at the early stage.
simplification: Patients have normal or reduced number of peripheral white blood cells at the early stage.

original: For example, lymphopenia with white blood cell count < 4×109/L including lymphocyte count < 1×109/L, and elevated aspartate aminotransferase levels and viremia were found in 1,099 COVID-19 patients.
simplification: For example, lymphopenia, elevated aspartate aminotransferase levels and viremia were found in over 1,000 COVID-19 patients.

original: The levels of liver and muscle enzymes and myoglobin were increased in the blood of some patients, and C-reactive protein and erythrocyte sedimentation were increased in the blood of most patients.
simplification: The levels of liver and muscle enzymes and myoglobin were increased in the blood of some patients. C-reactive protein and erythrocyte sedimentation were increased in the blood of most patients.

original: In patients with severe cases, the level of D-dimer, a fibrin degradation product present in the blood, was elevated, and lymphocyte count was progressively reduced.
simplification: In patients with severe cases, lymphocyte count was progressively reduced and the level of D-dimer was elevated. D-dimer is a fibrin degradation product present in the blood.

original: Abnormalities in chest radiography are found in most COVID-19 patients and featured by bilateral patchy shadows or ground glass opacity in the lungs.
simplification: Abnormalities in chest radiography are found in most COVID-19 patients. These abnormalities featured bilateral patchy shadows or ground glass opacity in the lungs.

original: Patients often develop an atypical pneumonia, acute lung injury, and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
simplification: Patients often develop an atypical pneumonia, acute lung injury, and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).

original: When ARDS happens, uncontrolled inflammation, fluid accumulation, and progressive fibrosis severely compromise the gas exchange.
simplification: When ARDS happens, uncontrolled inflammation, fluid accumulation, and progressive fibrosis severely compromise the gas exchange.

original: Dysfunction of type-I and type-II pneumocytes decreases the surfactant level and increases surface tension, thus reducing the ability of the lungs to expand and heightening the risk of lung collapse.
simplification: Dysfunction of type-I and type-II pneumocytes decreases the surfactant level and increases surface tension. Therefore, this reduces the ability of the lungs to expand and increases the risk of lung collapse.

original: Therefore, the worst chest radiographic findings often parallel the most severe extent of the disease.
simplification: Therefore, the worst chest radiographic findings are often found in the most severe extent of the disease.

original: On February 18, 2020, the first pathological analysis of COVID-19 demonstrated the desquamation of pneumocytes, hyaline membrane formation, and interstitial lymphocyte infiltration, and multinucleated syncytial cells in the lungs of a patient who died of the disease, consistent with the pathology of viral infection and ARDS and similar to that of SARS and MERS patients.
simplification: In February 2020, the first pathological analysis of COVID-19 demonstrated the desquamation of pneumocytes, hyaline membrane formation, and interstitial lymphocyte infiltration, and multinucleated syncytial cells in the lungs of a patient who died of the disease. These findngs were consistent with the pathology of viral infection and ARDS, and were similar to that of SARS and MERS patients.

original: The detection of SARS-CoV-2 RNA via reverse-transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) was used as the major criteria for the diagnosis of COVID-19.
simplification: The detection of SARS-CoV-2 RNA via reverse-transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) was used as the main criteria for the diagnosis of COVID-19.

original: However, due to the high false-negative rate, which may accelerate the epidemic, clinical manifestations started to be used for diagnosis (which no longer solely relied on RT-PCR) in China on February 13, 2020.
simplification: However, due to the high false-negative rate, clinical manifestations started to be used for diagnosis (which no longer solely relied on RT-PCR) in China on February 13, 2020.

original: A similar situation also occurred with the diagnosis of SARS.
simplification: A similar situation also occurred with the diagnosis of SARS.

original: Therefore, a combination of disease history, clinical manifestations, laboratory tests, and radiological findings is essential and imperative for making an effective diagnosis.
simplification: Therefore, a combination of disease history, clinical manifestations, laboratory tests are essential for making an effective diagnosis.

original: On February 14, 2020, the Feng Zhang group described a protocol of using the CRISPR-based SHERLOCK technique to detect SARS-CoV-2, which detects synthetic SARS-CoV-2 RNA fragments at 20 × 10-18 mol/L to 200 × 10-18 mol/L (10-100 copies per microliter of input) using a dipstick in less than an hour without requiring elaborate instrumentation.
simplification: On February 14, 2020, the Feng Zhang group described a protocol of using the CRISPR-based SHERLOCK technique to detect SARS-CoV-2. This technique detects synthetic SARS-CoV-2 RNA fragments at 20 × 10-18 mol/L to 200 × 10-18 mol/L (10-100 copies per microliter of input) using a dipstick in less than an hour. It does not require elaborate instrumentation.

original: Hopefully, the new technique can dramatically enhance the sensitivity and convenience if verified in clinical samples.
simplification: Hopefully, the new technique can enhance the sensitivity and convenience, if verified in clinical samples.

original: Due to the lack of experience with the novel CoV, physicians can mainly provide supportive care to COVID-19 patients, while attempting a variety of therapies that have been used or proposed before for the treatment of other CoVs such as SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV and other viral diseases (Table ​(Table2).2).
simplification: Due to the lack of experience with the novel CoV, physicians can mainly provide supportive care to COVID-19 patients, whilst attempting a variety of therapies that have been used or proposed before for the treatment of other CoVs and other viral diseases (Table ​(Table2).2).

original: Even plasma from recovered patients was proposed to be used for treatment.
simplification: Plasma from recovered patients was also proposed to be used for treatment.

original: Pharmaceutical companies are racing to develop antibodies and vaccines against the virus.
simplification: Pharmaceutical companies are racing to develop treatments and vaccines against the virus.

original: SARS-CoV-2 mainly attacks the lungs in the beginning and probably also attacks, to a lesser degree, other organs that express ACE2, such as the gastrointestinal system and the kidneys.
simplification: SARS-CoV-2 mainly attacks the lungs in the beginning and probably also attacks other organs that express ACE2, such as the gastrointestinal system and the kidneys.

original: Nevertheless, respiratory dysfunction and failure are the major threat to the patients and the major cause of death.
simplification: Respiratory dysfunction and failure are the main threat to the patients and the main cause of death.

original: Thus, respiratory support is critical to relieve the symptoms and save lives and includes general oxygen therapy, high-flow oxygen, noninvasive ventilation, and invasive mechanical ventilation depending on the severity of the disease.
simplification: Therefore, respiratory support is essential to relieve the symptoms and save lives. Respiratory support includes general oxygen therapy, high-flow oxygen, noninvasive ventilation, and invasive mechanical ventilation. Treatment depends on the severity of the disease.

original: Patients with severe respiratory symptoms have to be supported by extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO), a modified cardiopulmonary bypass technique used for the treatment of life-threatening cardiac or respiratory failure.
simplification: Patients with severe respiratory symptoms have to be supported by extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO). ECMO is a modified cardiopulmonary bypass technique used for the treatment of life-threatening cardiac or respiratory failure.

original: In addition, the maintenance of electrolyte balance, the prevention and treatment of secondary infection and septic shock, and the protection of the functions of the vital organs are also essential for SARS-CoV-2 patients.
simplification: Also essential for SARS-CoV-2 patients is the maintenance of electrolyte balance, prevention and treatment of secondary infection and septic shock, and the protection of the functions of the vital organs.

original: It has been known that a cytokine storm results from an overreaction of the immune system in SARS and MERS patients.
simplification: A cytokine storm results from an overreaction of the immune system in SARS and MERS patients.

original: Comorbidities and complications: Patients with COVID-19 who require intensive care are more likely to suffer from acute cardiac injury and arrhythmia.
simplification: Patients with COVID-19 who require intensive care are more likely to suffer from acute cardiac injury and arrhythmia.

original: Cardiac events were also the main reason for death in SARS patients.
simplification: Heart problems were also the main reason for death in SARS patients.

original: It has been reported that SARS-CoV-2 can also bind to ACE2-positive cholangiocytes, which might lead to liver dysfunctions in COVID-19 patients.
simplification: It has been reported that SARS-CoV-2 can also bind to ACE2-positive cholangiocytes. This might lead to liver dysfunctions in COVID-19 patients.

original: It is worth noting that age and underlying disease are strongly correlated and might interfere with each other.
simplification: Age and underlying disease are strongly correlated and might interfere with each other.

original: Abnormal laboratory findings: The C-reactive protein (CRP) level in blood reflects the severity of inflammation or tissue injury and has been proposed to be a potential prognostic factor for disease, response to therapy, and ultimate recovery.
simplification: Abnormal laboratory findings: The C-reactive protein (CRP) level in blood reflects the severity of inflammation or tissue injury. CRP has been proposed to be a potential prognostic factor for disease, response to therapy, and ultimate recovery.

original: The correlation of CRP level to the severity and prognosis of COVID-19 has also been proposed.
simplification: The correlation of CRP level to the severity and course of COVID-19 has also been suggested.

original: In addition, elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), aspartate aminotransferase (AST), alanine aminotransferase (ALT), and creatine kinase (CK) may also help predict the outcome.
simplification: Elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), aspartate aminotransferase (AST), alanine aminotransferase (ALT), and creatine kinase (CK) may also help predict the outcome.

original: These enzymes are expressed extensively in multiple organs, especially in the heart and liver, and are released during tissue damage.
simplification: These enzymes are expressed extensively in multiple organs, especially in the heart and liver. The enzymes are released during tissue damage.

original: Thus, they are traditional markers for heart or liver dysfunctions.
simplification: Therefore, they are markers for heart or liver dysfunctions.

original: Major clinical symptoms: Chest radiography and temporal progression of clinical symptoms should be considered together with the other issues for the prediction of outcomes and complications of COVID-19.
simplification: Major clinical symptoms: Chest radiography and temporal progression of clinical symptoms should be considered alongside the other issues for the prediction of outcomes and complications of COVID-19.

original: Use of steroids: As described above, steroids are immunosuppressant commonly used as an adjunctive therapy for infectious diseases to reduce the severity of inflammatory damage.
simplification: Use of steroids: Steroids are immunosuppressants. commonly used as a supplementary therapy for infectious diseases. Steriods reduce the severity of inflammatory damage.

original: Since a high dosage of corticosteroids was widely used in severe SARS patients, many survivors suffered from avascular osteonecrosis with life-long disability and poor life quality.
simplification: Since a high dosage of corticosteroids was widely used in severe SARS patients, many survivors suffered from avascular osteonecrosis. This caused life-long disability and poor life quality.

original: Thus, if needed, steroids should be used at low dosage and for a short time in COVID-19 patients.
simplification: If needed, steroids should be used at low dosage and for a short time in COVID-19 patients.

original: Mental stress: As described above, during the COVID-19 outbreak many patients have suffered from extraordinary stress as they often endured long periods of quarantine and extreme uncertainty and witnessed the death of close family members and fellow patients.
simplification: Mental stress: During the COVID-19 outbreak many patients have suffered from extraordinary stress. Patients have often endured long periods of quarantine, faced extreme uncertainty and witnessed the death of others close to them.

original: It is imperative to provide psychological counseling and long-term support to help these patients recover from the stress and return to normal life.
simplification: It is necessary to provide psychological counseling and long-term support to help these patients recover from the stress and return to normal life.

original: According to demographic studies so far, COVID-19 seems to have different epidemiological features from SARS.
simplification: COVID-19 seems to have different epidemiological features from SARS, studies have suggested.

original: In addition to replicating in the lower respiratory tract, SARS-CoV-2 can efficiently replicate in the upper respiratory tract and causes mild or no symptoms in the early phase of infection, similar to other CoVs that cause common colds.
simplification: In addition to replicating in the lower respiratory tract, SARS-CoV-2 can efficiently replicate in the upper respiratory tract. This can cause mild or no symptoms in the early stage of infection, similar to other CoVs that cause common colds.

original: Therefore, infected patients at the early phase or incubation period can produce a large amount of virus during daily activities, causing great difficulty for the control of the epidemic.
simplification: Therefore, infected patients at the early stage of infection can produce a large amount of virus during daily activities. This can cause difficulty in controlling the epidemic.

original: However, the transmission of SARS-CoV was considered to occur when the patients are severely ill, while most transmission did not happen at the early phase.
simplification: The transmission of SARS-CoV was considered to occur when the patients are severely ill, while most transmission did not happen at the early phase.

original: Thus, the current outbreak of COVID-19 is much more severe and difficult to control than the outbreak of SARS.
simplification: Therefore, the current outbreak of COVID-19 is much more severe and difficult to control than the outbreak of SARS.

original: Great efforts are currently underway in China including the lockdown of Wuhan and surrounding cities and continuous quarantine of almost the entire population in hopes of interrupting the transmission of SARS-CoV-2.
simplification: Great efforts are currently underway in China, including the lockdown of Wuhan and surrounding cities. China have ensured continuous quarantine of almost the entire population in hopes of stopping the spread of SARS-CoV-2.

original: Although these actions have been dramatically damaging the economy and other sectors of the country, the number of new patients is declining, indicating the slowdown of the epidemic.
simplification: These actions have been dramatically damaging the economy and other sectors of the country. However, the number of new patients is declining, indicating the slowdown of the epidemic.

original: The most optimistic estimate is that the outbreak will end by March and the downswing phase will last for 3-4 months.
simplification: The most optimistic estimate is that the outbreak will end by March and the downswing phase will last for 3-4 months.

original: However, some other experts are not that optimistic.
simplification: However, some other experts are not that optimistic.

original: Paul Hunter, et al., estimated that COVID-19, which seems substantially more infectious than SARS, will not end in 2020.
simplification: Paul Hunter and collegues estimated that COVID-19 will not end in 2020.

original: Ira Longini, et al., established a model to predict the outcome of the epidemic and suggested that SARS-CoV-2 could infect two-thirds of the global population.
simplification: Ira Longini and collegues created a model to predict the outcome of the epidemic. They suggested that SARS-CoV-2 could infect 2/3 of the global population.

original: A Canadian group reported that SARS-CoV-2 was detected in both mid-turbinate and throat swabs of patients who recovered and left the hospital 2 weeks earlier, which indicates that the newly identified virus could become a cyclical episode similar to influenza.
simplification: It has been reported that SARS-CoV-2 was detected in both nose and throat swabs of patients who recovered and left the hospital 2 weeks earlier. This indicates that the newly identified virus could become a cyclical episode, similar to influenza.

original: However, promising signs have occurred in China based on the declining number of new cases, indicating the current strategies might have been working.
simplification: However, promising signs have occurred in China based on the declining number of new cases, suggesting the current strategies might have been working.

original: Ebola was originally predicted to cause up to a million cases with half a million deaths.
simplification: Ebola was originally predicted to cause up to 1 million cases with 500,000 deaths.

original: However, via strict quarantine and isolation, the disease has eventually been put under control.
simplification: However, with strict quarantine and isolation, the disease has eventually been controlled.

original: It is possible, similar to SARS-CoV, that SARS-CoV-2 might become weaker in infectivity and eventually die down or become a less pathogenic virus co-existent with humans.
simplification: It is possible that SARS-CoV-2 might become less infectious and eventually die down. It may become a less pathogenic virus that can co-exist with humans.

original: A comparison of the epidemic of COVID-19 with that of SARS and MERS is provided below (Fig. ​(Fig.55).
simplification: A comparison of the epidemic of COVID-19 with that of SARS and MERS is provided below (Fig. ​(Fig.55).

original: SARS-CoV-2 is highly transmittable through coughing or sneezing, and possibly also through direct contact with materials contaminated by the virus.
simplification: SARS-CoV-2 is easily spread through coughing or sneezing, and possibly also through touching items contaminated by the virus.

original: The virus was also found in feces, which raises a new possibility of feces-to-mouth transmission.
simplification: The virus was also found in feces, which raises a new possibility of feces-to-mouth transmission.

original: A recent study on 138 cases reported that 41% of the cases were possibly caused by nosocomial infections, including 17 patients with other prior diseases and 40 health-care providers.
simplification: A recent study on 138 cases reported that 41% of the cases were possibly caused by hospital infections. This included 17 patients with other prior diseases and 40 health-care providers

original: Thus, great precaution should be used to protect humans, especially health-care providers, social workers, family members, colleagues, and even bystanders in contact with patients or infected people.
simplification: Therefore, great precaution should be used to protect humans, especially everyone who is in contact with patients and infected people.

original: The first line of defense that could be used to lower the risk of infection is through wearing face masks; both the use of surgical masks and N95 respirator masks (series # 1860s) helps control the spread of viruses.
simplification: The first line of defense that could be used to lower the risk of infection is through wearing face masks; both the use of surgical masks and N95 respirator masks (series # 1860s) helps control the spread of viruses.

original: Surgical face masks prevent liquid droplets from a potentially infected individual from traveling through the air or sticking onto surfaces of materials, where they could be passed on to others.
simplification: Surgical face masks prevent liquid droplets from a potentially infected person from traveling through the air, or sticking onto surfaces of materials.

original: However, only N95 (series # 1860s) masks can protect against the inhalation of virions as small as 10 to 80 nm, with only 5% of the virions being able to penetrate completely; SARS-CoV-2 is similar to SARS-CoV in size and both are approximately 85 nm.
simplification: However, only N95 (series # 1860s) masks can protect against the inhalation of virions as small as 10 to 80 nm, with only 5% of the virions being able to pass through the mask completely. SARS-CoV-2 is similar to SARS-CoV in size as both are approximately 85 nm.

original: Since particles can penetrate even five surgical masks stacked together, health-care providers in direct contact with patients must wear N95 (series # 1860s) masks but not surgical masks.
simplification: Since particles can pass through five surgical masks stacked together, health-care providers in direct contact with patients must wear N95 (series # 1860s) masks.

original: In addition to masks, health-care providers should wear fitted isolation gowns in order to further reduce contact with viruses.
simplification: In addition to masks, health-care providers should wear fitted isolation gowns in order to further reduce contact with viruses.

original: Viruses can also infect an individual through the eyes.
simplification: Viruses can also infect people through the eyes.

original: On January 22, 2020, a doctor was infected with SARS-CoV-2 although he wore an N95 mask; the virus might have entered his body through his inflammatory eyes.
simplification: On January 22, 2020, a doctor who was wearing an N95 mask was infected with SARS-CoV-2. It has been suggested that the virus might have entered his body through his eyes.

original: Thus, health-care providers should also wear transparent face shields or goggles while working with patients.
simplification: Therefore, health-care providers should also wear transparent face shields or goggles while working with patients.

original: For the general public in affected or potentially affected areas, it is highly suggested that everybody wash their hands with disinfectant soaps more often than usual, try to stay indoors for self-quarantine and limit contact with potentially infected individuals.
simplification: For the general public, it is highly suggested that everybody wash their hands with disinfectant soaps more often than usual. Everyone should also try to stay indoors for self-quarantine and limit contact with potentially infected individuals.

original: Three feet is considered an appropriate distance for people to stay away from a patient.
simplification: 3 feet is considered an appropriate distance for people to stay away from a patient.

original: These actions are effective methods to lower the risk of infection as well as prevent the spread of the virus.
simplification: These actions are effective ways to lower the risk of infection, as well as prevent the spread of the virus.

original: Although SARS-CoV-2 came as a new virus to the human world, its high homology to SARS-CoV as reported on 7 January 2020 should have caused high alert to China based on her deep memory of the SARS outbreak in 2003.
simplification: Although SARS-CoV-2 came as a new virus to the human world, its high similarity to SARS-CoV should have caused high alert to China, based on the SARS outbreak in 2003.

original: However, not until 19 January 2020 did the director of the Center of Disease Control of Wuhan comfort the citizens by saying that the novel virus has low contagiousness and limited reproductivity from human to human and that it is not a problem to prevent and contain the disease.
simplification: However, not until 19 January 2020 did the director of the Center of Disease Control of Wuhan comfort the citizens by saying that the novel virus has low contagiousness and limited reproductivity from human to human. The director also announced that it is not a problem to prevent and contain the disease.

original: This message remarkably relaxed the alarm of the public, especially when the entire country was preparing for the Spring Festival, and the critical time was missed to contain the disease at its minimal scale in Wuhan.
simplification: This message relaxed the alarm of the public, especially when the entire country was preparing for the Spring Festival, and the critical time was missed to contain the disease at its minimal scale in Wuhan.

original: The disease control agencies in China may take this hard lesson and make critical improvements in the future.
simplification: The disease control agencies in China may take this hard lesson and make important improvements in the future.

original: The outbreak of COVID-19 caused by the novel virus SARS-CoV-2 started in the end of December 2019.
simplification: The outbreak of COVID-19, caused by the novel virus SARS-CoV-2, started at the end of December 2019

original: In less than two months, it has spread all over China and near 50 other countries globally at the time of this writing.
simplification: In less than two months, it has spread all over China and near 50 other countries globally.

original: Since the virus is very similar to SARS-CoV and the symptoms are also similar between COVID-19 and SARS, the outbreak of COVID-19 has created a sense of SARS recurring.
simplification: Since the virus is very similar to SARS-CoV and the symptoms between the two viruses are similar, the outbreak of COVID-19 has created a sense of SARS recurring.

original: However, there are some remarkable differences between COVID-19 and SARS, which are essential for containing the epidemic and treating the patients.
simplification: However, there are some remarkable differences between COVID-19 and SARS. These are essential for containing the epidemic and treating the patients.

original: COVID-19 affects more elderly individuals than youth and more men than women, and the severity and death rate are also higher in elderly individual than in youth.
simplification: COVID-19 affects more elderly individuals than youth, and the severity and death rate are also higher in elderly individual than in youth. COVID-19 also affects more men than women.

original: SARS has higher mortality than COVID-19 (10.91% versus 1.44%).
simplification: SARS has higher death rate than COVID-19 (10.91% versus 1.44%).

original: COVID-19 patients transmit the virus even when they are symptomless whereas SARS patients do so usually when they are severely ill, which causes much greater difficulty to contain the spread of COVID-19 than SARS.
simplification: COVID-19 patients transmit the virus even when they are symptomless, whereas SARS patients do so usually when they are severely ill. This causes greater difficulty to contain the spread of COVID-19 than SARS.

original: This partially explains why SARS-CoV-2 spread much faster and broader than SARS-CoV.
simplification: This partially explains why SARS-CoV-2 spread much faster and broader than SARS-CoV.

original: The regular RNA assay for SARS-CoV-2 can be negative in some COVID-19 patients.
simplification: The regular RNA assay for SARS-CoV-2 can be negative in some COVID-19 patients.

original: On the other hand, cured patients can be positive for the virus again.
simplification: Cured patients can be positive for the virus again.

original: These findings dramatically increase the risk of virus spreading.
simplification: These findings dramatically increase the risk of virus spreading.

original: Given such rapid progress in research on COVID-19, several critical issues remain to be solved, as follows:
simplification: Despite such rapid progress in research on COVID-19, several critical issues remain to be solved:

original: Where did SARS-CoV-2 come from?
simplification: Where did SARS-CoV-2 come from?

original: Although 96% genetic homolog was found between SARS-CoV-2 and two bat SARS-like CoVs, we still cannot conclude that SARS-CoV-2 is from bats.
simplification: Although 96% genetic similarity was found between SARS-CoV-2 and two bat SARS-like CoVs, we still cannot conclude that SARS-CoV-2 is from bats.

original: What animal was the intermediate species to transmit the virus from the original host, say bats, to humans?
simplification: What animal was the species to transmit the virus from the original host, say bats, to humans?

original: However, currently there is no evidence in support of a direct pangolin origin of SARS-CoV-2 due to the sequence divergence between SARS-CoV-2 and pangolin SARS-CoV-2-related beta-CoVs.
simplification: Currently, there is no evidence to say that SARS-CoV-2 was of direcyly pangolin origin. This is due to the sequence difference between SARS-CoV-2 and pangolin SARS-CoV-2-related beta-CoVs.

original: In addition, the distance between SARS-CoV-2 and RaTG13 is even shorter than that between SARS-CoV-2 and pangolin SARS-CoV-2-related beta-CoVs.
simplification: The distance between SARS-CoV-2 and RaTG13 is shorter than that between SARS-CoV-2 and pangolin SARS-CoV-2-related beta-CoVs.

original: The evolutionary pathway of SARS-CoV-2 in bats, pangolins and other mammals remains to be established.
simplification: The evolution of SARS-CoV-2 in bats, pangolins and other mammals remains to be known.

original: Whereas the highest sequence homology has been found in the RBDs between SARS-CoV-2 and pangolin, SARS-CoV-2-related beta-CoVs, SARS-CoV-2 and RaTG13 share the highest genome-wide sequence homology.
simplification: The highest sequence similarity has been found in the RBDs between SARS-CoV-2 and pangolin and SARS-CoV-2-related beta-CoVs. SARS-CoV-2 and RaTG13 share the highest genome-wide sequence similarity.

original: It is highly speculative that the high degree of similarity between the RBDs of pangolin SARS-CoV-2-related beta-CoVs and SARS-CoV-2 is driven by selectivity-mediated convergent evolution.
simplification: The high degree of similarity between the RBDs of pangolin SARS-CoV-2-related beta-CoVs and SARS-CoV-2 may be driven by selectivity-mediated convergent evolution.

original: As a driving force in evolution, recombination is widespread among beta-CoVs.
simplification: Recombination is widespread among beta-CoVs, as it helps evolution.

original: The jury is still out on the immediate zoonotic origin of SARS-CoV-2.
simplification: The immediate zoonotic origin of SARS-CoV-2 is still unknown.

original: Besides the highly pathogenic HCoVs, the zoonotic origin of HCoV-229E, HCoV-OC43, HCoV-NL63 and HCoV-HKU1 have also been studied.
simplification: The zoonotic origin of less pathogenic HCoVs, HCoV-229E, HCoV-OC43, HCoV-NL63 and HCoV-HKU1,have also been studied.

original: Phylogenetic evidence indicated that both HCoV-NL63 and HCoV-229E might have originated from bat CoVs, while the parental viruses of HCoV-OC43 and HCoV-HKU1 have been found in rodents.
simplification: Phylogenetic evidence indicated that both HCoV-NL63 and HCoV-229E might have originated from bat CoVs. On the other hand, the parental viruses of HCoV-OC43 and HCoV-HKU1 have been found in rodents.

original: It has been reported that a bat CoV termed ARCoV.2 (Appalachian Ridge CoV) detected in North American tricolored bat displayed close relationship with HCoV-NL63.
simplification: It has been reported that a bat CoV termed ARCoV.2 (Appalachian Ridge CoV) detected in North American tricolored bat showed a close relationship with HCoV-NL63.

original: On the other hand, HCoV-229E was genetically related to another bat CoV, termed Hipposideros/GhanaKwam/19/2008, which was detected in Ghana, while camelids have also been suspected as its intermediate host.
simplification: HCoV-229E was genetically related to another bat CoV, termed Hipposideros/GhanaKwam/19/2008, which was detected in Ghana. Camelids have also been suspected as its intermediate host.

original: For clarity, the current knowledge on animal origins of known HCoVs is summarized in Figure ​1 and Table 2.
simplification: The current knowledge on animal origins of known HCoVs is summarized in Figure ​1 and Table 2.

original: Phylogenetic analysis has provided evidence for interspecies transmission events of HCoVs in the history.
simplification: Phylogenetic analysis has provided evidence for interspecies transmission of HCoVs in history.

original: When HCoV-OC43 crossed species to infect humans from domestic livestock around 1890, a pandemic of respiratory infection was recorded.
simplification: When HCoV-OC43 crossed from domestic livestock to human to infect humans in around 1890, a pandemic of respiratory infection was recorded.

original: The interspecies transmission history of HCoV-229E is less clear.
simplification: The history of interspecies transmission of HCoV-229E is less clear.

original: Bat alpha-CoVs closely related to HCoV-229E have been found.
simplification: Bat alpha-CoVs closely related to HCoV-229E have been found.

original: Between them there is an alpaca alpha-CoV.
simplification: Between them, there is an alpaca alpha-CoV.

original: Several lines of evidence support the transmission of virus from bats to humans directly.
simplification: Several pieces of evidence support the transmission of virus from bats to humans directly.

original: First, humans but not alpacas might have contact with bats in a shared ecological niche.
simplification: First, humans might have contact with bats in a shared ecological niche.

original: Instead, humans have close contact with alpacas.
simplification: Instead, humans have close contact with alpacas.

original: Second, HCoV-229E-related bat alpha-CoVs are diverse and non-pathogenic in bats, whereas alpaca alpha-CoV caused an outbreak of respiratory disease in infected animals.
simplification: Second, HCoV-229E-related bat alpha-CoVs are diverse and non-pathogenic in bats. Alpaca alpha-CoV caused an outbreak of respiratory disease in infected animals.

original: Finally, alpaca alpha-CoV has not been found in feral animals.
simplification: Finally, alpaca alpha-CoV has not been found in wild animals.

original: Thus, the possibility cannot be excluded that alpacas obtain the HCoV-229E-related alpha-CoV from humans.
simplification: Therefore, the possibility that alpacas obtain the HCoV-229E-related alpha-CoV from humans can not be excluded.

original: In fact, bats are the direct source of human pathogenic viruses including rabies virus, Ebola virus, Nipah virus and Hendra virus.
