simplification: Bats are the direct source of human pathogenic viruses including rabies virus, Ebola virus, Nipah virus and Hendra virus.

original: It is therefore not too surprising that bats might transmit HCoV-229E to humans directly.
simplification: It is therefore not unlikely that bats might transmit HCoV-229E to humans directly.

original: Alternatively, whereas bat alpha-CoVs serve as the gene pool of HCoV-229E, alpacas and dromedary camels might serve as intermediate hosts that transmit viruses to humans, exactly as in the case of MERS-CoV.
simplification: Alternatively, whereas bat alpha-CoVs serve as the gene pool of HCoV-229E, alpacas and dromedary camels might serve as intermediate hosts that transmit viruses to humans. This is what happened in the case of MERS-CoV.

original: MERS-CoV serves as an excellent example of interspecies transmission from bats to dromedary camels and from dromedary camels to humans.
simplification: MERS-CoV serves as an excellent example of interspecies transmission from bats to dromedary camels and from dromedary camels to humans.

original: The evolutionary origin of MERS-CoV from bats is known at its initial identification and has also been strengthened by subsequent findings.
simplification: The evolutionary origin of MERS-CoV from bats is known at its initial identification and has also been strengthened by more recent findings.

original: It is obvious that bats provide a rich pool of virus species for interspecies exchange of genetic fragments and interspecies transmission.
simplification: Bats provide a rich pool of virus species for interspecies exchange of genetic material and interspecies transmission.

original: Longevity, densely packed colonies, close social interaction and strong ability to fly are all favourable conditions for bats to be an ideal 'virus spreader'.
simplification: Bats are an ideal 'virus spreader'; longevity, densely packed colonies, close social interaction and strong ability to fly are all favourable conditions

original: On the other hand, MERS-CoV has been introduced to dromedary camels for decades.
simplification: MERS-CoV has been introduced to dromedary camels for decades.

original: It is well adapted to these camels that have turned from an intermediate host to a stable and natural reservoir host.
simplification: These camels have turned from an intermediate host to a stable and natural reservoir host, as the virus is well adapted.

original: MERS-CoV causes very mild disease and maintains a relatively low mutation rate in these animals.
simplification: MERS-CoV causes very mild disease and has quite a low mutation rate in these animals.

original: Its sporadic transmission to humans is an accident and humans remain a dead-end host of MERS-CoV as its transmission cannot be sustained.
simplification: Its irregular transmission to humans is an accident and humans remain a dead-end host of MERS-CoV; its transmission cannot be sustained.

original: Particularly, pangolin beta-CoVs are highly pathogenic in pangolins.
simplification: Pangolin beta-CoVs are highly pathogenic in pangolins.

original: They might be a dead-end host for SARS-CoV-2-related beta-CoVs, similar to civets in the case of SARS-CoV.
simplification: They might be a dead-end host for SARS-CoV-2-related beta-CoVs. This is similar to civets in the case of SARS-CoV.

original: Several possibilities for interspecies transmission of SARS-CoV-2 from animals to humans have to be ruled in or ruled out in future studies.
simplification: Several possibilities for interspecies transmission of SARS-CoV-2 from animals to humans have to figured out in future studies.

original: First, bats could be the reservoir host of a SARS-CoV-2-related virus almost identical to SARS-CoV-2.
simplification: Bats could be the reservoir host of a SARS-CoV-2-related virus, which is almost identical to SARS-CoV-2.

original: Humans might share the ecological niche with bats through butchering or coal mining.
simplification: Humans might share the ecological niche with bats through butchering or coal mining.

original: Second, pangolins could be one of intermediate amplifying host to which a SARS-CoV-2-related virus had been newly introduced.
simplification: Pangolins could be one of intermediate amplifying host to which a SARS-CoV-2-related virus had been newly introduced.

original: Humans contract the virus through butchering and consumption of game meat.
simplification: Humans contract the virus through butchering and consumption of game meat.

original: It is possible that many mammals including domestic animals are susceptible to SARS-CoV-2.
simplification: It is possible that many mammals, including domestic animals, are susceptible to SARS-CoV-2.

original: A survey of domestic and wild animals for antibodies is warranted.
simplification: A survey of domestic and wild animals for antibodies is called for.

original: Third, as mentioned above, recombination and adaptation of SARS-CoV-2 might have occurred in a third species that has contact with both bats and pangolins.
simplification: Recombination and adaptation of SARS-CoV-2 might have occurred in a third species that has contact with both bats and pangolins.

original: The search for the animal origins of SARS-CoV-2 is still on.
simplification: The search for the animal origins of SARS-CoV-2 is still on.

original: Apart from different types of the animal hosts, three major factors on the viral side are also important in facilitating CoVs to cross species barriers.
simplification: Apart from different types of the animal hosts, three major factors on the viral side are also important in CoVs ability to cross species barriers.

original: First of all, their relatively high mutation rates in RNA replication.
simplification: First of all, their high mutation rates in RNA replication.

original: CoVs have a proof-reading exoribonuclease, deletion of which results in exceedingly high mutability and attenuation or even inviability.
simplification: CoVs have a proof-reading exoribonuclease. Deletion of this results in very high mutability and attenuation, or even inviability.

original: Interestingly, the nucleotide analogue Remdesivir is known to suppress CoV replication through inhibition of this exoribonuclease and the RNA-dependent RNA polymerase.
simplification: The nucleotide analogue Remdesivir is known to suppress CoV replication through inhibition of this exoribonuclease and the RNA-dependent RNA polymerase.

original: Remdesivir is one of most promising anti-SARS-CoV-2 agents to be tested in clinical trials.
simplification: Remdesivir is one of the most promising anti-SARS-CoV-2 agents to be tested in clinical trials.

original: Nevertheless, mutation rates of CoVs are about a million times higher than those of their hosts.
simplification: Mutation rates of CoVs are about a million times higher than those of their hosts.

original: In addition, mutation rate is often high when CoVs are not well adapted to the host.
simplification: Mutation rate is often high when CoVs are not well adapted to the host.

original: Compared to SARS-CoV with a high mutation rate, the mutation rate of SARS-CoV-2 is apparently lower, suggestive of a higher level of adaptation to humans.
simplification: Compared to SARS-CoV with a high mutation rate, the mutation rate of SARS-CoV-2 is apparently lower. This is suggestive of a higher level of adaptation to humans.

original: Presumably, it has already been adapted to another host close to humans.
simplification: It may have already been adapted to another host close to humans.

original: In addition to SARS-CoV-2, this also applies to MERS-CoV, which is well adapted to dromedary camels.
simplification: In addition to SARS-CoV-2, this also applies to MERS-CoV, which is well adapted to dromedary camels.

original: Theoretically, it is unlikely that genetic drift would render vaccines and antivirals against SARS-CoV-2 ineffective quickly.
simplification: It is unlikely that genetic drift would render vaccines and antivirals against SARS-CoV-2 ineffective quickly.

original: Second, the large RNA genome in CoVs exerts extra plasticity in genome modification for mutations and recombination, thereby increasing the probability for interspecies co-evolution, which is advantageous for the emergence of novel CoVs when the conditions become appropriate.
simplification: The large RNA genome in CoVs exerts extra plasticity in genome modification for mutations and recombination, therefore increasing the probability for interspecies co-evolution. This is advantageous for the emergence of novel CoVs, when the conditions become appropriate.

original: This is supported by the copious unique open reading frames and protein functions encoded towards the 3′ end of the genome.
simplification: This is supported by the large amount of unique open reading frames and protein functions encoded towards the 3′ end of the genome.

original: Third, CoVs randomly and frequently switch templates during RNA replication through a unique “copy-choice” mechanism.
simplification: CoVs randomly and frequently switch templates during RNA replication through a unique “copy-choice” mechanism.

original: In a host that serves as the mixing vessel, strand switching occurs frequently during CoV RNA transcription.
simplification: In a host that serves as the mixing vessel, strand switching often occurs during CoV RNA transcription.

original: Highly homologous full-length and subgenomic RNAs could recombine to generate new CoVs.
simplification: Highly similar full-length and subgenomic RNAs could recombine to generate new CoVs.

original: Phylogenetic evidence of natural recombination has been found in both HCoV-HKU1 and HCoV-OC43, as well as animal CoVs such as bat SL-CoV and batCoV-HKU9.
simplification: Phylogenetic evidence of natural recombination has been found in both HCoV-HKU1 and HCoV-OC43, as well as animal CoVs such as bat SL-CoV and batCoV-HKU9.

original: Virus-host interaction in relation to transmission
simplification: Virus-host interaction in relation to transmission

original: Besides three viral factors stated above, viral interaction with host receptor is another key factor influential on interspecies transmission.
simplification: Besides 3 viral factors, viral interaction with host receptor is another key factor influential on interspecies transmission.

original: Herein, recombination of SARS-CoV is taken as a typical example, which also showed evidence of positive selection during interspecies transmission events.
simplification: Recombination of SARS-CoV is taken as a typical example, which also showed evidence of positive selection during interspecies transmission events.

original: Based on the comparative analysis between isolates of human and civet SARS-CoVs, SARS-CoV is thought to undergo rapid adaptation in different hosts, particularly with mutations at the RBD of the S protein.
simplification: Based on the comparative analysis between isolates of human and civet SARS-CoVs, SARS-CoV is thought to undergo rapid adaptation in different hosts. This is particularly true with mutations at the RBD of the S protein.

original: Generally, the RBD in the S protein of a CoV interacts with the cellular receptor and is intensely selected by the host antibody response.
simplification: The RBD in the S protein of a CoV interacts with the cellular receptor and is selected by the host antibody response.

original: In SARS-CoV, the RBD is in the 318th to 510th amino acids on the S1 fragment, which binds to the human ACE2 as well as its coreceptors for viral entry.
simplification: In SARS-CoV, the RBD is in the 318th to 510th amino acids on the S1 fragment; which binds to the human ACE2, as well as its coreceptors, for viral entry.

original: The RBD of SARS-CoV is capable of recognizing the ACE2 receptors of various animals, including bat, civet, mouse and raccoon dog, allowing interspecies transmission of the virus.
simplification: The RBD of SARS-CoV is capable of recognizing the ACE2 receptors of various animals, allowing interspecies transmission of the virus.

original: In fact, only 6 amino acid residues were observed to be different from human and civet viral isolates in the RBD and 4 of them locate in the receptor-binding motif for interaction with the ACE2 receptor.
simplification: Only 6 amino acid residues were observed to be different from human and civet viral isolates in the RBD. 4 of the amino acid residues locate in the receptor-binding motif for interaction with the ACE2 receptor.

original: Civet SARS-CoV has K479N and S487T mutations in its RBD, which might increase the affinity of the interaction of spike protein with human ACE2 receptor.
simplification: Civet SARS-CoV has K479N and S487T mutations in its RBD, which might increase the affinity of the interaction of spike protein with human ACE2 receptor.

original: In other words, these two amino acid substitutions might be critical to viral adaption to humans.
simplification: These two amino acid substitutions might be critical to viral adaption to humans.

original: It is noteworthy that SARS-CoV-2 shares the same cellular receptor with SARS-CoV.
simplification: It is important that SARS-CoV-2 shares the same cellular receptor with SARS-CoV.

original: A 30% difference between SARS-CoV-2 and SARS-CoV in the S1 unit of the S protein implicates that the binding affinity of its S protein with human ACE2 might have altered.
simplification: A 30% difference between SARS-CoV-2 and SARS-CoV in the S1 unit of the S protein suggests that the binding affinity of its S protein with human ACE2 might have changed.

original: Indeed, a cryo-EM study indicates a 10- to 20-fold higher affinity of this binding than that between human ACE2 and SARS-CoV S protein.
simplification: A cryo-EM study indicates a 10- to 20-fold higher affinity of this binding than that between human ACE2 and SARS-CoV S protein.

original: It will also be of interest to determine whether any other coreceptor might be required for SARS-CoV-2 transmission.
simplification: It will also be of interest to find out whether any other coreceptor might be required for SARS-CoV-2 transmission.

original: Intriguingly, HCoV-NL63 also binds to ACE2 but with a different part of S.
simplification: HCoV-NL63 also binds to ACE2 but with a different part of S.

original: There exist many other HCoV receptors, such as aminopeptidase N for HCoV-229E, and 9-O-acetylated sialic acid for HCoV-OC43.
simplification: Many other HCoV receptors exist, such as aminopeptidase N for HCoV-229E, and 9-O-acetylated sialic acid for HCoV-OC43.

original: They might also account for successful adaptation of these CoVs in humans after interspecies transmission from their animal hosts.
simplification: They might also account for successful adaptation of these CoVs in humans after interspecies transmission from their animal hosts.

original: In addition to cellular receptors, the outcome of interspecies transmission of HCoVs is also governed by other host dependency and restriction factors.
simplification: In addition to cellular receptors, the outcome of interspecies transmission of HCoVs is also controlled by other host dependency and restriction factors.

original: The divergence of these host proteins between humans and natural reservoir hosts of HCoVs such as bats, dromedary camels and rodents might constitute a barrier to interspecies transmission.
simplification: The divergence of these host proteins between humans and natural reservoir hosts of HCoVs, such as bats dromedary camels and rodents, might be a barrier to interspecies transmission.

original: HCoVs have to usurp host dependency factors and subvert host restriction factors for a successful interspecies transmission.
simplification: HCoVs have to take over host dependency factors and subvert host restriction factors for a successful interspecies transmission.

original: In this regard, molecular determinants in this important area of virus-host interaction remain to be identified and characterized.
simplification: Molecular determinants in this important area of virus-host interaction remain to be identified and characterized.

original: An unbiased genome-wide screening of host dependency and restriction factors for SARS-CoV-2 using the state-of-the-art technology of CRISPR might be fruitful.
simplification: An unbiased genome-wide screening of host dependency and restriction factors for SARS-CoV-2, using the technology of CRISPR, might be fruitful.

original: Emergence of novel HCoVs: back to ground zero
simplification: Emergence of new HCoVs: back to ground zero

original: The diversity of bat CoVs provides ample opportunities for the emergence of novel HCoVs.
simplification: The diversity of bat CoVs provides plenty of opportunities for the emergence of novel HCoVs.

original: In this sense, bat CoVs serve as the gene pool of HCoVs.
simplification: In this sense, bat CoVs serve as the gene pool of HCoVs.

original: In addition, rapid mutation and genetic recombination also drive HCoV evolution and serve as two important steps in this process.
simplification: Rapid mutation and genetic recombination also drive HCoV evolution and serve as two important steps in this process.

original: For example, the acquisition or loss of novel protein-coding genes has the potential to drastically modify viral phenotypes.
simplification: The acquisition or loss of novel protein-coding genes has the potential to significantly change viral phenotypes.

original: Among SARS-CoV accessory proteins, ORF8 has been thought to be important in adaptation to humans, as SARS-CoV-related bat viruses were isolated but found to encode divergent ORF8 proteins.
simplification: Among SARS-CoV accessory proteins, ORF8 has been thought to be important in adaptation to humans. SARS-CoV-related bat viruses were isolated but found to encode divergent ORF8 proteins.

original: A 29-nucleotide deletion characteristic of SARS-CoVs has been found in strains isolated at the beginning of the human epidemic.
simplification: A 29-nucleotide deletion characteristic of SARS-CoVs has been found in strains isolated at the start of the human epidemic.

original: This deletion splits ORF8 into ORF8a and ORF8b and is thought to be an adaptive mutation that promotes the switch of hosts.
simplification: This deletion splits ORF8 into ORF8a and ORF8b; it is thought to be an adaptive mutation that promotes the switch of hosts.

original: Besides, SARS-CoV has a possible recombination history with lineages of alpha- and gamma-CoVs, where a large number of smaller recombinant regions were identified in the RNA-dependent RNA polymerase.
simplification: SARS-CoV has a possible recombination history with lineages of alpha- and gamma-CoVs, where a large number of smaller recombinant regions were identified in the RNA-dependent RNA polymerase.

original: Recombination locations were also identified in the nsp9, most of nsp10, and parts of nsp14.
simplification: Recombination locations were also identified in the nsp9, most of nsp10, and parts of nsp14.

original: Likewise, it has been shown that the epidemic MERS-CoV experienced recombination events between different lineages, which occurred in dromedary camels in Saudi Arabia.
simplification: Likewise, it has been shown that the epidemic MERS-CoV experienced recombination events between different lineages. This occurred in dromedary camels in Saudi Arabia.

original: Besides SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV, recombination events have also been observed in other HCoVs, in which the HCoVs recombine with other animal CoVs in their non-structural genes.
simplification: Besides SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV, recombination events have also been observed in other HCoVs; in which the HCoVs recombine with other animal CoVs in their non-structural genes.

original: It should also be cautioned that artificial selection can contribute to unintended changes in viral genomes, most likely resulting from relieving viruses from selection pressures exerted, such as by the host immune system.
simplification: Artificial selection can contribute to unintended changes in viral genomes, most likely resulting from relieving viruses from selection pressures exerted, such as by the host immune system.

original: An example of these effects is the loss of a full-length ORF4 in the HCoV-229E prototype strain, owing to a two-nucleotide deletion.
simplification: An example of these effects is the loss of a full-length ORF4 in the HCoV-229E prototype strain, owing to a two-nucleotide deletion.

original: While intact ORF4 could be observed in bat and camel viruses related to HCoV-229E, the alpaca alpha-CoV displays a single nucleotide insertion, resulting in a frameshift.
simplification: While intact ORF4 could be observed in bat and camel viruses related to HCoV-229E, the alpaca alpha-CoV displays a single nucleotide insertion, therefore resulting in a frameshift.

original: Last but not least, the evolution of novel HCoVs is also driven by the selection pressure in their reservoir hosts.
simplification: The evolution of novel HCoVs is also driven by the selection pressure in their reservoir hosts.

original: Asymptomatic or only mild symptoms were detected when bats were infected with CoVs, indicating the mutual adaptation between CoVs and bats.
simplification: Asymptomatic or only mild symptoms were detected when bats were infected with CoVs. This indicates the mutual adaptation between CoVs and bats.

original: It appeared that bats are well adapted to CoVs anatomically and physiologically.
simplification: It appeared that bats are well adapted to CoVs, both anatomically and physiologically.

original: For example, defects in the activation of pro-inflammatory response in bats efficiently reduce the pathology triggered by CoVs.
simplification: Defects in the activation of the pro-inflammatory response in bats efficiently reduces the illness triggered by CoVs.

original: Besides, the natural killer cell activity in bats is suppressed due to upregulation of inhibitory natural killer cell receptor NKG2/CD94 and low expression level of major histocompatibility complex class I molecules.
simplification: The natural killer cell activity in bats is suppressed due to upregulation of inhibitory natural killer cell receptor NKG2/CD94, and low expression level of major histocompatibility complex class I molecules.

original: Moreover, the high level of reactive oxygen species (ROS) generated from high metabolic activity of bats could both suppress CoV replication and affects proofreading by exoribonuclease, thus providing the selection pressure for the generation of virus strains highly pathogenic when introduced into a new host.
simplification: The high level of reactive oxygen species (ROS) generated from high metabolic activity of bats could both suppress CoV replication and affects proofreading by exoribonuclease. Therefoe, this provides the selection pressure for the generation of virus strains highly pathogenic when introduced into a new host.

original: More pathogenic CoV strains might also evolve by recombination, leading to the acquisition of novel proteins or protein features for host adaptation.
simplification: More pathogenic CoV strains might also evolve by recombination, leading to the acquisition of novel proteins or protein features for host adaptation.

original: Thus, it is not by chance that three novel HCoVs have emerged in the past two decades.
simplification: Therefore, it is not by chance that 3 new HCoVs have emerged in the past two decades.

original: CoVs are non-pathogenic or cause mild symptoms in their reservoir hosts such as bats and camels.
simplification: CoVs are non-pathogenic or cause mild symptoms in their reservoir hosts, such as bats and camels.

original: They replicate robustly without eliciting a strong host immune response.
simplification: They replicate robustly without triggering a strong host immune response.

original: Herein lie the secrets of why asymptomatic carriers are seen and what causes the severe cases in human infection.
simplification: Herein are the secrets of why asymptomatic carriers are seen, and what causes the severe cases in human infection.

original: The severe symptoms are mainly due to the hyperactivation of immune response and the cytokine storm wherein the stronger the immune response, the more severe the lung damage.
simplification: The severe symptoms are mainly due to the hyperactivation of immune response and the cytokine storm. The stronger the immune response, the more severe the lung damage.

original: In contrast, in asymptomatic carriers, the immune response has been de-coupled from CoV replication.
simplification: In asymptomatic carriers, the immune response has been de-coupled from CoV replication.

original: The same strategy of delinking the immune response might have beneficial effects in anti-SARS-CoV-2 therapy.
simplification: The same method of delinking the immune response might have beneficial effects in anti-SARS-CoV-2 therapy.

original: The interferon response is particularly strong in bats.
simplification: The anti-viral response is particularly strong in bats.

original: Thus, administration of type I interferon at least in the early phase of SARS-CoV-2 infection in humans should be beneficial.
simplification: Administration of type I interferon  in the early phase of SARS-CoV-2 infection in humans should be beneficial.

original: In addition, NLRP3 inflammasome activation in bats is defective.
simplification: In addition, NLRP3 inflammasome activation in bats is defective.

original: By this reasoning, inhibition of NLRP3 inflammasome with MCC950 might be useful in the treatment of COVID-19.
simplification: Inhibition of NLRP3 inflammasome with MCC950 might be useful in the treatment of COVID-19.

original: The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 follows the general theme by which SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV arose.
simplification: The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 follows the general way SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV arose.

original: Whereas a bat beta-CoV sharing 95% nucleotide homology with SARS-CoV has been found, there also exists a bat-CoV sharing 96% nucleotide homology with SARS-CoV-2.
simplification: A bat beta-CoV sharing 95% nucleotide similarity with SARS-CoV has been found. There is also a bat-CoV sharing 96% nucleotide similarity with SARS-CoV-2.

original: Whereas civets and other animals in the markets have been found to harbour viruses identical to SARS-CoV, immediate intermediate hosts for SARS-CoV-2 have not been identified.
simplification: Whereas civets and other animals in the markets have been found to carry viruses identical to SARS-CoV, immediate intermediate hosts for SARS-CoV-2 have not been identified.

original: Pangolin beta-CoVs strikingly homologous to SARS-CoV-2 have been found, indicating that pangolins might serve as one of intermediate hosts or pangolin beta-CoVs could contribute gene fragments to the final version of SARS-CoV-2.
simplification: Pangolin beta-CoVs very similar to SARS-CoV-2 have been found, suggesting that pangolins might serve as one of intermediate hosts. Pangolin beta-CoVs could contribute gene pieces to the final version of SARS-CoV-2.

original: Although questions remain, there is no evidence that SARS-CoV-2 is man-made either deliberately or accidentally.
simplification: Although questions remain, there is no evidence that SARS-CoV-2 is man-made.

original: CoVs have returned to the limelight due to the recent outbreak of SARS-CoV-2.
simplification: CoVs have returned to the spotlight, due to the recent outbreak of SARS-CoV-2.

original: The study of CoVs in bats and other animals has drastically changed our perception of the importance of zoonotic origins and animal reservoirs of HCoVs in human transmission.
simplification: The study of CoVs in bats and other animals has changed our perception of the importance of zoonotic origins and animal reservoirs of HCoVs in human transmission.

original: Pervasive evidence has shown that SARS-CoV, MERS-CoV and SARS-CoV-2 have a bat origin and are transmitted to humans via intermediate hosts.
simplification: Evidence has shown that SARS-CoV, MERS-CoV and SARS-CoV-2 have a bat origin and are transmitted to humans via intermediate hosts.

original: Given that SARS-CoV infection originates from the contact between humans and civets in the markets, closing wet markets and killing civets therein could have effectively ended the SARS epidemic.
simplification: SARS-CoV infection comes from the contact between humans and civets in the markets, so closing wet markets and killing civets could have ended the SARS epidemic.

original: By the same reasoning, pangolins should be removed from wet markets to prevent zoonotic transmission, in view of the discovery of multiple lineages of pangolin beta-CoVs closely related to SARS-CoV-2.
simplification: Pangolins should be removed from wet markets to prevent transmission between animals, due to the discovery of multiple lineages of pangolin beta-CoVs closely related to SARS-CoV-2.

original: However, whether and how SARS-CoV-2 is transmitted to humans through pangolins and other mammals remain to be clarified in future investigations.
simplification: Whether SARS-CoV-2 is transmitted to humans through pangolins and other mammals remains to be found out in investigations.

original: On the other hand, MERS-CoV has existed in dromedary camels for a long time.
simplification: MERS-CoV has existed in dromedary camels for a long time.

original: These camels serve as an important tool for transportation as well as a main source of meat, milk, leather and wool products for the local people.
simplification: These camels serve as an important tool for transportation, as well as a main source of meat, milk, leather and wool products for the local people.

original: They are widely distributed across the Middle East and Africa.
simplification: They are widely found across the Middle East and Africa.

original: It is therefore impossible to sacrifice all camels for the control of MERS, as what was done in wild animal markets in China to prevent the spreading of SARS-CoV and SARS-CoV-2.
simplification: It is impossible to sacrifice all camels for the control of MERS, as what was done in wild animal markets in China to prevent the spreading of SARS-CoV and SARS-CoV-2.

original: To stop the recurrent outbreaks of MERS, a comprehensive approach should be taken to develop effective vaccines against MERS-CoV for camels, in combination with other infection control measures.
simplification: To stop the recurrent outbreaks of MERS, an overall approach should be taken to develop effective vaccines against MERS-CoV for camels. This should be combined with other infection control measures.

original: As we are not able to eliminate these viruses, new genotypes might emerge to cause outbreaks.
simplification: As we are not able to eliminate these viruses, new variants might emerge to cause outbreaks.

original: A variety of zoonotic CoVs are circulating in the wild.
simplification: A variety of animal CoVs are circulating in the wild.

original: Particularly, bat CoVs with zoonotic potential are so diverse.
simplification: Bat CoVs with zoonotic potential are so diverse.

original: There are plenty of opportunities that these zoonotic CoVs evolve and recombine, resulting in the emergence of new CoVs that are more transmissible and/or deadly in humans in future.
simplification: There are plenty of opportunities that these animal CoVs evolve and recombine, resulting in the emergence of new CoVs that are more transmissible and/or deadly in humans in future.

original: The culture of eating wild animals in some places of China should be abandoned to reduce unnecessary contact between humans and animals.
simplification: The culture of eating wild animals in some places of China should be stopped to reduce unnecessary contact between humans and animals.

original: With the ordeals of SARS, MERS and COVID-19, a better preparedness and response plan should be in place.
simplification: followng SARS, MERS and COVID-19, a better preparedness and response plan should be in place.

original: In fact, many viruses have existed in the planet for a very long time.
simplification: Many viruses have existed in the planet for a very long time.

original: They stay in their own natural reservoirs until there is a chance for spillover.
simplification: They stay in their own natural reservoirs until there is a chance to leave

original: Although bats have many features that favours the spreading of viruses, the chance for humans to be in contact with bats and other wildlife species can be minimized if people are educated to stay away from them.
simplification: Although bats have many features that helps the spreading of viruses, the chance for humans to be in contact with bats and other wildlife species can be reduced if people are educated to stay away from them.

original: Continuous surveillance in mammals is necessary for better understanding of the ecology of CoVs and their natural hosts, which will prove useful in preventing animal-to-human transmission and future outbreaks.
simplification: Continuous surveillance in mammals is necessary for better understanding of the ecology of CoVs and their natural hosts. This will prove useful in preventing animal-to-human transmission and future outbreaks.

original: To conclude, the most effective way to prevent viral zoonosis is for humans to stay away from the ecological niches of the natural reservoirs of the zoonotic viruses.
simplification: The most effective way to prevent viral zoonosis is for humans to stay away from the ecological niches of the natural reservoirs of the zoonotic viruses.

original: Several pieces in the puzzle of the zoonotic origin of SARS-CoV-2 are still missing.
simplification: Several pieces in the puzzle of the zoonotic origin of SARS-CoV-2 are still missing.

original: First, if bats transmit an ancestral virus of SARS-CoV-2 to pangolins, it will be of interest to see under what circumstances bats and pangolins could share the same ecological niche.
simplification: If bats transmit a virus related to SARS-CoV-2 to pangolins, it will be of interest to see under what circumstances bats and pangolins could share the same ecological niche.

original: Second, if bats play a more direct role in human transmission, how humans get into contact with bats should be determined.
simplification: If bats play a more direct role in human transmission, how humans get into contact with bats should be determined.

original: Third, if a third mammal acts as the true intermediate host, how it interacts with the different species including humans, bats and pangolins has to be clarified.
simplification: If a third mammal acts as the true intermediate host, how it interacts with the different species including humans, bats and pangolins has to be clarified.

original: Finally, since many mammals including domestic animals might be susceptible to SARS-CoV-2, both surveillance and experimental infection should be conducted.
simplification: Since many mammals might be susceptible to SARS-CoV-2, both surveillance and experimental infection should be conducted.

original: Should it be a bat, a pangolin or another mammal, it is expected that SARS-CoV-2 or its parental viruses that are almost identical will be identified in its natural hosts in future.
simplification: it is expected that SARS-CoV-2 or its parental viruses that are almost identical will be identified in its natural hosts in future.

original: Continued investigations in this area will elucidate the evolutionary pathway of SARS-CoV-2 in animals, with important implications in the prevention and control of COVID-19 in humans.
simplification: Continued investigations in this area will reveal the evolutionary pathway of SARS-CoV-2 in animals, with important implications in the prevention and control of COVID-19 in humans.

original: Several anticoagulants are being tested in Italy.
simplification: Several anticoagulants are being tested in Italy.

original: Low-molecular-weight heparin is being widely used to treat patients, prompting the Italian Medicines Agency to publish guidelines on its use.
simplification: Low-molecular-weight heparin is being widely used to treat patients. This has prompted the Italian Medicines Agency to publish guidelines on its use.

original: A multicenter study on 300 patients researching the use of enoxaparin sodium at prophylaxis and therapeutic dosages was announced in Italy on April 14.
simplification: A study on 300 patients researching the use of enoxaparin sodium at treatment and therapeutic dosages was announced in Italy on April 14.

original: Since SARS-CoV-2 is a virus, considerable scientific attention has been focused on repurposing approved anti-viral drugs that were developed for prior outbreaks such as MERS, SARS, and West Nile virus.
simplification: Since SARS-CoV-2 is a virus, a lot of scientific attention has been focused on repurposing approved anti-viral drugs that were developed for prior outbreaks. These outbreaks include MERS, SARS, and West Nile virus.

original: Ribavirin: ribavirin was recommended for COVID-19 treatment according to Chinese 7th edition guidelines
simplification: Ribavirin: ribavirin was recommended for COVID-19 treatment according to Chinese 7th edition guidelines

original: Umifenovir: umifenovir was recommended for COVID-19 treatment according to Chinese 7th edition guidelines
simplification: Umifenovir: umifenovir was recommended for COVID-19 treatment according to Chinese 7th edition guidelines

original: Some antibiotics that have been identified as potentially repurposable as COVID-19 treatments:
simplification: Some antibiotics that have been identified as potentially repurposable as COVID-19 treatments:

original: Tocilizumab (Anti-IL-6 receptor): Approved by China.
simplification: Tocilizumab (Anti-IL-6 receptor): Approved by China.

original: Also trials in Italy and China. and see Tocilizumab#COVID-19.
simplification: Also trials in Italy and China. and see Tocilizumab

original: b'Angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) is an enzyme attached to the outer surface (cell membranes) of cells in the lungs, arteries, heart, kidney, and intestines.
simplification: b'Angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) is an enzyme attached to the outer surface (cell membranes) of cells in organs

original: ACE2 counters the activity of the related angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) by reducing the amount of angiotensin-II and increasing Ang(1-7) making it a promising drug target for treating cardiovascular diseases.ACE2 also serves as the entry point into cells for some coronaviruses.
simplification: ACE2 counters the activity of the related angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) by reducing angiotensin-II and increasing Ang(1-7). This makes it a promising drug target for treating cardiovascular diseases. ACE2 also serves as the entry point into cells for some coronaviruses.

original: The human version of the enzyme is often referred to as hACE2.
simplification: The human version of this enzyme is referred to as hACE2

original: Angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 is a zinc containing metalloenzyme located on the surface of endothelial and other cells.
simplification: Angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 is located on the surface of some cells, including endothelial cells

original: ACE2 protein contains an N-terminal peptidase M2 domain and a C-terminal collectrin renal amino acid transporter domain.
simplification: ACE2 protein contains an N-terminal peptidase M2 domain, and a C-terminal collectrin renal amino acid transporter domain.

original: ACE2 is a single-pass type I membrane protein, with its enzymatically active domain exposed on the surface of cells in lungs and other tissues.
simplification: ACE2 is a membrane protein, with its enzymatically active domain found on the surface of cells in lungs and other tissues.

original: The extracellular domain of ACE2 is cleaved from the transmembrane domain by another enzyme known as sheddase, and the resulting soluble protein is released into the blood stream and ultimately excreted into urine.
simplification: The extracellular domain of ACE2 is cleaved from the transmembrane domain by another enzyme known as sheddase. The resulting soluble protein is released into the blood stream and eventually passed into urine.

original: ACE2 is present in most organs: ACE2 is attached to the cell membrane of mainly lung type II alveolar cells, enterocytes of the small intestine, arterial and venous endothelial cells and arterial smooth muscle cells in most organs.
simplification: ACE2 is present in most organs. It is attached to the membrane of cells in most organs.

original: ACE2 mRNA expression is also found in the cerebral cortex, striatum, hypothalamus, and brainstem.
simplification: ACE2 mRNA expression is also found in several parts of the brain

original: The primary function of ACE2 is to act as a counter balance to ACE.
simplification: The main function of ACE2 is to act as a counter balance to ACE.

original: ACE cleaves angiotensin I hormone into the vasoconstricting  angiotensin II.
simplification: ACE splits angiotensin I hormone into the hormone angiotensin II.

original: ACE2 in turn cleaves the carboxyl-terminal amino acid phenylalanine from angiotensin II (Asp-Arg-Val-Tyr-Ile-His-Pro-Phe) and hydrolyses it into the vasodilator angiotensin (1-7), (H-Asp-Arg-Val-Tyr-Ile-His-Pro-OH).
simplification: ACE2 cleaves phenylalanine from angiotensin II and hydrolyses it into angiotensin.

original: ACE2 can also cleave a number of other peptides including [des-Arg9]-bradykinin, apelin, neurotensin, dynorphin A, and ghrelin.
simplification: ACE2 can also cleave a number of other peptides.

original: ACE2 also regulates the membrane trafficking of the neutral amino acid transporter SLC6A19 and has been implicated in Hartnup's disease.
simplification: ACE2 also regulates the membrane trafficking of the neutral amino acid transporter SLC6A19. ACE2 has also been implicated in Hartnup's disease.

original: As a transmembrane protein, ACE2 serves as the main entry point into cells for some coronaviruses, including HCoV-NL63; SARS-CoV (the virus that causes SARS); and SARS-CoV-2 (the virus that causes COVID-19).
simplification: ACE2 is a protein that serves as an entry point into cells for some coronaviruses. These coronaviruses include HCoV-NL63; SARS-CoV (the virus that causes SARS); and SARS-CoV-2 (the virus that causes COVID-19).

original: More specifically, the binding of the spike S1 protein of SARS-CoV and SARS-CoV2 to the enzymatic domain of ACE2 on the surface of cells results in endocytosis and translocation of both the virus and the enzyme into endosomes located within cells.
simplification: The binding of the spike S1 protein of SARS-CoV and SARS-CoV2 to ACE2 on the surface of cells results in endocytosis and translocation of both the virus and the enzyme into endosomes, located within cells.

original: This entry process also requires priming of the S protein by the host serine protease TMPRSS2, the inhibition of which is under current investigation as a potential therapeutic.This has led some to hypothesize that decreasing the levels of ACE2, in cells, might help in fighting the infection.
simplification: This entry process also requires priming of the S protein by the host serine protease TMPRSS2, which has led some to hypothesise that decreasing the levels of ACE2 in cells might help to fight infection.

original: b'A COVID-19 vaccine is a hypothetical vaccine against coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19).
simplification: b'A COVID-19 vaccine is an imagined vaccine against coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19).

original: Although no vaccine has completed clinical trials, there are multiple attempts in progress to develop such a vaccine.
simplification: Although no vaccine has completed clinical trials, there are multiple attempts to develop such a vaccine.

original: In late February 2020, the World Health Organization (WHO) said it did not expect a vaccine against SARS-CoV-2, the causative virus, to become available in less than 18 months.
simplification: In late February 2020, the World Health Organization (WHO) said it did not expect a vaccine against SARS-CoV-2 to become available in less than 18 months.

original: Five vaccine candidates were in Phase I safety studies in April.
simplification: Five vaccine candidates were in Phase I safety studies in April.

original: COVID-19 was identified in December 2019.
simplification: COVID-19 was identified in December 2019.

original: A major outbreak spread around the world in 2020, leading to considerable investment and research activity to develop a vaccine.
simplification: A major outbreak spread around the world in 2020. This lead to considerable investment and research to develop a vaccine.

original: Many organizations are using published genomes to develop possible vaccines against SARS-CoV-2.
simplification: Many organizations are using published genomes to develop possible vaccines against SARS-CoV-2.

original: Stated in April, imperatives of the CEPI initiative for vaccine development are speed, manufacturing capacity, deployment at scale, and global access.
simplification: Imperatives of the CEPI initiative for vaccine development are speed, manufacturing capacity, deployment at scale, and global access.

original: In April, CEPI scientists reported that 10 different technology platforms were under research and development during early 2020 to create an effective vaccine against COVID-19.
simplification: In April, CEPI scientists reported that 10 different technology platforms were under research and development during early 2020 to create an effective vaccine against COVID-19.

original: Major platform targets advanced into Phase I safety studies include:
simplification: Platform targets turned into Phase I safety studies include:

original: As reported by CEPI scientists in April, 115 total vaccine candidates are in early stages of development, with 78 confirmed as active projects (79, according to the Milken Institute), and 37 others announced, but with little public information available (presumed to be in planning or being designed).
simplification: As reported by CEPI scientists in April, 115 total vaccine candidates are in early stages of development. 78 are confirmed as active projects (79, according to the Milken Institute), and 37 others announced, but with little public information available (presumed to be in planning or being designed).

original: A Phase I-II trial conducts preliminary safety and immunogenicity testing, is typically randomized, placebo-controlled, and at multiple sites, while determining more precise, effective doses.
simplification: A Phase I-II trial conducts preliminary safety and immunogenicity testing. They are typically randomized, placebo-controlled, and at multiple sites. These trials determine more precise, effective doses.

original: Phase III trials typically involve more participants, including a control group, and test effectiveness of the vaccine to prevent the disease, while monitoring for adverse effects at the optimal dose.
simplification: Phase III trials typically involve more participants, including a control group, and test effectiveness of the vaccine to prevent the disease. They also monitor for adverse effects at the optimal dose

original: Of 79 vaccine candidates in active development (confirmed as of early April 2020), 74 were not yet in human evaluation (still in "preclinical" research).
simplification: Of 79 vaccine candidates in active development (confirmed as of early April 2020), 74 were not yet in human evaluation (still in "preclinical" research).

original: Around 24 January 2020 in Australia, the University of Queensland announced that it is investigating the potential of a molecular clamp vaccine that would genetically modify viral proteins in order to stimulate an immune reaction.
simplification: In January 2020 the University of Queensland, Australia, announced that it is investigating the potential of a molecular clamp vaccine. This vaccine would genetically modify viral proteins in order to stimulate an immune reaction.

original: Around 24 January 2020 in Canada, the International Vaccine Centre (VIDO-InterVac) at the University of Saskatchewan announced the commencement of work on a vaccine, aiming to start human testing in 2021.
simplification: In January 2020 in Canada, the International Vaccine Centre (VIDO-InterVac) announced that work on a vaccine was starting. They are aiming to start human testing in 2021

original: Vaccine development projects were announced at the Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention on 26 January 2020, and the University of Hong Kong on 28 January.
simplification: Vaccine development projects were announced at the Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention on 26 January 2020, and the University of Hong Kong on 28 January.

original: Around 29 January 2020, Janssen Pharmaceutical Companies, led by Hanneke Schuitemaker, announced that it had begun work on developing a vaccine.
simplification: In late January 2020, Janssen Pharmaceutical Companies announced that it had begun work on developing a vaccine.

original: Janssen is co-developing an oral vaccine with its biotechnology partner, Vaxart.
simplification: Janssen is co-developing an oral vaccine with its biotechnology partner, Vaxart.

original: On 18 March 2020, Emergent BioSolutions announced a manufacturing partnership with Vaxart to develop the vaccine.
simplification: On 18 March 2020, Emergent BioSolutions announced a partnership with Vaxart to develop the vaccine.

original: On 8 February 2020, the laboratory OncoGen in Romania published a paper on the design of a vaccine with similar technology to the one used for cancer neoantigen vaccination therapy.
simplification: On 8 February 2020, the laboratory OncoGen in Romania published a paper on the design of a vaccine with similar technology to the one used for cancer neoantigen vaccination therapy.

original: On 25 March the head of the research institute announced that they had finalized the synthesis of the vaccine and were beginning the tests.
simplification: The esearch institute announced that they had finalized the synthesis of the vaccine and were beginning the tests on the 25th March.

original: On 27 February 2020, a Generex subsidiary company, NuGenerex Immuno-Oncology, announced they were beginning a vaccine project to create an Ii-Key peptide vaccine against COVID-19.
simplification: On 27 February 2020, NuGenerex Immuno-Oncology announced they were beginning a vaccine project to create an Ii-Key peptide vaccine against COVID-19.

original: They wanted to produce a vaccine candidate that could be tested in humans "within 90 days."
simplification: They wanted to produce a potential vaccine that could be tested in humans "within 90 days."

original: On 5 March 2020, Washington University in St. Louis announced its projects to develop a vaccine.
simplification: On 5 March 2020, Washington University announced its projects to develop a vaccine.

original: On 5 March 2020, the United States Army Medical Research and Materiel Command at Fort Detrick and the Walter Reed Army Institute of Research in Silver Spring, both in western Maryland, announced they were working on a vaccine.
simplification: On 5 March 2020, the United States Army Medical Research and Materiel Command and the Walter Reed Army Institute of Research announced they were working on a vaccine.

original: Around 10 March 2020, Emergent Biosolutions announced that it had teamed with Novavax Inc.
simplification: In March 2020, Emergent Biosolutions announced that it had teamed with Novavax Inc.

original: in the development and manufacture of a vaccine.
simplification: in the development and manufacture of a vaccine.

original: The partners further announced plans for preclinical testing and a Phase I clinical trial by July 2020.
simplification: The partners announced plans for preclinical testing and a Phase I clinical trial by July 2020.

original: On 12 March 2020, India's Health Ministry announced they are working with 11 isolates, and that even on a fast track it would take at least around one-and-a-half to two years to develop a vaccine.
simplification: On 12 March 2020, India's Health Ministry announced they are working with 11 isolates. Also, they announced that even on a fast track it would take at least around 1 - 2.5 to years to develop a vaccine.

original: On 12 March 2020, Medicago, a biotechnology company in Quebec City, Quebec, reported development of a coronavirus-like particle under partial funding from the Canadian Institutes for Health Research.
simplification: On 12 March 2020, Medicago reported development of a coronavirus-like particle under partial funding from the Canadian Institutes for Health Research.

original: The vaccine candidate is in laboratory research, with human testing planned for July or August 2020.
simplification: The vaccine candidate is in laboratory research. Human testing is planned for July or August 2020.

original: Earlier that week, The Guardian reported that the US President Donald Trump had offered CureVac "'large sums of money' for exclusive access to a Covid-19 vaccine", against which the German government protested.
simplification: The Guardian reported that the US President Donald Trump had offered CureVac "'large sums of money' for exclusive access to a Covid-19 vaccine". The German government have protested this.

original: On 17 March 2020, American pharmaceutical company Pfizer announced a partnership with German company BioNTech to jointly develop a mRNA-based vaccine.
simplification: American pharmaceutical company Pfizer announced a partnership with German company BioNTech to jointly develop a mRNA-based vaccine.

original: mRNA-based vaccine candidate BNT162, currently in pre-clinical testing with clinical trials expected to begin in April 2020.
simplification: mRNA-based vaccine candidate BNT162 is currently in pre-clinical testing. Clinical trials are expected to begin in April 2020.

original: In Italy on 17 March 2020, Takis Biotech, an Italian biotech company announced they will have pre-clinical testing results in April 2020 and their final vaccine candidate could begin human testing by fall.
simplification: In Italy on 17 March 2020, Takis Biotech announced they will have pre-clinical testing results in April 2020. Their final vaccine candidate could begin human testing by fall.

original: In France on 19 March 2020, the Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations (CEPI) announced a US$4.9 million investment in a COVID-19 vaccine research consortium involving the Institut Pasteur, Themis Bioscience (Vienna, Austria), and the University of Pittsburgh, bringing CEPI's total investment in COVID-19 vaccine development to US$29 million.
simplification: In France on 19 March 2020, the Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations (CEPI) announced a US$4.9 million investment in a COVID-19 vaccine research consortium involving the Institut Pasteur, Themis Bioscience (Vienna, Austria), and the University of Pittsburgh. This brings CEPI's total investment in COVID-19 vaccine development to US$29 million.

original: CEPI's other investment partners for COVID-19 vaccine development are Moderna, Curevac, Inovio, Novavax, the University of Hong Kong, the University of Oxford, and the University of Queensland.
simplification: CEPI's other investment partners for COVID-19 vaccine development are Moderna, Curevac, Inovio, Novavax, the University of Hong Kong, the University of Oxford, and the University of Queensland.

original: On 20 March 2020, Russian health officials announced that scientists have begun animal testing of six different vaccine candidates.
simplification: Russian health officials announced that scientists have begun animal testing of six different vaccine candidates. This announcement came on 20 March 2020.

original: Imperial College London researchers announced on 20 March 2020 that they are developing a self-amplifying RNA vaccine for COVID-19.
simplification: Imperial College London researchers announced on 20 March 2020 that they are developing a self-amplifying RNA vaccine for COVID-19.

original: The vaccine candidate was developed within 14 days of receiving the sequence from China.
simplification: The vaccine candidate was developed within 14 days of receiving the sequence from China.

original: In late March, the Canadian government announced C$275 million in funding for 96 research projects on medical countermeasures against COVID-19, including numerous vaccine candidates at Canadian companies and universities, such as the Medicago and University of Saskatchewan initiatives.
simplification: In late March, the Canadian government announced C$275 million in funding for 96 research projects on medical countermeasures against COVID-19. This includes numerous vaccine candidates at Canadian companies and universities, such as the Medicago and University of Saskatchewan initiatives.

original: Around the same time, the Canadian government announced C$192 million specifically for developing a COVID-19 vaccine, with plans to establish a national "vaccine bank" of several new vaccines that could be used if another coronavirus outbreak occurs.
simplification: The Canadian government announced C$192 million specifically for developing a COVID-19 vaccine. They also announced plans to establish a national "vaccine bank" of several new vaccines that could be used if another coronavirus outbreak occurs.

original: On 2 April 2020, researchers at the University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine reported on testing of PittCoVacc, a possible COVID-19 vaccine in mice, stating that "MNA delivered SARS-CoV-2 S1 subunit vaccines elicited potent antigen-specific antibody responses [in the mice] that were evident beginning 2 weeks after immunization."
simplification: On 2 April 2020, researchers at the University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine reported on testing of PittCoVacc, a possible COVID-19 vaccine in mice. The researchers stated that "MNA delivered SARS-CoV-2 S1 subunit vaccines produced potent antigen-specific antibody responses [in the mice] that were evident beginning 2 weeks after immunization."

original: In Canada on 16 April 2020, the University of Waterloo School of Pharmacy announced design of a DNA-based vaccine candidate as a possible nasal spray.
simplification: On 16 April 2020, the University of Waterloo School of Pharmacy announced design of a DNA-based vaccine candidate as a possible nasal spray.

original: Using bacteriophages, the DNA will be designed to replicate inside human bacteria to produce harmless virus-like particles, which may stimulate the immune system to produce antibodies against the SARS-CoV-2 virus.
simplification: Using bacteriophages, the DNA will be designed to replicate inside human bacteria to produce harmless virus-like particles. The virus-like particles may stimulate the immune system to produce antibodies against the SARS-CoV-2 virus.

original: In March 2020, the US government, industry, and three universities pooled resources to access supercomputers from IBM, combined with cloud computing resources from Hewlett Packard Enterprise, Amazon, Microsoft, and Google.
simplification: In March 2020, the US government, industry, and three universities pooled resources to access supercomputers from IBM. They combined these with cloud computing resources from Hewlett Packard Enterprise, Amazon, Microsoft, and Google.

original: Some vaccines have heterologous effects, also called non-specific effects.
simplification: Some vaccines have heterologous effects, also called non-specific effects.

original: That means they can have benefits beyond the disease they prevent.
simplification: That means they can have benefits beyond the disease they prevent.

original: A further randomized trial in Australia is seeking to enrol 4,170 healthcare workers.
simplification: Another randomized trial in Australia is seeking to enrol 4,170 healthcare workers.

original: It is possible vaccines in development will not be safe or effective.
simplification: It is possible vaccines in development will not be safe or effective.

original: Vaccines against SARS and MERS have been tested in non-human animal models.
simplification: Vaccines against SARS and MERS have been tested in animal models.

original: As of 2020, there is no cure or protective vaccine for SARS that has been shown to be both safe and effective in humans.
simplification: As of 2020, there is no cure or protective vaccine for SARS that has been shown to be both safe and effective in humans.

original: According to research papers published in 2005 and 2006, the identification and development of novel vaccines and medicines to treat SARS was a priority for governments and public health agencies around the world.There is also no proven vaccine against MERS.
simplification: According to research papers from 2005 and 2006, the identification and development of novel vaccines and medicines to treat SARS was a priority for governments and public health agencies around the world. There is also no proven vaccine against MERS.

original: As of 14 April 2020, the app was awaiting approval by the Google Play Store and Apple App Store.
simplification: As of 14 April 2020, the app was awaiting approval by the Google Play Store and Apple App Store.

original: On 12 April, the government stated that the contact tracing app was in an advanced stage of development, and would be available for deployment within weeks.A similar app is planned in Ireland, and in France ("StopCovid").
simplification: On 12 April, the government stated that the contact tracing app was far along in its development and would be available for use within weeks. A similar app is planned in Ireland, and one called "StopCovid" in France.

original: Both Australia and New Zealand are considering apps based on Singapore's TraceTogether app and BlueTrace protocol.Russia intends to introduce a geofencing app for patients diagnosed with COVID-19 living in Moscow, designed to ensure they do not leave home.
simplification: Australia and New Zealand are considering apps based on Singapore's TraceTogether app and BlueTrace protocol. Russia intends to introduce a geofencing app for patients diagnosed with COVID-19 living in Moscow, to make sure they do not leave home.

original: Ross Anderson, professor of security engineering at Cambridge University, listed a number of potential practical problems with app-based systems, including false positives and the potential lack of effectiveness if takeup of the app is limited to only a small fraction of the population.
simplification: Ross Anderson, professor of security engineering at Cambridge University, listed a number of potential practical problems with app-based systems.

original: Addressing concerns about the spread of misleading or harmful "coronavirus" apps, Apple set limits on which types of organizations could add coronavirus-related apps to its App Store, limiting them to only "official" or otherwise reputable organizations.
simplification: Addressing concerns about the spread of misleading or harmful "coronavirus" apps, Apple set limits on which types of organizations could add coronavirus-related apps to its App Store. These restriction limited them to only "official" or otherwise reputable organizations.

original: Google and Amazon have implemented similar restrictions.
simplification: Google and Amazon have put similar restrictions in place.

original: Privacy campaigners voiced their concern regarding the implications of mass surveillance using coronavirus apps, in particular about whether surveillance infrastructure created to deal with the coronavirus pandemic will be dismantled once the threat has passed.
simplification: Privacy campaigners voiced their concern regarding the implications of mass surveillance using coronavirus apps. The main concern was about whether the surveillance system made to deal with the pandemic would be taken down once the pandemic had passed.

original: Amnesty International and over 100 other organizations issued a statement calling for limits on this kind of surveillance.
simplification: Amnesty International and many other organizations have called for limits on this kind of surveillance.

original: The organisations declared eight conditions on governmental projects:
simplification: The organisations announced eight conditions on governmental projects:

original: surveillance would have to be "lawful, necessary and proportionate";
simplification: surveillance would have to be "lawful, necessary and proportionate";

original: extensions of monitoring and surveillance would have to have sunset clauses;
simplification: extensions of monitoring and surveillance would have to have sunset clauses;

original: the use of data would have to be limited to COVID-19 purposes;
simplification: data would have to be only used for COVID-19 purposes;

original: data security and anonymity would have to be protected and shown to be protected based on evidence;
simplification: data security and anonymity would have to be protected. It would have to be shown to be protected based on evidence;

original: digital surveillance would have to avoid exacerbating discrimination and marginalisation;
simplification: digital surveillance would have to avoid making discrimination and marginalisation worse;

original: any sharing of data with third parties would have to be defined in law;
simplification: any sharing of data with third parties would have to be defined in law;

original: there would have to be safeguards against abuse and the rights of citizens to respond to abuses;
simplification: there would have to be safeguards against abuse and the rights of citizens to respond to abuses;

original: meaningful participation by all "relevant stakeholders" would be required, including that of public health experts and marginalised groups.The German Chaos Computer Club (CCC) and Reporters Without Borders (Reporter ohne Grenzen) (RSF) also issued checklists.
simplification: meaningful participation by all "relevant stakeholders" would be required. This includes that of public health experts and marginalised groups. The German Chaos Computer Club (CCC) and Reporters Without Borders (Reporter ohne Grenzen) (RSF) also issued checklists.

original: The proposed Google/Apple plan intends to address the problem of persistent surveillance by removing the tracing mechanism from their device operating systems once it is no longer needed.
simplification: The proposed Google/Apple plan intends to address the problem of persistent surveillance by removing the tracing mechanism from their device operating systems once it is no longer needed.

original: Some countries used network-based location tracking instead of apps, eliminating both the need to download an app and the ability to avoid tracking.
simplification: Some countries used network-based location tracking instead of apps. This eliminated the need to download an app and the ability to avoid tracking.

original: In Israel, network-based tracking was approved.
simplification: Network-based tracking was approved in Israel.

original: Network-based solutions that have access to raw location data have significant potential privacy problems.
simplification: Network-based solutions that have access to raw location data have significant potential privacy problems.

original: However, not all systems with central servers need to have access to personal location data; a number of privacy-preserving systems have been created that use central servers only for intercommunication (see section below).
simplification: Not all systems with central servers need to have access to personal location data; a number of privacy-preserving systems have been created that use central servers only for intercommunication.

original: In South Korea, a non-app-based system was used to perform contact tracing.
simplification: In South Korea, a non-app-based system was used for contact tracing.

original: Instead of using a dedicated app, the system gathered tracking information from a variety of sources including mobile device tracking data and card transaction data, and combined these to generate notices via text messages to potentially-infected individuals.
simplification: Instead of using a dedicated app, the system gathered tracking information from a variety of sources including mobile device tracking data and card transaction data. They then combined these to generate notices via text messages to potentially-infected individuals.

original: In addition to using this information to alert potential contacts, the government has also made the location information publicly available, something permitted because of far-reaching changes to information privacy laws after the MERS outbreak in that country.
simplification: In addition to using this information to alert potential contacts, the government has also made the location information publicly available. This was allowed because of changes to information privacy laws after the MERS outbreak in that country.

original: This information is available to the public via a number of apps and websites.Countries including Germany considered using both centralized and privacy-preserving systems.
simplification: This information is available to the public via a number of apps and websites. Countries, such as Germany, considered using both centralized and privacy-preserving systems.

original: As of 6 April 2020, the details had not yet been released.
simplification: The details had not yet been released as of 6 April 2020

original: Privacy-preserving contact tracing is a well-established concept, with a substantial body of research literature dating back to at least 2013.As of 7 April 2020, over a dozen expert groups were working on privacy-friendly solutions, such as using Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) to log a user's proximity to other cellphones.
simplification: Privacy-preserving contact tracing is a well-established concept, with a large body of research literature dating back to at least 2013. As of 7 April 2020, over a dozen expert groups were working on privacy-friendly solutions, such as using Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) to log a user's closeness to other cellphones.

original: However, PEPP-PT is a co-ordination effort which contains both centralised and decentralised approaches, and is not a single protocol.Decentralised protocols include Decentralized Privacy-Preserving Proximity Tracing (DP-PPT/DP-3T), Temporary Contact Numbers (TCN, fka Contact Event Numbers, CEN), Privacy Sensitive Protocols and Mechanisms for Mobile Contact Tracing (PACT) and others.
simplification: PEPP-PT is a co-ordination effort which contains both centralised and decentralised approaches, and is not a single protocol. Decentralised protocols include Decentralized Privacy-Preserving Proximity Tracing (DP-PPT/DP-3T), Temporary Contact Numbers (TCN, fka Contact Event Numbers, CEN), Privacy Sensitive Protocols and Mechanisms for Mobile Contact Tracing (PACT) and others.

original: In these protocols, identifiable personal data never leaves the device, and all matching happens on-device.
simplification: In these protocols, identifiable personal data never leaves the device, and all matching happens on-device.

original: The Privacy Group at MIT Media Lab has been developing SafePaths, a platform for using privacy-preserving techniques when collecting and using location or path intersection data to track the spread of COVID-19.
simplification: The Privacy Group at MIT Media Lab has been developing SafePaths, a platform for using privacy-preserving techniques when collecting and using location or path intersection data to track the spread of COVID-19.

original: It is based on research from the whitepaper "Apps Gone Rogue: Maintaining Personal Privacy in an Epidemic" released in March 2020.Another similar effort is the SafeTrace platform by Enigma MPC, a company developing privacy technologies that was also originally founded at the MIT Media Lab.
simplification: It is based on research from the whitepaper "Apps Gone Rogue: Maintaining Personal Privacy in an Epidemic". Another similar effort is the SafeTrace platform by Enigma MPC, a company developing privacy technologies.

original: SafeTrace utilizes secure hardware technologies to allow users to share sensitive location and health data with other users and officials, without compromising the privacy of that data.
simplification: SafeTrace utilizes secure hardware technologies to allow users to share sensitive location and health data with other users and officials, without compromising the privacy of that data.

original: On 5 April 2020, the global TCN Coalition was founded by groups that had coalesced around what was essentially the same approach and largely overlapping protocols, with the goal to reduce fragmentation, and enable global interoperability of tracing and alerting apps, a key aspect of achieving widespread adoption.
simplification: On 5 April 2020, the global TCN Coalition was founded by groups that had united around what was almost the same approach and largely overlapping protocols. They had the goal to reduce fragmentation, and enable global interoperability of tracing and alerting apps, a key aspect of achieving widespread adoption.

original: On 10 April 2020, Google and Apple, the companies that control the Android and iOS mobile platforms, announced an initiative for contact tracing, which they claimed would preserve privacy, based on a combination of Bluetooth Low Energy technology and privacy-preserving cryptography.
simplification: Google and Apple, the companies that control the Android and iOS mobile platforms, announced an initiative for contact tracing on 10 April 2020. They claimed this would preserve privacy, based on a combination of Bluetooth Low Energy technology and privacy-preserving cryptography.

original: They also published specifications of the core technologies used in the system.
simplification: They also published specifications of the main technologies used in the system.

original: According to Apple and Google, the system is intended to be rolled out in three stages:
simplification: Apple and Google have said that the system is intended to be rolled out in three stages:

original: Few data are available about microscopic lesions and the pathophysiology of COVID-19.
simplification: There is not much data available about microscopic lesions and the pathophysiology of COVID-19.

original: The main pathological findings at autopsy are:
simplification: The main pathological findings at autopsy are:

original: Macroscopy: pleurisy, pericarditis, lung consolidation and pulmonary oedema
simplification: Macroscopy: pleurisy, pericarditis, lung consolidation and pulmonary oedema

original: Four types of severity of viral pneumonia can be observed:
simplification: Four types of severity of viral pneumonia can be found:

original: mild pneumonia: pulmonary oedema, pneumocyte hyperplasia, large atypical pneumocytes, interstitial inflammation with lymphocytic infiltration and multinucleated giant cell formation
simplification: mild pneumonia: pulmonary oedema, pneumocyte hyperplasia, large atypical pneumocytes, interstitial inflammation with lymphocytic infiltration and multinucleated giant cell formation

original: severe pneumonia: diffuse alveolar damage (DAD) with diffuse alveolar exudates.
simplification: severe pneumonia: diffuse alveolar damage (DAD) with diffuse alveolar exudates.

original: DAD is the cause of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and severe hypoxemia.
simplification: DAD is the cause of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and severe hypoxemia.

original: Preventive measures to reduce the chances of infection include staying at home, avoiding crowded places, washing hands with soap and water often and for at least 20 seconds, practising good respiratory hygiene and avoiding touching the eyes, nose or mouth with unwashed hands.
simplification: Preventive measures to reduce the chances of infection include staying at home, avoiding crowded places, and washing hands with soap and water often and for at least 20 seconds. Practising good respiratory hygiene and avoiding touching the face with unwashed hands are also good preventive measures.

original: The CDC recommends covering the mouth and nose with a tissue when coughing or sneezing and recommends using the inside of the elbow if no tissue is available.
simplification: The CDC recommends covering the mouth and nose with a tissue when coughing or sneezing. They also recommend using the inside of the elbow if no tissue is available.

original: Proper hand hygiene after any cough or sneeze is encouraged.
simplification: Good hand hygiene after any cough or sneeze is encouraged.

original: The CDC has recommended the use of cloth face coverings in public settings, in part to limit transmission by asymptomatic individuals.Social distancing strategies aim to reduce contact of infected persons with large groups by closing schools and workplaces, restricting travel and cancelling large public gatherings.
simplification: The CDC has recommended the use of cloth face coverings in public settings, in part to limit the spread of the virus by people with no symptoms. Social distancing strategies aim to reduce contact of infected persons with large groups by closing schools and workplaces, restricting travel and cancelling large public gatherings.

original: Distancing guidelines also include that people stay at least 6 feet (1.8 m) apart.
simplification: Distancing guidelines also include that people stay at least 6 feet (1.8 m) apart.

original: There is no medication known to be effective at preventing COVID-19.As a vaccine is not expected until 2021 at the earliest, a key part of managing COVID-19 is trying to decrease the epidemic peak, known as "flattening the curve".
simplification: There is no medication known to be effective at preventing COVID-19. As a vaccine is not expected until 2021 at the earliest, a key part of managing COVID-19 is trying to decrease the epidemic peak. This is known as "flattening the curve".

original: The CDC also recommends that individuals wash hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, especially after going to the toilet or when hands are visibly dirty, before eating and after blowing one's nose, coughing or sneezing.
simplification: The CDC recommends that people wash their hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds. This is especially important after going to the toilet or when hands are visibly dirty, before eating and after blowing your nose, coughing or sneezing.

original: It further recommends using an alcohol-based hand sanitiser with at least 60% alcohol, but only when soap and water are not readily available.For areas where commercial hand sanitisers are not readily available, the WHO provides two formulations for local production.
simplification: It further recommends using an alcohol-based hand sanitiser with at least 60% alcohol, but only when soap and water are not available. For areas where commercial hand sanitisers are not readily available, the WHO provides two formulations for local production.

original: In these formulations, the antimicrobial activity arises from ethanol or isopropanol.
