On 6 March, the Italian College of Anaesthesia, Analgesia, Resuscitation and Intensive Care (SIAARTI) published medical ethics recommendations regarding triage protocols that might be used.

original: On 19 March, Italy overtook China as the country with the most coronavirus-related deaths in the world after reporting 3,405 fatalities from the pandemic.
simplification: On 19 March, Italy overtook China as the country with the most coronavirus-related deaths in the world. This came after Italy reported 3,405 fatalities from the pandemic.

original: On 22 March, it was reported that Russia had sent nine military planes with medical equipment to Italy.
simplification: On 22 March, it was reported that Russia had sent nine military planes with medical equipment to Italy.

original: As of 5 April, there were 128,948 confirmed cases, 15,887 deaths, and 21,815 recoveries in Italy, with the majority of those cases occurring in the Lombardy region.
simplification: As of 5 April, there were 128,948 confirmed cases in Italy. 15,887 of those cases resulted in death, and 21,815 were classed as recovered. The majority of those cases occurred in the Lombardy region.

original: A CNN report indicated that the combination of Italy's large elderly population and inability to test all who have the virus to date may be contributing to the high fatality rate.
simplification: A CNN report indicated that Italy's large elderly population, and their inability to test all who have the virus to date, may be contributing to the high fatality rate.

original: The United Kingdom's response to the virus first emerged as one of the most relaxed of the affected countries, and until 18 March 2020, the British government did not impose any form of social distancing or mass quarantine measures on its citizens.
simplification: The United Kingdom's response to the emerging virus was one of the most relaxed of the affected countries; until 18 March 2020, the British government did not impose any form of social distancing or mass quarantine measures on its citizens.

original: On 20 March, the government announced that all leisure establishments such as pubs and gyms were to close as soon as possible, and promised to pay up to 80% of workers' wages to a limit of £2,500 per month to prevent unemployment in the crisis.On 23 March, the Prime Minister announced tougher social distancing measures, banning gatherings of more than two people and restricting travel and outdoor activity to that deemed strictly necessary.
simplification: On 20 March, the government announced that all leisure establishments such as pubs and gyms were to close as soon as possible. The government promised to pay up to 80% of workers' wages to a limit of £2,500 per month, to avoid unemployment in the crisis. On 23 March, the Prime Minister announced tougher social distancing measures, banning gatherings of more than two people, and restricting travel and outdoor activity to that deemed necessary.

original: Unlike previous measures, these restrictions were enforceable by police through the issuing of fines and the dispersal of gatherings.
simplification: Unlike previous measures, these restrictions were enforceable by police through the issuing of fines and the dispersal of gatherings.

original: Most businesses were ordered to close, with exceptions for businesses deemed "essential", including supermarkets, pharmacies, banks, hardware shops, petrol stations, and garages.
simplification: Most businesses were ordered to close, with exceptions for businesses deemed "essential". Essential businesses included supermarkets, pharmacies, banks, hardware shops, petrol stations, and garages.

original: On 20 January, the first known case of COVID-19 was confirmed in the Pacific Northwest state of Washington in a man who had returned from Wuhan on 15 January.
simplification: On 20 January, the first known case of COVID-19 was confirmed in the Pacific Northwest state of Washington. The case was identified in a man who had returned from Wuhan on 15 January.

original: The White House Coronavirus Task Force was established on 29 January.
simplification: The White House Coronavirus Task Force was established on 29 January.

original: On 31 January, the Trump administration declared a public health emergency, and placed restrictions on entry for travellers from China.
simplification: On 31 January, the Trump administration declared a public health emergency, and placed restrictions on entry for travellers from China.

original: On 28 January 2020, the Center for Disease Control—the leading public health institute of the U.S. government—announced they had developed their own testing kit.
simplification: On 28 January 2020, the Center for Disease Control announced they had developed their own testing kit.

original: Despite doing so, the United States had a slow start in testing, which obscured the true extent of the outbreak at the time.
simplification: Despite doing so, the United States had a slow start in testing, which obscured how bad the outbreak was at the time.

original: Testing was marred by defective test kits produced by the federal government in February, a lack of federal government approval for non-government test kits (by academia, companies and hospitals) until the end of February, and restrictive criteria for people to qualify for a test until early March (a doctor's order was required thereafter).
simplification: Testing was affected negatively by defective test kits, produced by the federal government, and a lack of federal government approval for non-government test kits (by academia, companies and hospitals) until the end of February Furthermore, restrictive criteria for people to qualify for a test until early March also affected testing (a doctor's order was required thereafter).

original: By 27 February, The Washington Post reported fewer than 4,000 tests had been conducted in the United States.
simplification: By 27 February, The Washington Post reported fewer than 4,000 tests had been conducted in the United States.

original: By 13 March, The Atlantic reported that less than 14,000 tests had been conducted.
simplification: By 13 March, The Atlantic reported that less than 14,000 tests had been conducted.

original: On 22 March, the Associated Press reported: "Many people who have symptoms and a doctor's order have waited hours or days for a test."After the first death in the United States was reported in Washington state on 29 February, Governor Jay Inslee declared a state of emergency, an action that was soon followed by other states.
simplification: On 22 March, the Associated Press reported: "Many people who have symptoms and a doctor's order have waited hours or days for a test." After the first death in the United States was reported in Washington state on 29 February, Governor Jay Inslee declared a state of emergency. This action was soon followed by other states.

original: Schools in the Seattle area cancelled classes on 3 March, and by mid-March, schools across the country were shutting down.On 6 March 2020, the United States was advised of projections for the impact of the new coronavirus on the country by a group of epidemiologists at Imperial College London.
simplification: Schools in the Seattle area cancelled classes on 3 March, and by mid-March, schools across the country were shutting down. On 6 March 2020, the United States was advised of possibilities for the impact of the new coronavirus on the country by a group of epidemiologists at Imperial College London.

original: On the same day President Trump signed the Coronavirus Preparedness and Response Supplemental Appropriations Act, which provided $8.3 billion in emergency funding for federal agencies to respond to the outbreak.
simplification: On the same day President Trump signed the Coronavirus Preparedness and Response Supplemental Appropriations Act. The Act provided $8.3 billion in emergency funding for federal agencies to respond to the outbreak.

original: Corporations imposed employee travel restrictions, cancelled conferences, and encouraged employees to work from home.
simplification: Corporations imposed employee travel restrictions, cancelled conferences, and encouraged employees to work from home.

original: Sports events and seasons were cancelled.On 11 March, Trump announced travel restrictions for most of Europe, excluding the United Kingdom, for 30 days, effective 13 March.
simplification: Sports events and seasons were cancelled. On 11 March, Trump announced travel restrictions for most of Europe, excluding the United Kingdom, for 30 days. The travel restrictions came into effect on 13 March.

original: The following day, he expanded the restrictions to include the United Kingdom and Ireland.
simplification: The following day, he expanded the restrictions to include the United Kingdom and Ireland.

original: On 13 March, he declared a national emergency, which made federal funds available to respond to the crisis.
simplification: On 13 March, he declared a national emergency, which made federal funds available to respond to the crisis.

original: Beginning on 15 March, many businesses closed or reduced hours throughout the U.S. to try to reduce the spread of the virus.
simplification: Beginning on 15 March, many businesses closed or reduced hours throughout the U.S. to try to reduce the spread of the virus.

original: By 17 March, the epidemic had been confirmed in all 50 states and in the District of Columbia.On 23 March, it was reported that New York City had 10,700 cases of the coronavirus, more than the total number of cases in South Korea.
simplification: By 17 March, the epidemic had been confirmed in all 50 states and in the District of Columbia.On 23 March, it was reported that New York City had 10,700 cases of the coronavirus, more than the total number of cases in South Korea.

original: On 25 March, the governor said that social distancing seemed to be working, as estimates of case doubling slowed from 2.0 days to 4.7 days.
simplification: On 25 March, the governor said that social distancing seemed to be working, as estimates of case doubling slowed from 2.0 days to 4.7 days.

original: As of 28 March, there were 32,308 confirmed cases in New York City, and 672 people had died from the virus.On 26 March, the United States was reported to have more confirmed coronavirus infection cases than any other country in the world, including China and Italy.As of 8 April, 400,335 cases have been confirmed in the United States, and 12,841 people have died.
simplification: As of 28 March, there were 32,308 confirmed cases in New York City, and 672 people had died from the virus. On 26 March, the United States was reported to have more confirmed coronavirus infection cases than any other country in the world. As of 8 April, 400,335 cases have been confirmed in the United States, and 12,841 people have died.

original: Per media reports on 30 March, U.S. President Trump has decided to extend social distancing guidelines until 30 April.
simplification: U.S. President Trump has decided to extend social distancing guidelines until 30 April.

original: On the same day, the USNS Comfort, a hospital ship with about 1000 beds, made anchor in New York.
simplification: The USNS Comfort, a hospital ship with about 1000 beds, made anchor in New York.

original: On 3 April, the U.S. had a record 884 deaths due to the coronavirus in a 24-hour period.
simplification: On 3 April, the U.S. had a record 884 deaths due to the coronavirus in a 24-hour period.

original: In the state of New York the cases have exceeded 100,000 people on 3 April.The White House has been criticized for downplaying the threat and controlling the messaging by directing health officials and scientists to coordinate public statements and publications related to the virus with the office of Vice-President Mike Pence.
simplification: In the state of New York, there have been over 100,000 cases on 3 April. The White House has been criticized for downplaying the threat and controlling the messaging by directing health officials and scientists to coordinate public statements and publications related to the virus.

original: Overall approval of Trump's management of the crisis has been polarized along partisan lines.
simplification: Overall approval of Trump's management of the crisis has been polarized along partisan lines.

original: Some U.S. officials and commentators criticized the U.S. reliance on importation of critical materials, including essential medical supplies, from China.
simplification: Some U.S. officials and commentators criticized the U.S. reliance on importation of critical materials from China. The critical materials imported includes essential medical supplies.

original: An analysis of air travel patterns was used to map and predict patterns of spread and was published in The Journal of Travel Medicine in mid-January 2020.
simplification: An analysis of air travel patterns was used to map and predict patterns of virus spread. It was published in The Journal of Travel Medicine in mid-January 2020.

original: Based on 2018 information from the International Air Transport Association, Bangkok, Hong Kong, Tokyo, and Taipei had the largest volume of travellers from Wuhan.
simplification: Bangkok, Hong Kong, Tokyo, and Taipei had the largest volume of travellers from Wuhan; based on 2018 information from the International Air Transport Association.

original: Results are generally available within a few hours to 2 days.
simplification: Results are generally available within a few hours to 2 days.

original: The RT-PCR test performed with throat swabs is only reliable in the first week of the disease.
simplification: The RT-PCR test performed with throat swabs is only reliable in the first week of the disease.

original: Later on the virus can disappear in the throat while it continues to multiply in the lungs.
simplification: Later on, the virus can disappear in the throat while it continues to multiply in the lungs.

original: For infected people tested in the second week, alternatively sample material can then be taken from the deep airways by suction catheter or coughing up material (sputum) can be used.
simplification: For infected people tested in the second week, alternative sample material can then be taken from the deep airways by suction catheter or coughing up material (sputum) can be used.

original: One of the early PCR tests was developed at Charité in Berlin in January 2020 using real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR), and formed the basis of 250,000 kits for distribution by the World Health Organization (WHO).
simplification: One of the early PCR tests was developed at Charité in Berlin in January 2020 using real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR). It was formed the basis of 250,000 kits for distribution by the World Health Organization (WHO).

original: The United Kingdom had also developed a test by 23 January 2020.The South Korean company Kogenebiotech developed a clinical grade, PCR-based SARS-CoV-2 detection kit (PowerChek Coronavirus) on 28 January 2020.
simplification: The United Kingdom had also developed a test by 23 January 2020. The South Korean company Kogenebiotech developed a clinical grade PCR-based SARS-CoV-2 detection kit (PowerChek Coronavirus) on 28 January 2020.

original: It looks for the "E" gene shared by all beta coronaviruses, and the RdRp gene specific to SARS-CoV-2.In China, BGI Group was one of the first companies to receive emergency use approval from China's National Medical Products Administration for a PCR-based SARS-CoV-2 detection kit.In the United States, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) is distributing its 2019-Novel Coronavirus (2019-nCoV) Real-Time RT-PCR Diagnostic Panel to public health labs through the International Reagent Resource.
simplification: It looks for the "E" gene shared by all beta coronaviruses, and the RdRp gene specific to SARS-CoV-2. In China, BGI Group was one of the first companies to receive emergency use approval from China's National Medical Products Administration for a PCR-based SARS-CoV-2 detection kit. In the United States, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) is distributing its 2019-Novel Coronavirus (2019-nCoV) Real-Time RT-PCR Diagnostic Panel to public health labs through the International Reagent Resource.

original: One of three genetic tests in older versions of the test kits caused inconclusive results due to faulty reagents, and a bottleneck of testing at the CDC in Atlanta; this resulted in an average of fewer than 100 samples a day being successfully processed throughout the whole of February 2020.
simplification: One of three genetic tests in older versions of the test kits caused inconclusive results due to faulty reagents, and a bottleneck of testing at the CDC in Atlanta; this resulted in an average of fewer than 100 samples a day being successfully processed throughout the whole of February 2020.

original: Tests using two components were not determined to be reliable until 28 February 2020, and it was not until then that state and local laboratories were permitted to begin testing.
simplification: Tests using two components were not determined to be reliable until 28 February 2020. It was not until then that state and local laboratories were allowed to begin testing.

original: The test was approved by the Food and Drug Administration under an Emergency Use Authorization. US commercial labs began testing in early March 2020.
simplification: The test was approved by the Food and Drug Administration under an Emergency Use Authorization. US commercial labs began testing in early March 2020.

original: As of 5 March 2020 LabCorp announced nationwide availability of COVID-19 testing based on RT-PCR.
simplification: As of 5 March 2020 LabCorp announced nationwide availability of COVID-19 testing based on RT-PCR.

original: Quest Diagnostics similarly made nationwide COVID-19 testing available as of 9 March 2020.
simplification: Quest Diagnostics made nationwide COVID-19 testing available on 9 March 2020

original: No quantity limitations were announced; specimen collection and processing must be performed according to CDC requirements.
simplification: No quantity limitations were announced; specimen collection and processing must be performed according to CDC requirements.

original: In Russia, the COVID-19 test was developed and produced by the State Research Center of Virology and Biotechnology VECTOR.
simplification: In Russia, the COVID-19 test was developed and produced by the State Research Center of Virology and Biotechnology VECTOR.

original: On 11 February 2020 the test was registered by the Federal Service for Surveillance in Healthcare.On 12 March 2020, Mayo Clinic was reported to have developed a test to detect COVID-19 infection.On 13 March 2020, Roche Diagnostics received FDA approval for a test which could be performed within 3.5 hours in high volume, thus allowing one machine to do approximately 4,128 tests in a 24-hour period.
simplification: On 11 February 2020, the test was registered by the Federal Service for Surveillance in Healthcare. On 12 March 2020, Mayo Clinic was reported to have developed a test to detect COVID-19 infection. On 13 March 2020, Roche Diagnostics received FDA approval for a test which could be performed within 3.5 hours in high volume, therefore allowing 1 machine to do over 4,000 tests in a 24-hour period.

original: On 19 March 2020, the FDA issued emergency use authorization (EUA) to Abbott Laboratories for a test on Abbott's m2000 system; the FDA had previously issued similar authorization to Hologic, LabCorp, and Thermo Fisher Scientific.
simplification: On 19 March 2020, the FDA issued emergency use authorization (EUA) to Abbott Laboratories for a test on their m2000 system. The FDA had previously issued similar authorization to Hologic, LabCorp, and Thermo Fisher Scientific.

original: On 21 March 2020, Cepheid similarly received EUA from the FDA for a test that takes about 45 minutes.
simplification: On 21 March 2020, Cepheid received EUA from the FDA for a test that takes about 45 minutes.

original: The FDA has approved a test that uses isothermal nucleic acid amplification technology instead of PCR.
simplification: The FDA has approved a test that uses isothermal nucleic acid amplification technology instead of PCR.

original: Since this does not require a series of alternating temperature cycles this method can deliver positive results in as little as five minutes and negative results in 13 minutes.
simplification: Since this does not require a series of alternating temperature cycles, this method can deliver positive results in as little as 5 minutes and negative results in 13 minutes.

original: There are currently about 18,000 of these machines in the U.S. and Abbott expects to ramp up manufacturing to deliver 50,000 tests per day.A test which uses a monoclonal antibody which specifically binds to the nucleocapsid protein (N protein) of the novel coronavirus is being developed in Taiwan, with the hope that it can provide results in 15 to 20 minutes just like a rapid influenza test.
simplification: There are currently about 18,000 of these machines in the U.S., and Abbott expects to ramp up manufacturing to deliver 50,000 tests per day. A test which uses a monoclonal antibody which binds to the nucleocapsid protein (N protein) of the novel coronavirus is being developed in Taiwan. They hope that it can provide results in 15 to 20 minutes, just like a rapid influenza test.

original: A March 2020 literature review concluded that "chest radiographs are of little diagnostic value in early stages, whereas CT [computed tomography] findings may be present even before symptom onset."
simplification: A March 2020 literature review concluded that "chest radiographs are of little diagnostic value in early stages, whereas CT [computed tomography] findings may be present even before symptom onset."

original: Subpleural dominance, crazy paving and consolidation develop as the disease evolves.
simplification: Subpleural dominance, crazy paving and consolidation develop as the disease progresses

original: A study comparing PCR to CT in Wuhan at the point of origin of the current pandemic has suggested that CT is significantly more sensitive than PCR, though less specific, with many of its imaging features overlapping with other pneumonias and disease processes.
simplification: A study comparing PCR to CT in Wuhan has suggested that CT is significantly more sensitive than PCR, but is less specific. Many of its imaging features overlap with other pneumonias and disease processes.

original: As of March 2020, the American College of Radiology recommends that "CT should not be used to screen for or as a first-line test to diagnose COVID-19".As of March 2020, the CDC recommends PCR for initial screening.
simplification: As of March 2020, the American College of Radiology recommends that "CT should not be used to screen for, or as a first-line test, to diagnose COVID-19". As of March 2020, the CDC recommends PCR for initial screening.

original: Part of the immune response to infection is the production of antibodies including IgM and IgG.
simplification: Part of the immune response to infection is the production of antibodies. These antibodies include IgM and IgG.

original: These can be used to detect infection in individuals starting 7 days or so after the onset of symptoms, to determine immunity, and in population surveillance.Assays can be performed in central laboratories (CLT) or by point-of-care testing (PoCT).
simplification: These can be used to detect infection in individuals starting 7 days or so after the onset of symptoms. They can also be used to determine immunity, and in population surveillance. Assays can be performed in central laboratories (CLT) or by point-of-care testing (PoCT).

original: The high-throughput automated systems in many clinical laboratories will be able to perform these assays but their availability will depend on the rate of production for each system.
simplification: The high-throughput automated systems in clinical laboratories will be able to perform these assays, but their availability will depend on the rate of production for each system.

original: For CLT a single specimen of peripheral blood is commonly used, although serial specimens can be used to follow the immune response.
simplification: For CLT, a single specimen of peripheral blood is commonly used. However, serial specimens can be used to follow the immune response.

original: For PoCT a single specimen of blood is usually obtained by skin puncture.
simplification: For PoCT, a single specimen of blood is usually obtained by skin puncture.

original: Unlike PCR methods an extraction step is not needed before assay.On March 26, 2020, the FDA named 29 entities that provided notification to the agency as required and are now therefore able to distribute their antibody tests.
simplification: Unlike PCR methods, an extraction step is not needed before assay. On March 26, 2020, the FDA named 29 entities that provided notification to the agency as required, and are now able to distribute their antibody tests.

original: As of April 7, 2020, only a single test has been approved by the FDA under an emergency use authorization.In late March 2020, Euroimmun Medical Laboratory Diagnostics and Epitope Diagnostics received European approvals for their test kits, which can detect IgG and IgA antibodies against the virus in blood samples.
simplification: As of April 7 2020, only a single test has been approved by the FDA under an emergency use authorization. In late March 2020, Euroimmun Medical Laboratory Diagnostics and Epitope Diagnostics received European approvals for their test kits. The kits can detect IgG and IgA antibodies against the virus in blood samples.

original: The testing capacity is several hundred samples within hours and therefore much faster than the conventional PCR assay of viral RNA.
simplification: The testing capacity is several hundred samples within hours, and therefore much faster than the conventional PCR assay of viral RNA.

original: The antibodies are usually detectable 14 days after the onset of the infection.In early April, the UK found none of the antibody test kits it purchased were sufficiently good to use.
simplification: The antibodies are usually detectable 14 days after the onset of the infection. In early April, the UK found none of the antibody test kits that were purchased were good enough to use.

original: Hong Kong has set up a scheme where suspected patients can stay home, "emergency department will give a specimen tube to the patient", they spit into it, send it back and get a test result a while after.The British NHS has announced that it is piloting a scheme to test suspected cases at home, which removes the risk of a patient infecting others if they come to a hospital or having to disinfect an ambulance if one is used.In drive-through testing for COVID-19 for suspected cases, a healthcare professional takes sample using appropriate precautions.
simplification: Hong Kong has set up a scheme where suspected patients can stay home, "emergency department will give a specimen tube to the patient", they spit into it, send it back and get a test result shortly after. The British NHS has announced that it is trialling a scheme to test suspected cases at home, which removes the risk of a patient infecting others if they come to a hospital, or having to disinfect an ambulance if one is used. In drive-through testing for COVID-19 for suspected cases, a healthcare professional takes a sample using appropriate precautions.

original: Drive-through centers have helped South Korea do some of the fastest, most-extensive testing of any country.In Germany, the National Association of Statutory Health Insurance Physicians said on 2 March, that it had a capacity for about 12,000 tests per day in the ambulatory setting and 10.700 had been tested in the prior week.
simplification: Drive-through centers have helped South Korea do some of the fastest, most-extensive testing of any country. On 2 March in Germany, the National Association of Statutory Health Insurance Physicians said that it had a capacity for about 12,000 tests per day in the ambulatory setting and 10.700 had been tested in the prior week.

original: Costs are borne by the health insurance when the test is ordered by a physician.
simplification: Health insurance covers the cost when the test is ordered by a physician.

original: According to the president of the Robert Koch Institute, Germany has an overall capacity for 160,000 tests per week.
simplification: Germany has an overall capacity for 160,000 tests per week, according to the president of the Robert Koch Institute.

original: As of 19 March drive in tests were offered in several large cities.
simplification: As of 19 March, drive in tests were offered in several large cities.

original: As of 26 March 2020 the total number of tests performed in Germany was unknown, because only positive results are reported.
simplification: As of 26 March 2020, the total number of tests performed in Germany was unknown. This is because only positive results are reported.

original: A first lab survey revealed that as of calendar week 12/2020 a total of at least 483,295 samples were tested up to and including week 12/2020 and 33,491 samples (6.9%) tested positive for SARS-CoV-2.In Israel, researchers at Technion and Rambam Hospital developed and tested a method for testing samples from 64 patients simultaneously, by pooling the samples and only testing further if the combined sample is found to be positive.In Wuhan a makeshift 2000-sq-meter emergency detection laboratory named "Huo-Yan" (Chinese: 火眼, or "Fire Eye" in English) was opened on 5 February 2020 by BGI, which can process over 10,000 samples a day.
simplification: A total of approximately 483,295 samples were tested up to and including week 12/2020 and 33,491 samples (6.9%) tested positive for SARS-CoV-2. In Israel, researchers at Technion and Rambam Hospital developed and tested a method for testing samples from 64 patients simultaneously. They did this by pooling the samples and only testing further if the combined sample is found to be positive. In Wuhan a makeshift 2000-sq-meter emergency detection laboratory named "Huo-Yan" (Chinese: 火眼, or "Fire Eye" in English) was opened on 5 February 2020 by BGI, which can process over 10,000 samples a day.

original: With the construction overseen by BGI-founder Wang Jian and taking 5-days, modelling has show cases in Hubei would have been 47% higher and the corresponding cost of the tackling the quarantine would have doubled if this testing capacity hadn't come on line.
simplification: With the construction overseen by BGI-founder Wang Jian, modelling has show cases in Hubei would have been 47% higher, and the corresponding cost of the tackling the quarantine would have doubled if this testing capacity hadn't come on line.

original: The Wuhan Laboratory has been promptly followed by Huo-Yan labs in Shenzhen, Tianjin, Beijing, and Shanghai, in a total of 12 cities across China.
simplification: The Wuhan Laboratory has been promptly followed by Huo-Yan labs in Shenzhen, Tianjin, Beijing, and Shanghai, in a total of 12 cities across China.

original: By 4 March 2020 the daily throughput totals were 50,000 tests per day.Open source, multiplexed designs released by Origami Assays have been released that can test as many as 1122 patient samples for COVID19 using only 93 assays .  These balanced designs can be run in small laboratories without the need for robotic liquid handlers.
simplification: By 4 March 2020, the totals were 50,000 tests per day. Open source, multiplexed designs released by Origami Assays that can test as many as 1122 patient samples for COVID19 using only 93 assays have been released. These balanced designs can be run in small laboratories, without the need for robotic liquid handlers.

original: By March, shortages and insufficient amounts of reagent has become a bottleneck for mass testing in the EU and UK and the US.
simplification: By March, shortages and insufficient amounts of reagent has become a barrier for mass testing in the EU and UK and the US.

original: This has led some authors to explore sample preparation protocols that involve heating samples at 98 °C (208 °F) for 5 minutes to release RNA genomes for further testing.On 31 March it was announced United Arab Emirates was now testing more of its population for Coronavirus per head than any other country, and was on track to scale up the level of testing to reach the bulk of the population.
simplification: This has led some authors to explore sample preparation protocols that involve heating samples at 98 °C (208 °F) for 5 minutes to release RNA genomes for further testing. On 31 March, it was announced United Arab Emirates was now testing more of its population for Coronavirus per head than any other country, and was on track to increase the level of testing to reach the majority of the population.

original: This was through a combination of drive-through capability, and purchasing a population-scale mass-throughput laboratory from Group 42 and BGI (based on their "Huo-Yan" emergency detection laboratories in China).
simplification: This was through a combination of drive-through capability, and purchasing a population-scale mass-throughput laboratory.

original: Constructed in 14 days, the lab is capable of conducting tens of thousands RT-PCR tests per day and is the first in the world of this scale to be operational outside of China.
simplification: Constructed in 14 days, the lab is capable of conducting tens of thousands RT-PCR tests per day. It is the first in the world of this scale to be operational outside of China.

original: Different testing recipes targeting different parts of the coronavirus genetic profile were developed in China, France, Germany, Hong Kong, Japan, and the United States.
simplification: Different testing recipes targeting different parts of the coronavirus genetic profile were developed in China, France, Germany, Hong Kong, Japan, and the United States.

original: The World Health Organization adopted the German recipe for manufacturing kits sent to low-income countries without the resources to develop their own.
simplification: The World Health Organization adopted the German recipe for manufacturing kits sent to low-income countries without the resources to develop their own.

original: The German recipe was published on 17 January 2020; the protocol developed by the United States Centers for Disease Control was not available until 28 January, delaying available tests in the U.S.China and the United States had problems with the reliability of test kits early in the outbreak, and these countries and Australia were unable to supply enough kits to satisfy demand and recommendations for testing by health experts.
simplification: The German recipe was published on 17 January 2020, but the protocol developed by the United States Centers for Disease Control was not available until 28 January which delayed available tests in the U.S. China and the United States had problems with the reliability of test kits early in the outbreak, and alongside Australia, were unable to supply enough kits to satisfy demand and recommendations for testing by health experts.

original: In contrast, experts say South Korea's broad availability of testing helped reduce the spread of the novel coronavirus.
simplification: Experts say South Korea's broad availability of testing helped reduce the spread of the novel coronavirus.

original: Testing capacity, largely in private sector labs, was built up over several years by the South Korean government.
simplification: Testing capacity, largely in private sector labs, was built up over several years by the South Korean government.

original: On 16 March, the World Health Organization called for ramping up the testing programmes as the best way to slow the advance of COVID-19 pandemic.High demand for testing due to wide spread of the virus caused backlogs of hundreds of thousands of tests at private U.S. labs, and supplies of swabs and chemical reagents became strained.
simplification: On 16 March, the World Health Organization called for increasing the testing programmes as the best way to slow the advance of COVID-19 pandemic. High demand for testing due to wide spread of the virus caused backlogs of hundreds of thousands of tests at private U.S. labs, and supplies of swabs and chemical reagents became strained.

original: In March 2020 China reported problems with accuracy in their test kits.
simplification: In March 2020, China reported problems with accuracy in their test kits.

original: In the United States, the test kits developed by the CDC had "flaws;" the government then removed the bureaucratic barriers that had prevented private testing.Spain purchased test kits from Chinese firm  Shenzhen Bioeasy Biotechnology Co Ltd, but found that results were inaccurate.
simplification: In the United States, the test kits developed by the CDC had "flaws;" the government then removed the bureaucratic barriers that had prevented private testing. Spain purchased test kits from the Chinese firm Shenzhen Bioeasy Biotechnology Co Ltd, but found that results were inaccurate.

original: The firm explained that the incorrect results may be a result of a failure to collect samples or use the kits correctly.
simplification: The firm explained that the incorrect results may be due to failure to collect samples or use the kits correctly.

original: The Spanish ministry said it will withdraw the kits that returned incorrect results, and would replace them with a different testing kit provided by Shenzhen Bioeasy.80% of test kits the Czech Republic purchased from China gave wrong results.Slovakia purchased 1.2 million test kits from China which were found to be inaccurate.
simplification: The Spanish ministry said it will withdraw the kits that returned incorrect results, and would replace them with a different testing kit provided by Shenzhen Bioeasy.80% of test kits the Czech Republic purchased from China gave wrong results.Slovakia purchased 1.2 million test kits from China which were found to be inaccurate.

original: Prime Minister Matovič suggested these be dumped into the Danube.Ateş Kara of the Turkish Health Ministry said the test kits Turkey purchased from China had a "high error rate" and did not "put them into use."The UK purchased 3.5 million test kits from China but in early April 2020 announced these were not usable.
simplification: Prime Minister Matovič suggested these be dumped into the Danube.Ateş Kara of the Turkish Health Ministry said the test kits Turkey purchased from China had a "high error rate" and did not "put them into use." The UK purchased 3.5 million test kits from China, but in early April 2020 announced these were not usable.

original: Testing, followed with quarantine of those who tested positive and tracing of those with whom the SARS-CoV-2 positive people had had contact, resulted in positive outcomes.
simplification: Testing followed with quarantine of those who tested positive, and tracing of those with whom the SARS-CoV-2 positive people had had contact, had positive results

original: Researchers working in the Italian town of Vò, the site of the first COVID-19 death in Italy, conducted two rounds of testing on the entire population of about 3,400 people, about ten days apart.
simplification: Researchers working in the Italian town of Vò conducted two rounds of testing on the entire population of about 3,400 people, about ten days apart.

original: About half the people testing positive had no symptoms, and all discovered cases were quarantined.
simplification: About half the people testing positive had no symptoms, and all confirmed cases were quarantined.

original: With travel to the commune restricted, this eliminated new infections completely.
simplification: Travel to the commune was restricted, which eliminated new infections completely.

original: With aggressive contact tracing, inbound travel restrictions, testing, and quarantining, the 2020 coronavirus pandemic in Singapore has proceeded much more slowly than in other developed countries, but without extreme restrictions like forced closure of restaurants and retail establishments.
simplification: With aggressive contact tracing, inbound travel restrictions, testing, and quarantining, the 2020 coronavirus pandemic in Singapore has proceeded much more slowly than in other developed countries. Singapore did not employ extreme restrictions like forced closure of restaurants and retail establishments.

original: Many events have been cancelled, and Singapore did start advising residents to stay at home on 28 March, but schools reopened on time after holiday break on 23 March.
simplification: Many events have been cancelled, and Singapore did start advising residents to stay at home on 28 March. Schools reopened on time after holiday break on 23 March.

original: Several other countries have also managed the pandemic with aggressive contact tracing, inbound travel restrictions, testing, and quarantining, but with less aggressive lock-downs, such as Iceland and South Korea.
simplification: Several other countries, such as Iceland and South Korea, have also managed the pandemic with aggressive contact tracing, inbound travel restrictions, testing, and quarantining, but with less aggressive lock-downs.

original: A statistical study has found that countries that have tested more, relative to the number of deaths, have much lower case fatality rates, probably because these countries are better able to detect those with only mild or no symptoms.
simplification: A statistical study has found that countries that have tested more, relative to the number of deaths, have much lower case fatality rates. This is probably because these countries are better able to detect those with only mild or no symptoms.

original: WHO recommends that countries that do not have testing capacity and national laboratories with limited experience on COVID-19 send their first five positives and the first ten negative COVID-19 samples to one of the 16 WHO reference laboratories for confirmatory testing.
simplification: WHO recommends that countries that do not have testing capacity and national laboratories with limited experience on COVID-19 send their first 5 positives and the first 10 negative COVID-19 samples to one of the 16 WHO reference laboratories for confirmatory testing.

original: Out of the 16 reference laboratories, 7 are in Asia, 5 in Europe, 2 in Africa, 1 in North America and 1 in Australia.
simplification: There are 16 reference laboratories; 7 are in Asia, 5 in Europe, 2 in Africa, 1 in North America and 1 in Australia.

original: In the following chart, the column “Positive as % of tests” is influenced by the country's testing policy.
simplification: In the following chart, the column “Positive as % of tests” is influenced by the country's testing policy.

original: A country that only tests people admitted to hospitals will have a higher positive as % of tests than a country that tests all citizens, whether or not they are showing symptoms, other things being equal.
simplification: A country that only tests people admitted to hospitals will have a higher positive as % of tests than a country that tests all citizens, whether or not they are showing symptoms.

original: Hand washing (or handwashing), also known as hand hygiene, is the act of cleaning one's hands for the purpose of removing soil, grease, microorganisms, or other unwanted substances.
simplification: Hand washing is the act of cleaning one's hands for the purpose of removing soil, grease, microorganisms, or other unwanted substances.

original: Hand washing with soap consistently at certain "critical moments" during the day prevents the spread of many diseases, for example diarrhoea and cholera, which are transmitted through fecal–oral route.
simplification: Hand washing with soap consistently at certain "critical moments" during the day prevents the spread of many diseases, for example diarrhoea and cholera, which are transmitted through fecal–oral route.

original: People can also become infected with respiratory diseases such as influenza or the common cold, for example, if they do not wash their hands before touching their eyes, nose, or mouth (i.e., mucous membranes).
simplification: People can also become infected with respiratory diseases such as influenza or the common cold if they do not wash their hands before touching their eyes, nose, or mouth (i.e., mucous membranes).

original: The five critical moments during the day where washing hands with soap is important include: before and after defecation, after cleaning a child's bottom or changing nappies, before feeding a child, before eating and before and after preparing food or handling raw meat, fish, or poultry.
simplification: The 5 critical moments during the day where washing hands with soap is important include: before and after going to the toilet, after cleaning a child's bottom or changing nappies, before feeding a child, before eating and before and after preparing food or handling raw meat, fish, or poultry.

original: If water and soap are not available, hands can be cleaned with ash. The World Health Organization recommends washing hands:
simplification: If water and soap are not available, hands can be cleaned with ash. The World Health Organization recommends washing hands:

original: Before, during, and after preparing food.
simplification: Before, during, and after preparing food.

original: Before and after caring for a sick person.
simplification: Before and after caring for a sick person.

original: After changing the diapers or cleaning up a child who has used the toilet.
simplification: After changing the diapers of a child and after cleaning up a child who has used the toilet.

original: After blowing your nose, coughing or sneezing.
simplification: After blowing your nose, coughing or sneezing.

original: After touching animal, animal feed, or animal waste.
simplification: After touching animal, animal feed, or animal waste.

original: Medical hand hygiene refers to hygiene practices related to medical procedures.
simplification: Medical hand hygiene refers to hygiene practices related to medical procedures.

original: Hand washing before administering medicine or medical care can prevent or minimize the spread of disease.
simplification: Hand washing before giving medicine or medical care can prevent, or minimize, the spread of disease.

original: The main medical purpose of washing hands is to cleanse the hands of pathogens (bacteria, viruses, or other microorganisms that can cause disease) and chemicals which can cause harm or diseases.
simplification: The main medical purpose of washing hands is to cleanse the hands of pathogens (bacteria, viruses, or other microorganisms that can cause disease) and chemicals which can cause harm or diseases.

original: This is especially important for people who handle food or work in the medical field, but also an important practice for the general public.
simplification: This is very important for people who handle food or work in the medical field. It is also an important practice for the general public.

original: Hand washing has many health benefits, including minimizing the spread of influenza, coronavirus, and other infectious diseases; preventing infectious causes of diarrhea; decreasing respiratory infections;
simplification: Hand washing has many health benefits, including: minimizing the spread of influenza, coronavirus, and other infectious diseases; preventing infectious causes of diarrhea, and decreasing respiratory infections.

original: and reducing infant mortality rate at home birth deliveries.
simplification: and reducing the death rate of babies at home birth deliveries.

original: A 2013 study showed that improved hand washing practices may lead to small improvements in the length growth in children under five years of age.
simplification: A 2013 study showed that improved hand washing practices may lead to small improvements in the length growth in children under five years of age.

original: In developing countries, childhood mortality rates related to respiratory and diarrheal diseases can be reduced by introducing simple behavioral changes, such as hand washing with soap.
simplification: In developing countries, childhood death rates related to respiratory and diarrheal diseases can be reduced by introducing simple changes, such as hand washing with soap.

original: This simple action can reduce the rate of mortality from these diseases by almost 50%.
simplification: This simple action can reduce the rate of deaths from these diseases by almost 50%.

original: Interventions that promote hand washing can reduce diarrhoea episodes by about a third, and this is comparable to providing clean water in low income areas.
simplification: Interventions that promote hand washing can reduce diarrhoea episodes by about 1/3, and this is comparable to providing clean water in low income areas.

original: 48% of reductions in diarrhoea episodes can be associated with hand washing with soap.Hand washing with soap is the single most effective and inexpensive way to prevent diarrhea and acute respiratory infections (ARI), as automatic behavior performed in homes, schools, and communities worldwide.
simplification: 48% of reductions in diarrhoea episodes can be associated with hand washing with soap. Hand washing with soap is the most effective and inexpensive way to prevent diarrhea and acute respiratory infections (ARI), as automatic behavior performed in homes, schools, and communities worldwide.

original: Pneumonia, a major ARI, is the number one cause of mortality among children under five years old, taking the lives of an estimated 1.8 million children per year.
simplification: Pneumonia, a major ARI, is the number one cause of death among children under five years old, taking the lives of an estimated 1.8 million children per year.

original: Diarrhea and pneumonia together account for almost 3.5 million child deaths annually.
simplification: Diarrhea and pneumonia together account for almost 3.5 million child deaths annually.

original: According to UNICEF, turning hand washing with soap before eating and after using the toilet into an ingrained habit can save more lives than any single vaccine or medical intervention, cutting deaths from diarrhea by almost half and deaths from acute respiratory infections by one-quarter.
simplification: According to UNICEF, turning hand washing with soap before eating and after using the toilet into an ingrained habit can save more lives than any single vaccine or medical intervention. Hand washing with soap can reduce deaths from diarrhea by almost half, and deaths from acute respiratory infections by one-quarter.

original: Hand washing is usually integrated together with other sanitation interventions as part of water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH) programmes.
simplification: Hand washing is usually combined with other sanitation interventions as part of water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH) programmes.

original: Hand washing also protects against impetigo which is transmitted through direct physical contact.
simplification: Hand washing also protects against impetigo, which is transmitted through direct physical contact.

original: A small detrimental effect of hand washing is that frequent hand washing can lead to skin damage due to drying of the skin.
simplification: Frequent hand washing can lead to skin damage due to drying of the skin.

original: A 2012 Danish study found that excessive hand washing can lead to an itchy, flaky skin condition known as hand eczema or hand dermatitis, which is especially common among health-care workers.
simplification: A 2012 study found that excessive hand washing can lead to an itchy, flaky skin condition known as hand eczema or hand dermatitis. It is especially common among health-care workers.

original: Too frequent hand washing is also seen as one of the symptoms of obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD).
simplification: Excessive hand washing is also seen as one of the symptoms of obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD).

original: There are five critical times during the day where washing hands with soap is important to reduce fecal-oral transmission of disease: after using the bathroom (urination, defecation), after cleaning a child's bottom (changing nappies), before feeding a child, before eating and before/after preparing food or handling raw meat, fish, or poultry.
simplification: There are 5 critical times during the day where washing hands with soap is important to reduce fecal-oral transmission of disease: after using the bathroom, after changing a child's nappies, before feeding a child, before eating and before/after preparing food or handling raw meat, fish, or poultry.

original: Other occasions when correct handwashing technique should be practiced in order to prevent the transmission of disease include before and after treating a cut or wound; after sneezing, coughing, or blowing your nose; after touching animal waste or handling animals; and after touching garbage.
simplification: Other times when correct handwashing technique should be practiced in order to prevent the transmission of disease include before and after treating a cut or wound; after sneezing, coughing, or blowing your nose; after touching animal waste or handling animals; and after touching garbage.

original: In many countries, there is a low rate of hand washing with soap.
simplification: There is a low rate of hand washing with soap in many countries.

original: A study of hand washing in 54 countries in 2015 found that on average, 38.7% of households practiced hand washing with soap.A 2014 study showed that Saudi Arabia had the highest rate of 97 percent; the United States near the middle with 77 percent; and China with the lowest rate of 23 percent.Several behaviour change methodologies now exist to increase uptake of the behaviour of hand washing with soap at the critical times.Group hand washing for school children at set times of the day is one option in developing countries to engrain hand washing in children's behaviors.
simplification: A study of hand washing in 54 countries in 2015 found that on average, 38.7% of households practiced hand washing with soap. A 2014 study showed that Saudi Arabia had the highest rate of 97%, the United States near the middle with 77%; and China with the lowest rate of 23%. Several behaviour change procedures now exist to increase the amount of people handwashing with soap at the critical times. Group hand washing for school children at set times of the day is one option in developing countries to engrain hand washing in children's behaviors.

original: The "Essential Health Care Program" implemented by the Department of Education in the Philippines is an example of at scale action to promote children's health and education.
simplification: The "Essential Health Care Program", implemented by the Department of Education in the Philippines, is an example of action to promote children's health and education.

original: Deworming twice a year, supplemented with washing hands daily with soap, brushing teeth daily with fluoride, is at the core of this national program.
simplification: Deworming twice a year, washing hands daily with soap, and brushing teeth daily with fluoride is at the core of this national program.

original: It has also been successfully implemented in Indonesia.
simplification: It has also been successfully implemented in Indonesia.

original: Removal of microorganisms from skin is enhanced by the addition of soaps or detergents to water.
simplification: Removal of microorganisms from skin is improved by the addition of soaps or detergents to water.

original: The main action of soaps and detergents is to reduce barriers to solution, and increase solubility.
simplification: The main action of soaps and detergents is to reduce barriers to solution, and increase solubility.

original: Water alone is an inefficient skin cleanser because fats and proteins, which are components of organic soil, are not readily dissolved in water.
simplification: Water alone is not a good skin cleanser because fats and proteins, which are components of organic soil, are not readily dissolved in water.

original: Cleansing is, however, aided by a reasonable flow of water..
simplification: Cleansing is, however, helped by a reasonable flow of water..

original: Solid soap, because of its reusable nature, may hold bacteria acquired from previous uses.
simplification: Solid soap, because of its reusable nature, may hold bacteria from previous uses.

original: A small number of studies which have looked at the bacterial transfer from contaminated solid soap have concluded transfer is unlikely as the bacteria are rinsed off with the foam.
simplification: A few studies which have looked at the bacterial transfer from contaminated solid soap have concluded transfer is unlikely as the bacteria are rinsed off with the foam.

original: The CDC still states "liquid soap with hands-free controls for dispensing is preferable".
simplification: The CDC says that "liquid soap with hands-free controls for dispensing is preferable".

original: Antibacterial soaps have been heavily promoted to a health-conscious public.
simplification: Antibacterial soaps have been promoted to a health-conscious public.

original: To date, there is no evidence that using recommended antiseptics or disinfectants selects for antibiotic-resistant organisms in nature.
simplification: To date, there is no evidence that using recommended antiseptics or disinfectants selects for antibiotic-resistant organisms in nature.

original: However, antibacterial soaps contain common antibacterial agents such as triclosan, which has an extensive list of resistant strains of organisms.
simplification: Antibacterial soaps contain common antibacterial agents such as triclosan, which has a long list of resistant strains of organisms.

original: So, even if antibiotic resistant strains aren't selected for by antibacterial soaps, they might not be as effective as they are marketed to be.
simplification: Antibacterial soaps might not be as effective as they are marketed to be, even if antibiotic resistant strains aren't selected.

original: Besides the surfactant and skin-protecting agent, the sophisticated formulations may contain acids (acetic acid, ascorbic acid, lactic acid) as pH regulator, antimicrobially active benzoic acid and further skin conditioners (aloe vera, vitamins, menthol, plant extracts).A comprehensive analysis from the University of Oregon School of Public Health indicated that plain soaps are as effective as consumer-grade anti-bacterial soaps containing triclosan in preventing illness and removing bacteria from the hands.
simplification: The complicated formulations may contain acids (acetic acid, ascorbic acid, lactic acid) as pH regulator, antimicrobially active benzoic acid and skin conditioners (aloe vera, vitamins, menthol, plant extracts). A comprehensive analysis from the University of Oregon School of Public Health indicated that plain soaps are as effective as consumer-grade anti-bacterial soaps containing triclosan in preventing illness and removing bacteria from the hands.

original: Hot water that is comfortable for washing hands is not hot enough to kill bacteria.
simplification: Hot water that is comfortable for washing hands is not hot enough to kill bacteria.

original: Bacteria grow much faster at body temperature (37 °C).
simplification: Bacteria grow much faster at body temperature (37 °C).

original: However, warm, soapy water is more effective than cold, soapy water at removing natural oils which hold soils and bacteria.
simplification: Warm and soapy water is more effective than cold and soapy water at removing natural oils, which hold soils and bacteria.

original: Contrary to popular belief however, scientific studies have shown that using warm water has no effect on reducing the microbial load on hands.
simplification: However, scientific studies have shown that using warm water has no effect on reducing the amount of microbes on the hands.

original: A hand sanitizer or hand antiseptic is a non-water-based hand hygiene agent.
simplification: A hand sanitizer, or hand antiseptic, is a non-water-based hand hygiene agent.

original: In the late 1990s and early part of the 21st century, alcohol rub non-water-based hand hygiene agents (also known as alcohol-based hand rubs, antiseptic hand rubs, or hand sanitizers) began to gain popularity.
simplification: In the late 1990s and early 2000s, alcohol rub non-water-based hand hygiene agents began to gain popularity.

original: Most are based on isopropyl alcohol or ethanol formulated together with a thickening agent such as Carbomer (polymer of acrylic acid) into a gel, or a humectant such as glycerin into a liquid, or foam for ease of use and to decrease the drying effect of the alcohol.
simplification: Most are based on isopropyl alcohol or ethanol formulated together with a thickening agent such as Carbomer (polymer of acrylic acid) into a gel, or a humectant such as glycerin into a liquid, or foam for ease of use and to decrease the drying effect of the alcohol.

original: Adding diluted hydrogen-peroxide increases further  the antimicrobial activity.Hand sanitizers containing a minimum of 60 to 95% alcohol are efficient germ killers.
simplification: Adding diluted hydrogen-peroxide increases the antimicrobial activity. Hand sanitizers containing a minimum of 60 to 95% alcohol are efficient germ killers.

original: Alcohol rub sanitizers kill bacteria, multi-drug resistant bacteria (MRSA and VRE), tuberculosis, and some viruses (including HIV, herpes, RSV, rhinovirus, vaccinia, influenza, and hepatitis) and fungi.
simplification: Alcohol rub sanitizers kill bacteria, multi-drug resistant bacteria (MRSA and VRE), tuberculosis, some viruses, and fungi.

original: Alcohol rub sanitizers containing 70% alcohol kill 99.97% (3.5 log reduction, similar to 35 decibel reduction) of the bacteria on hands 30 seconds after application and 99.99% to 99.999% (4 to 5 log reduction) of the bacteria on hands 1 minute after application.Hand sanitizers are most effective against bacteria and less effective against some viruses.
simplification: Alcohol rub sanitizers containing 70% alcohol kill 99.97% of the bacteria on hands 30 seconds after application. They kill 99.99% to 99.999% of the bacteria on hands 1 minute after application. Hand sanitizers are most effective against bacteria and less effective against some viruses.

original: Alcohol-based hand sanitizers are almost entirely ineffective against norovirus (or Norwalk) type viruses, the most common cause of contagious gastroenteritis.Enough hand antiseptic or alcohol rub must be used to thoroughly wet or cover both hands.
simplification: Alcohol-based hand sanitizers are almost entirely ineffective against norovirus (or Norwalk) type viruses, the most common cause of contagious stomach infection. Enough hand antiseptic or alcohol rub must be used to thoroughly wet or cover both hands.

original: The front and back of both hands and between and the ends of all fingers are rubbed for approximately 30 seconds until the liquid, foam or gel is dry.
simplification: The front and back of both hands and between and the ends of all fingers are rubbed for around 30 seconds until the liquid, foam or gel is dry.

original: Finger tips must be washed well too, rubbing them in both palms.The US Center for Disease Control and Prevention recommends hand washing over hand sanitizer rubs, particularly when hands are visibly dirty.
simplification: Finger tips must be washed well too, rubbing them in both palms.The US Center for Disease Control and Prevention recommends hand washing over hand sanitizer rubs, particularly when hands are visibly dirty.

original: The increasing use of these agents is based on their ease of use and rapid killing activity against micro-organisms; however, they should not serve as a replacement for proper hand washing unless soap and water are unavailable.
simplification: The increasing use of these agents is based on their ease of use and rapid killing activity against micro-organisms. However, they should not be a replacement for proper hand washing unless soap and water are unavailable.

original: Frequent use of alcohol-based hand sanitizers can cause dry skin unless emollients and/or skin moisturizers are added to the formula.
simplification: Frequent use of alcohol-based hand sanitizers can cause dry skin, unless emollients and/or skin moisturizers are added to the formula.

original: The drying effect of alcohol can be reduced or eliminated by adding glycerin and/or other emollients to the formula.
simplification: The drying effect of alcohol can be reduced or eliminated by adding glycerin and/or other emollients to the formula.

original: In clinical trials, alcohol-based hand sanitizers containing emollients caused substantially less skin irritation and dryness than soaps or antimicrobial detergents.
simplification: In clinical trials, alcohol-based hand sanitizers containing emollients caused less skin irritation and dryness than soaps or antimicrobial detergents.

original: Allergic contact dermatitis, contact urticaria syndrome or hypersensitivity to alcohol or additives present in alcohol hand rubs rarely occur.
simplification: Allergic contact dermatitis, contact urticaria syndrome or hypersensitivity to alcohol or additives present in alcohol hand rubs are rare.

original: The lower tendency to induce irritant contact dermatitis became an attraction as compared to soap and water hand washing.
simplification: The lower likelihood to induce irritant contact dermatitis became an attraction as compared to soap and water hand washing.

original: Despite their effectiveness, non-water agents do not cleanse the hands of organic material, but simply disinfect them.
simplification: Non-water agents do not cleanse the hands of organic material, but simply disinfect them.

original: It is for this reason that hand sanitizers are not as effective as soap and water at preventing the spread of many pathogens, since the pathogens still remain on the hands.
simplification: It is for this reason that hand sanitizers are not as effective as soap and water at preventing the spread of many pathogens, since the pathogens still remain on the hands.

original: Alcohol-free hand sanitizer efficacy is heavily dependent on the ingredients and formulation, and historically has significantly under-performed alcohol and alcohol rubs.
simplification: Alcohol-free hand sanitizer efficacy is heavily dependent on the ingredients and formulation, and has significantly under-performed alcohol and alcohol rubs.

original: More recently, formulations that use benzalkonium chloride have been shown to have persistent and cumulative antimicrobial activity after application, unlike alcohol, which has been shown to decrease in efficacy after repeated use, probably due to progressive adverse skin reactions.
simplification: Recently, formulations that use benzalkonium chloride have been shown to have continual and cumulative antimicrobial activity after application. Alcohol has been shown to decrease in efficacy after repeated use, probably due to progressive adverse skin reactions.

original: Many people in low-income communities cannot afford soap and use ash or soil instead.
simplification: Many people in low-income communities cannot afford soap and use ash or soil instead.

original: Ash or soil may be more effective than water alone, but may be less effective than soap.
simplification: Ash or soil may be more effective than water alone, but may be less effective than soap.

original: One concern is that if the soil or ash is contaminated with microorganisms it may increase the spread of disease rather than decrease it.
simplification: If the soil or ash is contaminated with microorganisms, it may increase the spread of disease rather than decrease it.

original: Like soap, ash is also a disinfecting agent because in contact with water, it forms an alkaline solution.
simplification: Ash is also a disinfecting agent because in contact with water, it forms an alkaline solution.

original: WHO recommended ash or sand as alternative to soap when soap is not available.
simplification: WHO recommended ash or sand as alternative to soap when soap is not available.

original: Correct handwashing technique recommended by the US Centers for Disease Control  for prevention of transmission of disease includes the following steps:
simplification: Correct handwashing technique, recommended by the US Centers for Disease Control, for prevention of transmission of disease includes the following steps:

original: Wet hands with warm or cold running water.
simplification: Wet hands with running water.

original: Running water is recommended because standing basins may be contaminated, while the temperature of the water does not seem to make a difference.
simplification: Running water is recommended because still water may be contaminated, while the temperature of the water does not seem to make a difference.

original: Lather hands by rubbing them with a generous amount of soap, including the backs of hands, between fingers, and under nails.
simplification: Cover hands in soap by rubbing them, including the backs of hands, between fingers, and under nails.

original: Soap lifts germs from the skin, and studies show that people tend to wash their hands more thoroughly when soap is used rather than water alone.
simplification: Soap lifts germs from the skin, and studies show that people tend to wash their hands more thoroughly when soap is used rather than water alone.

original: Scrub for at least 20 seconds.
simplification: Scrub for at least 20 seconds.

original: Scrubbing creates friction, which helps remove germs from skin, and scrubbing for longer periods removes more germs.
simplification: Scrubbing creates friction, which helps remove germs from skin. Scrubbing for longer periods removes more germs.

original: Rinse well under running water.
simplification: Rinse well under running water.

original: Rinsing in a basin can recontaminate hands.
simplification: Rinsing in a basin can recontaminate hands.

original: Dry with a clean towel or allow to air dry.
simplification: Dry with a clean towel or allow to air dry.

original: Wet and moist hands are more easily recontaminated.The most commonly missed areas are the thumb, the wrist, the areas between the fingers, and under fingernails.
simplification: Wet or damp hands are more easily recontaminated.The most commonly missed areas are the thumb, the wrist, the areas between the fingers, and under fingernails.

original: Artificial nails and chipped nail polish may harbor microorganisms.
simplification: Artificial nails and chipped nail polish may hold microorganisms.

original: Moisturizing lotion is often recommended to keep the hands from drying out; dry skin can lead to skin damage which can increase the risk for the transmission of infection.
simplification: Moisturizing lotion is often recommended to keep the hands from drying out; dry skin can lead to skin damage, which can increase the risk for infection.

original: Various low-cost options can be made to facilitate hand washing where tap-water and/or soap is not available e.g. pouring water from a hanging jerrycan or gourd with suitable holes and/or using ash if needed in developing countries.In situations with limited water supply (such as schools or rural areas in developing countries), there are water-conserving solutions, such as "tippy-taps" and other low-cost options.
simplification: Various low-cost options can be made to facilitate hand washing where tap-water and/or soap is not available e.g. pouring water from a hanging jerrycan or gourd with suitable holes and/or using ash if needed in developing countries. In situations with limited water supply (such as schools or rural areas in developing countries), there are water-conserving solutions, such as "tippy-taps" and other low-cost options.

original: A tippy-tap is a simple technology using a jug suspended by a rope, and a foot-operated lever to pour a small amount of water over the hands and a bar of soap.
simplification: A tippy-tap is a simple technology using a jug suspended by a rope, and a foot-operated lever to pour a small amount of water over the hands and a bar of soap.

original: Effective drying of the hands is an essential part of the hand hygiene process, but there is some debate over the most effective form of drying in public washrooms.
simplification: Effective drying of the hands is an essential part of the hand hygiene process, but there is some debate over the most effective form of drying in public washrooms.

original: A growing volume of research suggests paper towels are much more hygienic than the electric hand dryers found in many washrooms.
simplification: A growing amount of research suggests paper towels are much more hygienic than the electric hand dryers found in many washrooms.

original: In 2008, a study was conducted by the University of Westminster, London, and sponsored by the paper-towel industry the European Tissue Symposium, to compare the levels of hygiene offered by paper towels, warm-air hand dryers and the more modern jet-air hand dryers.
simplification: A study was conducted by the University of Westminster, London, and sponsored by the paper-towel industry the European Tissue Symposium, to compare the levels of hygiene offered by paper towels, warm-air hand dryers and the more modern jet-air hand dryers.

original: After washing and drying hands with the warm-air dryer, the total number of bacteria was found to increase on average on the finger pads by 194% and on the palms by 254%.
simplification: After washing and drying hands with the warm-air dryer, the total number of bacteria was found to increase on average on the finger pads by 194% and on the palms by 254%.

original: Drying with the jet-air dryer resulted in an increase on average of the total number of bacteria on the finger pads by 42% and on the palms by 15%.
simplification: Drying with the jet-air dryer caused an average increase in the total number of bacteria on the finger pads by 42% and on the palms by 15%.

original: After washing and drying hands with a paper towel, the total number of bacteria was reduced on average on the finger pads by up to 76% and on the palms by up to 77%.The scientists also carried out tests to establish whether there was the potential for cross contamination of other washroom users and the washroom environment as a result of each type of drying method.
simplification: After washing and drying hands with a paper towel, the total number of bacteria was reduced on average on the finger pads by up to 76% and on the palms by up to 77%. The scientists also carried out tests to establish whether there was the potential for cross contamination of other washroom users and the washroom environment as a result of each type of drying method.

original: The jet-air dryer, which blows air out of the unit at claimed speeds of 180 m/s (650 km/h; 400 mph), was capable of blowing micro-organisms from the hands and the unit and potentially contaminating other washroom users and the washroom environment up to 2 metres away.
simplification: The jet-air dryer, which blows air out of the unit at claimed speeds of 400 mph, was capable of blowing micro-organisms from the hands and the unit. This could potentially contaminate other washroom users and the environment up to 2 metres away.

original: Use of a warm-air hand dryer spread micro-organisms up to 0.25 metres from the dryer.
simplification: Use of a warm-air hand dryer spread micro-organisms up to 0.25 metres from the dryer.

original: Paper towels showed no significant spread of micro-organisms.In 2005, in a study conducted by TÜV Produkt und Umwelt, different hand drying methods were evaluated.
simplification: Paper towels showed no significant spread of micro-organisms. In a study conducted by TÜV Produkt und Umwelt, different hand drying methods were evaluated.

original: The following changes in the bacterial count after drying the hands were observed:
simplification: The following changes in the amount of bacteria after drying the hands were observed:

original: Many different hand dryer manufacturers exist, and hand driers have been compared against drying with paper towels.
simplification: Different hand dryer manufacturers exist, and hand driers have been compared against drying with paper towels.

original: Hand washing using hand sanitizing wipes is an alternative during traveling in the absence of soap and water.
simplification: Hand washing using hand sanitizing wipes is an alternative in the absence of soap and water.

original: Alcohol-based hand sanitizer should contain at least 60% alcohol.
simplification: Alcohol-based hand sanitizer should contain at least 60% alcohol.

original: Medical hand-washing became mandatory long after Hungarian physician Ignaz Semmelweis discovered its effectiveness (in 1846) in preventing disease in a hospital environment.
simplification: Medical hand-washing became mandatory long after physician Ignaz Semmelweis discovered its effectiveness  in preventing disease in a hospital environment.

original: There are electronic devices that provide feedback to remind hospital staff to wash their hands when they forget.
simplification: There are devices that provide feedback to remind hospital staff to wash their hands when they forget.

original: One study has found decreased infection rates with their use.
simplification: One study has found less infection rates with their use.

original: Medical hand-washing is for a minimum of 15 seconds, using generous amounts of soap and water or gel to lather and rub each part of the hands.
simplification: Medical hand-washing is for a minimum of 15 seconds. Generous amounts of soap and water or gel are used to lather and rub each part of the hands.

original: Hands should be rubbed together with digits interlocking.
simplification: Hands should be rubbed together with fingers interlocking.

original: If there is debris under fingernails, a bristle brush may be used to remove it.
simplification: If there is debris under fingernails, a brush may be used to remove it.

original: Since germs may remain in the water on the hands, it is important to rinse well and wipe dry with a clean towel.
simplification: Germs may remain in the water on the hands, so it is important to rinse well and wipe dry with a clean towel.

original: After drying, the paper towel should be used to turn off the water (and open any exit door if necessary).
simplification: After drying, the paper towel should be used to turn off the water and open any exit door if necessary.

original: This avoids re-contaminating the hands from those surfaces.
simplification: This avoids re-contaminating the hands from those surfaces.

original: The purpose of hand-washing in the health-care setting is to remove pathogenic microorganisms ("germs") and avoid transmitting them.
