simplification: Maciej Boni of Penn State University said, "Left alone, infectious outbreaks typically stop spreading as quickly and then start to slow down when the disease runs out of people to inect.

original: But it's almost impossible to make any sensible projection right now about when that will be".
simplification: But it's impossible to make any prediction when that will be at the moment".

original: The Chinese government's senior medical adviser Zhong Nanshan argued that "it could be over by June" if all countries can be mobilized to follow the WHO's advice on measures to stop the spread of the virus.
simplification: The Chinese government's senior medical adviser Zhong Nanshan said "it could be over by June" if all countries follow the WHO's advice on measures to stop the spread of the virus.

original: On 17 March, Adam Kucharski of the London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine stated that SARS-CoV-2 "is going to be circulating, potentially for a year or two".
simplification: On 17 March, Adam Kucharski of the London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine stated that SARS-CoV-2 "is going to be around, maybe for a year or two".

original: Genetic analysis has revealed that the coronavirus genetically clusters with the genus Betacoronavirus, in subgenus Sarbecovirus (lineage B) together with two bat-derived strains.
simplification: Genetic analysis has revealed that the coronavirus is similar to the genus Betacoronavirus, in subgenus Sarbecovirus (lineage B) together with two bat-derived strains.

original: Containment is undertaken in the early stages of the outbreak and aims to trace and isolate those infected as well as introduce other measures of infection control and vaccinations to stop the disease from spreading to the rest of the population.
simplification: Containment happens early in an outbreak and trys to find infected people and stoop them spreading the virus. Containmant also introduces other measures to stop the disease from spreading.

original: The ECDC and the European regional office of the WHO have issued guidelines for hospitals and primary healthcare services for shifting of resources at multiple levels, including focusing laboratory services towards COVID-19 testing, cancelling elective procedures whenever possible, separating and isolating COVID-19 positive patients, and increasing intensive care capabilities by training personnel and increasing the number of available ventilators and beds.
simplification: The ECDC and the European regional office of the WHO have issued guidelines for hospitals for moving resources. These include focusing on COVID-19 testing, cancelling sugery, keeping COVID-19 positive patients apart from other people, and getting more intensive care ventilators and beds.

original: These were mostly linked to the Huanan Seafood Wholesale Market, which also sold live animals, and one theory is that the virus came from one of these kinds of animals; or, in other words, has a zoonotic origin.A pneumonia cluster of unknown cause was observed on 26 December and treated by the doctor Zhang Jixian in Hubei Provincial Hospital, who informed the Wuhan Jianghan CDC on 27 December.
simplification: These were linked to the Huanan Seafood Wholesale Market. The market sold animals. One theory says the virus came from one of these animals. Viruses that come from animals have a zoonotic origin. Doctors noticed a group of people with breathing difficulties on 26 December . They were treated by the doctor Zhang Jixian in Hubei Provincial Hospital, who told the Wuhan Jianghan CDC on 27 December.

original: Eight of these doctors, including Li Wenliang, were admonished by the police for spreading false rumours, and another, Ai Fen, was reprimanded by her superiors for raising the alarm.
simplification: Eight of these doctors, including Li Wenliang, were punished by the police for lying. Another was reprimanded by her superiors for telling people.

original: Later official data shows that 6,174 people had already developed symptoms by 20 January 2020.As of 26 March, the United States has overtaken China and Italy with the highest number of confirmed cases in the world.As of 9 April 2020, more than 1.61 million cases have been reported worldwide; more than 97,000 people have died and more than 364,000 have recovered.
simplification: Data shows that around 6,000 people had symptoms by 20 January 2020. As of 26 March, the United States has overtaken China and Italy with the highest number of cases in the world. As of 9 April 2020, more than 1.61 million cases have been reported across the world. More than 97,000 people have died and more than 364,000 have recovered.

original: National reactions have included containment measures such as quarantines (known as stay-at-home orders, shelter-in-place orders, or lockdown) and curfews.As of 2 April, nearly 300 million people, or about 90% of the population, are under some form of lockdown in the United States, more than 50 million people are in lockdown in the Philippines, about 59 million people are in lockdown in South Africa, and 1.3 billion people are in lockdown in India.
simplification: Different countries have reacted with quarantines and curfews. Quarantines are also known as stay-at-home orders, shelter-in-place orders, or lockdown. As of 2 April, nearly 300 million people, or about 90% of the population of the United States, are under some form of lockdown. More than 50 million people are in lockdown in the Philippines. About 59 million people are in lockdown in South Africa. 1.3 billion people are in lockdown in India.

original: On 26 March, 1.7 billion people worldwide were under some form of lockdown, which increased to 2.6 billion people two days later—around a third of the world's population.
simplification: On 26 March, 1.7 billion people were in lockdown. This increased to 2.6 billion people two days later. 2.6 billion people is around a third of the world's population.

original: In what has been described as "the largest quarantine in human history", a cordon sanitaire was announced on 23 January stopping travel in and out of Wuhan, which was extended to a total of 15 cities in Hubei, affecting a total of about 57 million people.
simplification: In what has been called "the largest quarantine in human history", a lockdown was announced on 23 January stopping travel in and out of Wuhan. This was extended to a total of 15 cities in Hubei, affecting a total of about 57 million people.

original: In addition to newly constructed hospitals, China also converted 14 other facilities in Wuhan, such as convention centers and stadiums, into temporary hospitals.On 26 January, the government instituted further measures to contain the COVID-19 outbreak, including issuing health declarations for travellers and extending the Spring Festival holiday.
simplification: China converted 14 facilities in Wuhan into temporary hospitals. On 26 January, the government created further measures to contain the COVID-19 outbreak. These included health declarations for travellers and making the Spring Festival holiday longer.

original: Control of public movement was applied in many cities, and it has been estimated that about 760 million people (more than half the population) faced some form of outdoor restriction.After the outbreak entered its global phase in March, Chinese authorities took strict measures to prevent the virus from "importing" from other countries.
simplification: About half the population of China weren't allowed to move around in many cities. After the virus spread around the world, Chinese authorities took measures to stop the virus coming back from other countries.

original: For example, Beijing has imposed a 14-day mandatory quarantine for all international travellers entering the city.On 23 March, mainland China only one case had transmitted domestically in the five days prior, in this instance via a traveller returning to Guangzhou from Istanbul.
simplification: Beijing asks people coming from other countries to quarantine for  14 days. On 23 March, only one case was from China in the five days prior. Thhe case came from someone returning from Istanbul.

original: On 24 March 2020, Chinese Premier Li Keqiang reported that the spread of domestically transmitted cases has been basically blocked and the outbreak has been controlled in China.
simplification: On 24 March 2020, Chinese Premier Li Keqiang said that the spread of cases has stopped in China.

original: The same day travel restrictions were eased in Hubei, apart from Wuhan, two months after the lockdown was imposed.The Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs announced on 26 March 2020 that entry for visa or residence permit holders would be suspended from 28 March onwards, with no specific details on when this policy will end.
simplification: The same day travel restrictions were eased in most of Hubei. Restrictions were not eased in Wuhan. This happened two months after lockdown was imposed. On 26 March 2020, the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs said that entry would be suspended for visa or residence permit holders. They did not say when this will end.

original: The Chinese government encouraged businesses and factories to re-open on 30 March, and provided monetary stimulus packages for firms.The State Council declared a day of mourning to begin with a national three-minute moment of silence on 10:00 4 April, coinciding with Qingming Festival, although the central government asked families to pay their respects online in observance of physical distancing as to avoid a renewed COVID-19 outbreak.
simplification: The Chinese government asked businesses to re-open on 30 March. They provided money to businesses. The State Council said there would be a day of mourning on the 4th April. This would begin with a national three-minute silence at 10:00. This is at the same time as Qingming Festival. The central government asked families to pay their respects online to avoid a new COVID-19 outbreak.

original: The nation's health agency reported a significant increase in confirmed cases on 20 February, largely attributed to a gathering in Daegu of a new religious movement known as the Shincheonji Church of Jesus.
simplification: The nation's health agency reported an increase in cases on 20 February. The increase was attributed to a new religious movement known as the Shincheonji Church of Jesus.

original: Shincheonji devotees visiting Daegu from Wuhan were suspected to be the origin of the outbreak.
simplification: Shincheonji devotees visiting Daegu from Wuhan were suspected to be the origin of the outbreak.

original: As of 22 February, among 9,336 followers of the church, 1,261 or about 13% reported symptoms.South Korea declared the highest level of alert on 23 February 2020.
simplification: As of 22 February, about 13% of the followers of the church reported symptoms. South Korea declared the highest level of alert on 23 February 2020.

original: On 28 February, more than 2,000 confirmed cases were reported in Korea, rising to 3,150 on 29 February.
simplification: On 28 February, more than 2,000 confirmed cases were reported in Korea, rising to 3,150 on 29 February.

original: As a result, the government received criticism for the apparent lack of speed and intensity in its response to the concerns faced by the public. On March 16, Prime Minister Boris Johnson made an announcement advising against social contact and all non-essential travel, suggesting that people work from home when possible and avoid places like bars, restaurants and theaters.
simplification: The government was criticized for the apparent lack of speed and intensity in its response to concerns faced by the public. On March 16, Prime Minister Boris Johnson made an announcement advising against social contact and all non-essential travel, and suggested that people work from home when possible and avoid public places.

original: On 23 January, in reaction to the central authorities' decision to implement a transportation ban in Wuhan, WHO representative Gauden Galea remarked that while it was "certainly not a recommendation the WHO has made", it was also "a very important indication of the commitment to contain the epidemic in the place where it is most concentrated" and called it "unprecedented in public health history".On 30 January, following confirmation of human-to-human transmission outside China and the increase in the number of cases in other countries, the WHO declared the outbreak a Public Health Emergency of International Concern (PHEIC), the sixth PHEIC since the measure was first invoked during the 2009 swine flu pandemic.
simplification: On 23 January, in reaction to the central authorities' decision to implement a travel ban in Wuhan, WHO representative Gauden Galea remarked that while it was "certainly not a recommendation the WHO has made", it was also "a very important indication of the commitment to contain the epidemic in the place where it is most concentrated" and called it "unprecedented in public health history". On 30 January the WHO declared the outbreak a Public Health Emergency of International Concern (PHEIC). This was because of human-to-human virus spreading outside China and the increase in the number of cases in other countries. It was the sixth PHEIC since the measure was created during the 2009 swine flu pandemic.

original: WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom said that the PHEIC was due to "the risk of global spread, especially to low- and middle-income countries without robust health systems.
simplification: WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom said that the PHEIC was due to "the risk of global spread, especially to low- and middle-income countries without strong health systems.

original: In response to the implementations of travel restrictions, Tedros stated that "there is no reason for measures that unnecessarily interfere with international travel and trade" and that the "WHO doesn't recommend limiting trade and movement."
simplification: Tedros stated "there is no reason for measures that interfere with travel and trade" and that the "WHO doesn't recommend limiting trade and movement."

original: On 5 February, the WHO appealed to the global community for a $675 million contribution to fund strategic preparedness in low-income countries, citing the urgency to support those countries which "do not have the systems in place to detect people who have contracted the virus, even if it were to emerge".
simplification: On 5 February, the WHO asked for $675 million to prepare low-income countries. The WHO said it was urgent to support countries which "do not have the systems in place to detect people who have contracted the virus, even if it were to emerge".

original: Tedros further made statements declaring that "we are only as strong as our weakest link" and urged the international community to "invest today or pay more later".On 11 February, the WHO in a press conference established COVID-19 as the name of the disease.
simplification: Tedros said "we are only as strong as our weakest link" and asked countries to "invest today or pay more later". On 11 February, the WHO named the disease COVID-19.

original: On the same day, Tedros stated that UN Secretary-General António Guterres had agreed to provide the "power of the entire UN system in the response".
simplification: On the same day, Tedros said that UN Secretary-General António Guterres had agreed to provide the "power of the entire UN system in the response".

original: A UN Crisis Management Team was activated as a result, allowing coordination of the entire United Nations response, which the WHO states will allow them to "focus on the health response while the other agencies can bring their expertise to bear on the wider social, economic and developmental implications of the outbreak".
simplification: A UN Crisis Management Team was activated. The crisis coordinated the reesponse of the United Nations. The WHO states this will allow them to "focus on the health response while the other agencies can bring their expertise to bear on the wider social, economic and developmental implications of the outbreak".

original: On 14 February, a WHO-led Joint Mission Team with China was activated to provide international and WHO experts on the ground in China to assist in the domestic management and evaluate "the severity and the transmissibility of the disease" by hosting workshops and meetings with key national-level institutions and to conduct field visits to assess the "impact of response activities at provincial and county levels, including urban and rural settings".On 25 February, the WHO declared that "the world should do more to prepare for a possible coronavirus pandemic," stating that while it was still too early to call it a pandemic, countries should nonetheless be "in a phase of preparedness".
simplification: On 14 February, a team was created to provide experts in China. The team was led by the WHO. The team had experts from Chinaand the rest of the world. The team helped to manage and evaluate "the severity and the transmissibility of the disease". They did this by hosting events with key institutions. The team also conducted visits to find out the "impact of response activities at provincial and county levels, including urban and rural settings". On 25 February, the WHO said "the world should do more to prepare for a possible coronavirus pandemic,". The WHO also said it was too early to call it a pandemic, but countries should prepare.

original: In response to a developing outbreak in Iran, the WHO sent a Joint Mission Team there to assess the situation.On 28 February, WHO officials said that the coronavirus threat assessment at the global level would be raised from "high" to "very high", its highest level of alert and risk assessment.
simplification: In response to a new outbreak in Iran, the WHO sent a team to find  out the situation. On 28 February, WHO officials said that the global threat from coronavirus would be raised from "high" to "very high". Very high is the highest level.

original: Mike Ryan, executive director of the WHO's health emergencies program, warned in a statement that "This is a reality check for every government on the planet: Wake up.
simplification: Mike Ryan warned "This is a reality check for every government on the planet: Wake up. Mike Ryan is the executive director of the WHO's health emergencies program.

original: This virus may be on its way and you need to be ready," urging that the right response measures could help the world avoid "the worst of it".
simplification: This virus may be on its way and you need to be ready," urging that acting right could help avoid "the worst of it".

original: Ryan further stated that the current data did not warrant public health officials to declare a global pandemic, saying that such a declaration would mean "we're essentially accepting that every human on the planet will be exposed to that virus."
simplification: Ryan said the data did not mean it was a global pandemic. He said that would mean "we're essentially accepting that every human on the planet will be exposed to that virus."

original: The U.S. administration of Donald Trump has referred to the coronavirus as "Chinese virus" or "Wuhan virus" saying that China's "censorship supercharged a virus that has now turned into a global pandemic", which has in turn been criticized by some critics as racism and "distract[ing] from his administration's failure to contain the disease".
simplification: Donald Trump has called the coronavirus as "Chinese virus" or "Wuhan virus". They say China's "censorship made virus the virus stronger and turned it into a global pandemic". Some people have said this is racism. They also say it is "distract[ing] from his administration's failure to contain the disease".

original: EU foreign policy chief Josep Borrell warned that there is "a geo-political component including a struggle for influence through spinning and the 'politics of generosity'".
simplification: EU foreign policy chief Josep Borrell said there is "a political component, which includes a struggle for influence through spinning and the 'politics of generosity'".

original: Borrell also said that "China is aggressively pushing the message that, unlike the US, it is a responsible and reliable partner."
simplification: Borrell also said that "China is pushing the message that it is responsible, unlike the US."

original: Italy's La Stampa newspaper cited an anonymous "high-level political source" that 80 percent of Russia's aid was "useless or of little use to Italy".
simplification: La Stampa is a newspaper in Italy. An anonymous "high-level political source" said that 80 percent of Russia's aid was "not useful to Italy".

original: The President of Lombardy, Attilio Fontana, and Italian Foreign Minister Luigi Di Maio dismissed the media reports and expressed their gratitude.
simplification: Attilio Fontana is the President of Lombardy.  Luigi Di Maio is the Italian Foreign Minister. They both denied the reports and gave  their thanks.

original: Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said that "when offering assistance to US colleagues, [Putin] assumes that when US manufacturers of medical equipment and materials gain momentum, they will also be able to reciprocate if necessary."
simplification: Dmitry Peskov is the Kremlin spokesman. He said that "when helping US colleagues, Putin assumes that the US will help him if needed."

original: The planned NATO "Defender 2020" military exercise in Germany, Poland, and the Baltic states, the largest NATO war exercise since the end of the Cold War, will be held on a reduced scale.
simplification: NATO "Defender 2020" is a planned military exercise in Germany, Poland, and the Baltic states. It is the largest NATO war exercise since the end of the Cold War. It will be smaller than normal.

original: The Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament's general secretary Kate Hudson criticized the Defender 2020 exercise: "In the current public-health crisis, it jeopardizes the lives not only of the troops from the US and the many European countries participating but the inhabitants of the countries in which they are operating."The Iranian government has been heavily affected by the virus, with around two dozen parliament members infected as well as fifteen other current or former political figures.
simplification: Kate Hudson is The Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament's general secretary. She criticized the Defender 2020 exercise: "In the current crisis, it risks the lives of troops as well as people in the countries they are in." The Iranian government has been heavily affected by the virus. Around two dozen parliament members are infected. Fifteen other current or former political figures are also infected.

original: Iran's President Hassan Rouhani wrote a public letter to world leaders asking for help on 14 March 2020, saying that his country is struggling to fight the outbreak due to lack of access to international markets as a result of the United States sanctions against Iran.The outbreak has prompted calls for the United States to adopt social policies common in other wealthy countries, including universal health care, universal child care, paid family leave, and higher levels of funding for public health.
simplification: Hassan Rouhani is President of Iran. He wrote a public letter to world leaders on 14 March 2020. His letter said that his country is struggling to fight the outbreak because of sanctions. People in The United States have called for  social policies like those in other wealthy countries. These include free health care, free child care, paid leave, and more money for public health.

original: Political analysts anticipated it may negatively affect Donald Trump's chances of re-election in the 2020 presidential election.Diplomatic relations between Japan and South Korea worsened due to the pandemic.
simplification: Experts thought it may harm Donald Trump's chances of being elected again in 2020. Diplomatic relations between Japan and South Korea became worse due to the pandemic.

original: South Korea criticized Japan's "ambiguous and passive quarantine efforts" after Japan announced anybody coming from South Korea will be placed in two weeks' quarantine at government-designated sites.
simplification: South Korea criticized Japan's "ambiguous and passive quarantine efforts". This happened after Japan said that anybody coming from South Korea will be placed in two weeks' quarantine.

original: Emerging infectious disease – Infectious disease of emerging pathogen, often novel in its outbreak range or transmission mode
simplification: Emerging infectious disease – a disease in a new area or with a new way of spreading.

original: Globalization and disease – Overview of globalization and disease transmission
simplification: Globalization and disease – Summary of globalization and disease spreading

original: List of epidemics and pandemics – A list of death tolls due to infectious disease
simplification: List of epidemics and pandemics – A list of death tolls due to infectious disease

original: Wildlife smuggling and zoonoses – Health risks associated with the trade in exotic wildlife
simplification: Wildlife smuggling and diseases caught from animals – Health risks associated with the trade in exotic wildlife

original: Typical features on CT include bilateral multilobar ground-glass opacificities with a peripheral, asymmetric and posterior distribution.
simplification: Typical features on scans include misty patches on the lungs.

original: Commercial devices can measure and validate hand hygiene, if demonstration of regulatory compliance is required.
simplification: Sshop-bought devices can measure clean hands. This can be used if you need to show you followed the rules.

original: They also outline controls necessary to address those risks, and contingency plans for situations that may arise as a result of outbreaks.
simplification: They also give controls necessary to address risks, and plans for situations that may come as a result of outbreaks.

original: These become very high-risk jobs if workers perform aerosol-generating procedures on patients with confirmed or suspected COVID-19 diagnoses or if they collect or handle samples from these patients.
simplification: These become very high-risk jobs if workers perform aerosol-generating procedures on patients with confirmed or suspected COVID-19 diagnoses, or if they collect or handle their samples.

original: Given that the global supply of PPE is insufficient, WHO recommends minimizing the need for PPE through telemedicine, physical barriers such as clear windows, allowing only those involved in direct care to enter a room with a COVID-19 patient, using only the PPE necessary for the specific task, continuing use of the same respirator without removing it while caring for multiple patients with the same diagnosis, monitoring and coordinating the PPE supply chain, and discouraging the use of masks for asymptomatic individuals.
simplification: Because the global supply of PPE is insufficient, WHO recommends minimizing the need for PPE. This can be done through video calls, screens, letting fewer people enter a room with a COVID-19 patient, using only the PPE necessary, continuing use of the same respirator without removing it while caring for multiple patients with the same diagnosis, monitoring and coordinating the PPE supply chain, and discouraging the use of masks for asymptomatic individuals.

original: Katherine, the CRT (Amanda K, Amy V, Bryan J, Doreen D, Gregory V, Jaime V, Joel L, Lynette L, Ryan M, and Tony S), and the rest of the Leadership Team (Grant I, Heather W, Jaime V, Janeen U, Lisa S, Robyn A, Ryan M, and Toby N).
simplification: Katherine, the CRT (Amanda K, Amy V, Bryan J, Doreen D, Gregory V, Jaime V, Joel L, Lynette L, Ryan M, and Tony S), and the rest of the Leadership Team (Grant I, Heather W, Jaime V, Janeen U, Lisa S, Robyn A, Ryan M, and Toby N).

original: Obtaining cumulative number and cumulative incidence of COVID-19 cases
simplification: To obtain the total number of cases and predict the risk of getting COVID-19.

original: At the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC), the notified COVID-19 case counts in each country worldwide, obtained from only official sources such as the countries’ Ministry of Health, national and regional health authorities and the WHO, are updated each day at 8:00 a.m.
simplification: The European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) updates the COVID-19 counts in each country worldwide at 8:00 am each day. The update is from official sources such as the countries' Ministry of Health, national and regional health authorities and WHO.

original: These data were used for assessing the trends of COVID-19 in EU/EEA and the UK, and comparing them to that in Italy.
simplification: These data were used to analyse the trends of COVID in the EU/EEA and the UK. The trends were compared against Italy.

original: As a proxy of the prevalence of active COVID-19 cases, we calculated the 14-day truncated cumulative incidence of COVID-19 cases, thus taking into account the natural course of COVID-19, in each EU/EEA country and the UK, during the 1 January–15 March 2020 period.
simplification: The cumulative incidence of COVID-19 over 14 days were calculated to obtain a representation of the frequency of active COVID-19 cases. We took the natural course of COVID-19 into account in each EU/EEA country and the UK during the 1 January -15 March 2020 period.

original: We also presented the cumulative number of notified cases of each country as at 15 March 2020 8:00 a.m. compared with that of Italy for the 31 January–15 March 2020 period.
simplification: We presented the total number of reported cases of each country compared to Italy for the period of 31 January and 15 March 2020.

original: Trends of COVID-19 in EU/EEA countries and the UK
simplification: The current situation of COVID-19 in EU/EEA and the UK.

original: The trends in the 14-day truncated cumulative incidence of COVID-19 cases in EU/EEA countries and the UK generally followed that of Hubei Province (China) (Figure 1).
simplification: Figure 1 shows the risk of being infected with COVID-19 in the EU/EEA countries and the UK in 14 days. It was similar to the trend in Hubei Province (China).

original: For the EU/EEA and the UK overall, the cumulative incidence of COVID-19 started to increase around 21 February and then increased sharply around 28 February 2020 (Supplementary material).
simplification: The cumulative incidence COVID-19 started to grow in the EU/EEA and the UK overall. It started to increase around 21 February and then shot up around 28 February 2020.

original: This was mostly driven by the rapid increase in the number of reported cases from Italy, but all other EU/EEA countries and the UK showed similar increasing trends of the cumulative incidence of COVID-19 (Supplementary material).
simplification: This was mostly driven by the sharp increase in the number of reported cases from Italy. A similar rise in the cumulative incidence of COVID-19 was seen in all other EU/EEA countries and the UK.

original: Figure 2 shows the cumulative number of COVID-19 cases, in EU/EEA countries and the UK compared with that in Italy for the 31 January–15 March 2020 period.
simplification: Figure 2 shows the collective number of COVID-19 cases in the EU/EEA and the UK, compared to Italy between 31 January–15 March 2020.

original: It highlights that, as at 15 March 8:00 a.m., 15 other EU/EEA countries and the UK had already reported a total number of cases comparable to that of Italy just 3 weeks prior or less.
simplification: By 15th March 8:00 am, the total number of cases reported in 15 other EU/EEA countries and the UK were similar to Italy's in just under 3 weeks.

original: Our results indicate that the number of notified cases of COVID-19 is rapidly increasing in the EU/EEA and the UK.
simplification: Our results show that the number of reported cases of COVID-19 is rapidly increasing in the EU/EEA and the UK.

original: The observed trends in the cumulative incidence of COVID-19 suggest that the pandemic is progressing at a comparable speed in all countries.
simplification: The trend observed in the cumulative incidence of COVID-19, suggest that the outbreak is progressing at a similar rate in all countries.

original: This is despite countries being at different stages, variations in national public health responses, and possibly different case definitions in countries and different protocols for selecting patients that must be tested for confirmation of COVID-19, including catch-up testing.
simplification: This is despite countries having a variation in stages, protocols, and responses for selecting patients that must be tested for confirmation of COVID-19 and catch-up testing.

original: Early March 2020, doctors in the affected regions of Italy described a situation in which ca 10% of patients with COVID-19 required intensive care and media sources reported that hospitals and intensive care units in these regions had already reached their maximum capacity.
simplification: Doctors in affected regions of Italy described that 10% of patients with COVID needed intensive care in early March 2020. The media reported that hospital and intensive care units in those regions had already reached maximum capacity.

original: Data on admission of COVID-19 cases in a hospital and/or an intensive care unit are currently available at EU/EEA level for only 6% and 1% cases, respectively (data not shown).
simplification: The data on the admission of COVID-19 cases in a hospital and/or intensive care unit is currently available. It is only available for EU/EEA for only 6% of hospital cases and 1% of intensive care unit cases.

original: They should, however, be collected in a systematic fashion to complement current surveillance data that focus on the number of reported cases and the number of deaths.
simplification: The surveillance data focuses on the number of reported cases and the number of deaths. They should be collected systematically to go with the surveillance data.

original: SARS-CoV-2 infected people of all ages, but mainly at the age of 30-65.
simplification: SARS-CoV-2 infected people of all ages, but mainly at the age of 30-65.

original: Almost half (47.7%) of the infected individuals were over 50 years old, very few were under 20, and only 14 infected individuals were under the age of 10.
simplification: Almost half (47.7%) of the infected individuals were over 50 years old. A very few were under 20 and only 14 infected individuals were under the age of 10.

original: SARS-CoV-2 infected more men (0.31/100,000) than women (0.27/100,000).
simplification: SARS-CoV-2 infected more men (0.31/100,000) than women (0.27/100,000).

original: COVID-19 expanded in clusters mainly in and around Hubei.
simplification: COVID-19 expanded in groups mainly in and around Hubei.

original: COVID-19 took an average of 5 (2-9) days from onset to diagnosis.
simplification: COVID-19 took an average of 5 (2-9) days from start to diagnosis.

original: The average incubation period was 4.8 (3.0-7.2) days.
simplification: The average incubation period was 4.8 (3.0-7.2) days.

original: The average time from onset to death was 9.5 (4.8-13) days.
simplification: The average time from beginning to death was 9.5 (4.8-13) days.

original: The basic reproductive number (R0) was 3.77 (95% CI: 3.51-4.05), and the adjusted R0 was 2.23-4.82.
simplification: The basic reproductive number (R0) was 3.77 (95% CI: 3.51-4.05). The adjusted R0 was 2.23-4.82.

original: The number of infected people increased exponentially before 23 Jan. 2020, matching the time of massive transportation before the Spring Festival in China.
simplification: The number of infected people increased dramatically before 23 January 2020. It matched the time of massive transportation before the Spring Festival in China.

original: The mortality of patients with confirmed cases was 1.44% (95% CI: 1.10-1.86%), and the adjusted mortality of all the patients was 3.06% (95% CI: 2.02-4.59%).
simplification: The death rate of patients with confirmed cases was 1.44% (95% CI: 1.10-1.86%). The adjusted death rate of all the patients was 3.06% (95% CI: 2.02-4.59%).

original: Three major risk factors for COVID-19 were sex (male), age (≥60), and severe pneumonia.
simplification: The three major factors for COVID-19 were being of male gender, aged above 60 years old and having severe lung infection.

original: CoVs are a subfamily of large and enveloped viruses containing a single strand of sense RNA.
simplification: Coronaviruses are a subfamily of large and enveloped viruses containing a single strand of sense RNA.

original: They can be divided into four genera, i.e., alpha, beta, gamma, and delta, of which alpha- and beta-CoVs are known to infect humans.
simplification: They can be divided into four genera. It includes the alpha, beta, gamma, and delta. Alpha and beta-CoVs can infect humans.

original: The envelope spike (S) glycoprotein binds to its cellular receptors angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) and dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4) for SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV, respectively, and then membrane fusion occurs.
simplification: The membrane fusion happens when the envelope spike (S) glycoprotein binds to its cellular receptors angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) for SARS-CoV. Similarly, in MERS-CoV, this fusion occurs when it binds to dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4).

original: The viral RNA genome is released into the cytoplasm; after replication of the viral genome, genomic RNA accompanied by envelope glycoproteins and nucleocapsid proteins forms virion-containing vesicles, which then fuse with the plasma membrane to release the virus.
simplification: The viral RNA genome is released into the cytoplasm. Once the viral genome is replicated, genomic RNA accompanied by enveloped glycoproteins and nucleocapsid protein forms virion-containing vesicles. These vesicles fuse with the plasma membrane to release the virus.

original: The first genomic sequence of SARS-CoV-2 was reported on January 10, 2020.
simplification: The first genetic makeup of SARS-CoV-2 was reported on January 10, 2020.

original: SARS-CoV-2 was found to be a new type of beta-CoV with more than 99.98% genetic identity among 10 sequenced samples collected from the original site of the outbreak, the Huanan Seafood Market in Wuhan.
simplification: SARS-CoV-2 was found to be a new type of beta-CoV. It had more than 99.98% genetic identity out of the 10 sequenced samples collected from the original site of the outbreak, the Huanan Seafood Market in Wuhan.

original: SARS-CoV-2 is genetically more similar to SARS-CoV than to MERS-CoV.
simplification: SARS-CoV-2 is genetically more similar to SARS-CoV than to MERS-CoV.

original: Through transmission electron microscopy, SARS-CoV-2 particles were found in ultrathin sections of human airway epithelium.
simplification: Through transmission electron microscopy, SARS-CoV-2 particles were found in ultrathin sections of human airway epithelium.

original: Human ACE2 was found to be a receptor for SARS-CoV-2 as well as SARS-CoV.
simplification: Human ACE2 was found to be a receptor for SARS-CoV-2 and SARS-CoV.

original: However, the S protein of SARS-CoV-2 binds to human ACE2 more weakly than that of SARS-CoV, which is coincident with the fact that SARS-CoV-2 causes less severe infection in patients than SARS-CoV.
simplification: However, the S protein of SARS-CoV-2 binds to human ACE2 weakly than that of SARS-CoV. This correlated to the facts that SARS-CoV-2 causes less severe infection in patients than SARS-CoV.

original: SARS-CoV-2 can also form a novel short protein encoded by orf3b and a secreted protein encoded by orf8.
simplification: SARS-CoV-2 can form a novel short protein encoded by orf3b and a secreted protein encoded by orf8.

original: The orf3b of SARS-CoV-2 may play a role in the viral pathogenicity and inhibit the expression of IFNβ; however, orf8 does not contain any known functional domain or motif.
simplification: The orf3b of SARS-CoV-2 may play a role in the viral infection and obstructs the expression of IFNβ. However, orf8 does not contain any known functional domain or motif.

original: On February 18, 2020, Zhou, et al., reported the cryo-EM structure of the full-length human ACE2 at 2.9 Å resolution in complex with the amino acid transporter B0AT1.
simplification: On February 18, 2020, Zhou, et al., reported the cryo-EM structure of the full-length human ACE2 at 2.9 Å resolution in complex with the amino acid transporter B0AT1.

original: They found that the complex, which had open and closed conformations, was assembled as a dimer and the ACE2-B0AT1 complex can bind two S proteins, which provides evidence for CoV recognition and infection.
simplification: They found that the complex had open and close conformations, which was assembled as a dimer. The ACE2-B0AT1 complex can bind two S proteins and provides evidence for CoV recognition and infection.

original: B0AT1 may become a therapeutic target for drug screening to suppress SARS-CoV-2 infection.
simplification: B0AT1 may become a therapeutic target for drug screening to suppress SARS-CoV-2 infection.

original: The origin and intermediate host
simplification: The origin and intermediate host.

original: It has been known that both SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV originated from bats and were transmitted to humans via civet cats and camels, respectively.
simplification: It has been known that both SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV originated from bats. SARS-CoV was transmitted to humans via civet cats while MERS-CoV was transmitted to humans via camels.

original: Through a phylogenetic comparison of SARS-CoV-2 with other CoVs, bats were considered the native host of SARS-CoV-2 as the new virus is 96% identical to two SARS-like CoVs from bats called bat-SL-CoVZX45 and bat-SL-CoVZX21.
simplification: By comparing the genes of SARS-CoV-2 with other CoVs, bats were considered the native hosts. The new virus is 96% identical to two SARS-like CoVs from bats called bat-SL-CoVZX45 and bat-SL-CoVZX21.

original: However, what intermediate host helped the virus cross the species barrier to infect humans remains unknown, and the transmission route is yet to be elucidated.
simplification: The transmission route of which host helped the virus to cross species and infect humans is still unknown.

original: Ji, et al., proposed snakes as a carrier of the virus from bats to humans which involved homologous recombination within the S protein.
simplification: Ji, et al., suggested that snakes as carrier of the virus from bats to humans which involved chromosomal crossover within the S protein.

original: According to a study, researchers in Guangzhou, China, suggested that pangolins - long-snouted, ant-eating mammals often used in traditional Chinese medicine - are the potential intermediate host of SARS-CoV-2 based on 99% genetic homology in a CoV discovered in pangolins and SARS-CoV-2.
simplification: According to a study, researchers in Guangzhou, China, suggested that pangolins are the potential intermediate host of SARS-CoV-2. They are a long snouted, ant-eating mammal often used in traditional Chinese medicine. CoV found in pangolins shared 99% genetic similarity with SARS-CoV-2.

original: However, 1% difference spread all over two genomes is still a big difference; thus, conclusive results for concrete evidence are awaited (Fig. ​(Fig.33).
simplification: However, 1% difference spread all over two genomes is still a large difference. Therefore conclusive results for concrete evidence are still being looked for.

original: The physicochemical properties of SARS-CoV-2 are largely not yet known.
simplification: The physical and chemical properties of SARS-CoV-2 are still unknown.

original: SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV can survive in vitro for 48 hours in a dry environment and up to 5 days under 20 °C and 40%-50% humidity.
simplification: SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV can survive in vitro for 48 hours in a dry environment and up to 5 days under 20 °C and 40%-50% humidity.

original: SARS-CoV-2 may possess similar properties.
simplification: SARS-CoV-2 may possess similar properties.

original: It has been reported that SARS-CoV-2 is sensitive to ultraviolet rays and heat at 56 °C for 30 minutes; ether, 75% ethanol, chlorine-containing disinfectant, peracetic acid, chloroform, and other fatty solvents, but not chlorhexidine, can effectively inactivate the virus.
simplification: It has been reported that SARS-CoV-2 is sensitive to ultraviolet rays and heat at 56 °C for 30 minutes. Solutions such as ether, 75% ethanol, chlorine-containing disinfectant, peracetic acid, chloroform, and other fatty solvents, can effectively kill the virus. However, chlorhexidine cannot kill the virus.

original: The entire human population generally lacks immunity to SARS-CoV-2 and hence is susceptible to the novel virus.
simplification: The entire human population generally lacks immunity to SARS-CoV-2 and therefore, is vulnerable to the novel virus.

original: Currently, no detailed study has been reported regarding the immunological response to SARS-CoV-2.
simplification: Currently, there are no detailed study reported regarding the immune response to SARS-CoV-2.

original: Cytokine storm is a form of systemic inflammatory response featured by the release of a series of cytokines including TNFα, IL-1β, IL-2, IL-6, IFNα, IFNβ, IFNγ, and MCP-1.
simplification: Cytokine storm is a form of bodily response to inflammation that releases a series of cytokines including TNFα, IL-1β, IL-2, IL-6, IFNα, IFNβ, IFNγ, and MCP-1.

original: These cytokines induce immune cells to release a vast number of free radicals which are the major cause of ARDS and multiple organ failure.
simplification: These cytokines stimulate immune cells to release many free radicals which causes ARDS and multiple organ failure.

original: Immunosuppression is essential in the treatment of cytokine storms, especially in severe patients.
simplification: It is essential to treat cytokine storms with immunosuppressive drugs especially in severe patients.

original: Corticosteroids and tocilizumab, an anti-IL6 monoclonal antibody, have been used to treat cytokine storm.
simplification: Cytokine storm can be treated with an anti-IL9 monoclonal antibody such as corticosteroids and tocilizumab.

original: Other immunosuppression treatments for cytokine storm include the modulation of T cell-directed immune response; the blockade of IFN-γ, IL-1, and TNF; JAK inhibition; blinatumomab; suppressor of cytokine signaling 4; and HDAC inhibitors.
simplification: Modulation of T cell-directed immune response, blockage of IFN-γ, IL-1, and TNF, JAK inhibition, blinatumomab, suppressor of cytokine signalling 4, and HDAC inhibitors are other immunosuppressive treatments for cytokine storm.

original: Steroids, as immunosuppressants, were widely used in the treatment of SARS to reduce the severity of inflammatory damage.
simplification: Steroids were widely used as immunosuppressants to treat SARS. They reduced the severity of damaged caused by inflammation.

original: However, steroids at high dosages were not beneficial to severe lung injury in SARS and COVID-19 patients.
simplification: However, high dosages of steroid are not helpful in SARS and COVID-19 patients.

original: Instead, they may cause severe side effects, especially avascular osteonecrosis, dramatically affecting the prognosis.
simplification: They may cause serious side effects such as avascular osteonecrosis which dramatically affects the chance of recovery.

original: Nevertheless, short courses of corticosteroids at low-to-moderate doses have been recommended to be used prudently for critically ill COVID-19 patients.
simplification: Short courses of corticosteroids have been recommended to be used carefully for critically ill COVID-19 patients.

original: At the time of writing, no effective antiviral therapy has been confirmed.
simplification: No effective antiviral therapy has been confirmed at the time of writing.

original: However, intravenous administration with remdesivir, a nucleotide analog, has been found to be efficacious in an American patient with COVID-19.
simplification: However, remdesivir, a nucleotide analog, administered intravenously have been found to effective in treating an American patient with COVID-19.

original: Remdesivir is a novel antiviral drug developed by Gilead initially for the treatment of diseases caused by Ebola and Marlburg viruses.
simplification: Remdesivir is a new antiviral drug developed by Gilead to initially treat Ebola and Marlburg viruses.

original: Later, remdesivir also demonstrated possible inhibition of other single stranded RNA viruses including MERS and SARS viruses.
simplification: Remdesivir also showed possible inhibition of other single stranded viruses like MERS and SARS.

original: Based on these, Gilead has provided the compound to China to conduct a pair of trials on SARS-CoV-2-infected individuals, and the results are highly anticipated.
simplification: Based on these, Gilead has provided the compound to China to carry out a pair of trials on SARS-CoV-2 infected patients. The results are highly expected.

original: In addition, baricitinb, interferon-α, lopinavir/ritonavir, and ribavirin have been suggested as potential therapies for patients with acute respiratory symptoms.
simplification: Baricitinb, interferon-α, lopinavir/ritonavir, and ribavirin have been suggested as additional potential therapies for patients with acute respiratory symptoms.

original: Diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, liver damage, and other adverse reactions can occur following combined therapy with lopinavir/ritonavir.
simplification: Following combined therapy with lopinavir/ritonavir, diarrhoea, nausea, vomiting, liver damage and adverse reactions can occur.

original: The interaction of these treatments with other drugs used in the patients should be monitored carefully.
simplification: The interaction of these treatments with other drugs used in the patients should be monitored carefully.

original: Plasma from recovered patients and antibody generation
simplification: Plasma from recovered patients and antibody generation

original: The collection of the blood from patients who recovered from a contagious disease to treat other patients suffering from the same disease or to protect healthy individuals from catching the disease has a long history.
simplification: There is a long history of using blood collected from patients who have recovered from contagious disease. It can be used to treat other patient suffering from the same disease or to protect healthy individual from catching the disease.

original: Indeed, recovered patients often have a relatively high level of antibodies against the pathogen in their blood.
simplification: In fact, patients who have recovered often have a high level of antibodies against the pathogen in their blood.

original: Antibodies are an immunoglobulin (Ig) produced by B lymphocytes to fight pathogens and other foreign objects and they recognize unique molecules in the pathogens and neutralize them directly.
simplification: Antibodies are an immunoglobulin (Ig) produced by B lymphocytes to fight pathogens and other foreign objects. They recognize unique molecules in the pathogens and kill them directly.

original: Based on this, plasma was collected from the blood of a group of patients who recovered from COVID-19 and was injected into 10 seriously ill patients.
simplification: Based on this, plasma was collected from the blood of a group of patients who recovered from COVID-19. The collected blood was injected into 10 seriously ill patients.

original: Their symptoms improved within 24 hours, accompanied by reduced inflammation and viral loads and improved oxygen saturation in the blood.
simplification: Their symptoms improved within 24 hours. Inflammation and the number of viruses in the blood reduced. The oxygen level in the blood also improved.

original: However, verification and clarification are necessary to propose the method for large-scale use before specific therapies are not yet developed.
simplification: However, verification and clarification is required to propose the method for large-scale use as specific therapies are not yet developed.

original: In addition, given the therapeutic effects, some disadvantages associated with the plasma should be considered carefully.
simplification: Furthermore, given the healing effects, some disadvantages associated with the plasma must be considered carefully.

original: For example, antibodies can overstimulate the immune response and cause cytokine release syndrome, which is potentially a life-threatening toxicity.
simplification: For example, antibodies can overstimulate the immune response and cause cytokine release syndrome, which is a life-threatening condition.

original: The concentration of antibodies in the blood is usually low, and the demand for the plasma is large to treat critically ill patients.
simplification: The concentration of antibodies in the blood is usually low. However, the demand for the plasma is massive to treat critically ill patients.

original: It is difficult to develop and produce specific antibodies rapidly enough to fight against a global epidemic.
simplification: It is difficult to develop and produce specific antibodies quick enough to fight against a global outbreak.

original: Thus, it is more critical and practical to isolate B cells from recovered patients and identify the genetic codes encoding effective antibodies or screen for effective antibodies against essential proteins of the virus.
simplification: Therefore, it is more important and practical to identify B cell from recovered patients. Genetic codes can be identified to screen for effective antibodies against essential proteins of the virus.

original: This way, we can readily scale up the production of the antibodies.
simplification: This way, we can readily scale up the production of antibodies.

original: TCM has been used to treat a variety of diseases in China for thousands of years.
simplification: TCM has been used to treat a variety of diseases in China for thousands of years.

original: However, its effects largely rely on a combination of multiple components in a formula that varies depending on the diagnosis of a disease based on the theories of TCM.
simplification: However, its effects rely heavily on a combination of multiple components in a formula. This can vary depending on the diagnosis of a disease based on the theories of TCM.

original: Most of the effective components remain unknown or are vague as it is difficult to extract and verify such components or their optimal combinations.
simplification: Most of the effective component remain unknown or are vague as it is difficult to extract and verify such components or their optimal combination.

original: Currently, due to the lack of effective and specific therapy for COVID-19, TCM has become one of the major alternative treatments for patients with light to moderate symptoms or for those who have recovered from severe stages.
simplification: Due to the lack of effective and specific therapy for COVID-19, TCM has become one of the major alternative treatments for patients with light to moderate symptoms or for those who have recovered from severe stages.

original: For example, Shu Feng Jie Du capsules and Lian Hua Qing Wen capsules were found to be effective for COVID-19 treatment.
simplification: For example, Shu Feng Jie Du capsules and Lian Hua Qing Wen capsules were found to be successful at treating COVID-19.

original: Top cure rates in the treatment of COVID-19 patients were observed in several provinces in China that used TCM in 87% of their patients, including Gansu (63.7%), Ningxia (50%), and Hunan (50%), whereas Hubei province, which used TCM in only approximately 30% of its COVID-19 patients, had the lowest cure rate (13%).
simplification: Top cure rates that used TCM in the treatment of 87% COVID-19 patients were observed in several provinces in China. This includes Gansu (63.7%), Ningexia (50%) and Hunan (50%) whereas in Hubei province had the lowest cure rate (13%) as it approximately used only in 30% of COVID- patients.

original: However, this is quite a rough comparison as many other impact factors such as the number and severity of the patients should be included in the evaluation.
simplification: However, this is a rough estimation as many other impact factors such as the number and severity of the patients should be included in the evaluation.

original: On February 18, 2020, Boli Zhang and coworkers published a study to compare western medicine (WM) treatment alone with combined treatment of WM and TCM.
simplification: Boli Zhang and co-workers published a study on February 18, 2020, to compare the treatment of western medicine (WM) alone with combined treatment of WM and TCM.

original: They found that the times needed for body temperature recovery, symptom disappearance, and hospitalization were remarkably shorter in the WM+TCM group than in the WM only group.
simplification: They found that the time needed to recover from fever, symptoms to disappear and hospitalization were remarkably shorter in the WM+TCM group than in the WM only group.

original: Most impressively, the rate for symptomatic worsening (from light to severe) was remarkably lower for the WM+TCM group than for the WM only group (7.4% versus 46.2%) and the mortality was lower in the WM+TCM group than WM only group (8.8% versus 39%).
simplification: The rate for symptomatic worsening (from light severe) was lower for WM+TCM group than the WM only group (7.4% versus 46.2%). The mortality rate was lower for WM+TCM group than the WM only group (8.8% versus 39%).

original: Nevertheless, the efficacy and safety of TCM still await more well-controlled trials at larger scales and in more centers.
simplification: The efficacy and safety of TCM still requires more well-controlled trial at larger scales and in more centres.

original: It would also be intriguing to characterize the mechanism of actions and clarify the effective components of TCM treatments or their combinations if possible.
simplification: It would be interesting to characterize the mechanism of actions and identify the components of TCM treatment which make its effective.

original: Patients with suspected or confirmed COVID-19 mostly experience great fear of the highly contagious and even fatal disease, and quarantined people also experience boredom, loneliness, and anger.
simplification: Patients with suspected or confirmed COVID-19 mostly experience fear of the highly contagious and deadly disease. People in quarantine also experience boredom, loneliness and anger.

original: Furthermore, symptoms of the infection such as fever, hypoxia, and cough as well as adverse effects of the treatments such as insomnia caused by corticosteroids can lead to more anxiety and mental distress.
simplification: Furthermore, symptoms of the infection such as fever, hypoxia and cough and adverse effects like insomnia from corticosteroid treatment can lead to more anxiety and mental distress.

original: In the early phase of the SARS outbreak, a range of psychiatric morbidities including persistent depression, anxiety, panic attacks, psychomotor excitement, psychotic symptoms, delirium, and even suicidality were reported.
simplification: During the early phase of SARS outbreak, a range of mental disorders such as depression, anxiety panic attack, psychomotor excitement, psychotic symptoms, delirium and even suicidal tendencies were reported.

original: Mandatory contact tracing and quarantine, as a part of the public health responses to the COVID-19 outbreak, can make people more anxious and guilty about the effects of the contagion, quarantine, and stigma on their families and friends.
simplification: Compulsory contact tracing and quarantine can make people more anxious and guilty about the effects of the disease, quarantine and stigma on their family and friends.

original: Thus, mental health care should be provided to COVID-19 patients, suspected individuals, and people in contact with them as well as the general public who are in need.
simplification: Therefore, mental health care should be given to COVID-19 patients, suspected individual, people in contact with them and the general public who need it.

original: The psychological support should include the establishment of multidisciplinary mental health teams, clear communications with regular and accurate updates about the SARS-CoV-2 outbreak and treatment plans and the use of professional electronic devices and applications to avoid close contact with each other.
simplification: The psychological support should consist of multidisciplinary mental health team, clear communications with regular and accurate updates about the SARS-CoC-2 outbreak and treatment plans. Professional electronic devices and application should be used to avoid close contact with each other.

original: Effective vaccines are essential for interrupting the chain of transmission from animal reservoirs and infected humans to susceptible hosts and are often complementary to antiviral treatment in the control of epidemics caused by emerging viruses.
simplification: Effective vaccines are important for disrupting the chain of transmission from animals and infected humans to vulnerable hosts. They are often complementary to antiviral treatment in the control of outbreaks causes by upcoming viruses.

original: Efforts have been made to develop S protein-based vaccines to generate long-term and potent neutralizing antibodies and/or protective immunity against SARS-CoV.
simplification: Efforts have been made to develop S protein-based vaccines to generate long term and potent, antibodies and/or protective immunity against SARS-CoV.

original: Live-attenuated vaccines have been evaluated in animal models for SARS.
simplification: Vaccines containing weaker form of the viruses have been test in animal models for SARS.

original: This is probably because SARS died down 17 years ago and no new case has been reported since.
simplification: This is because SARS died down 17 years ago and no new case has been reported ever since.

original: In contrast, sporadic cases and clusters of MERS continue to occur in the Middle East and spread to other regions owing to the persistence of zoonotic sources in endemic areas.
simplification: In comparison, sporadic cases and clusters of MERS continue to appear in the Middle East. It has spread to other regions due to the persistence of zoonotic sources in endemic areas.

original: Vaccination strategies have been developed for MERS by using inactivated virus, DNA plasmids, viral vectors, nanoparticles, virus-like particles and recombinant protein subunits and some have been evaluated in animal models.
simplification: Vaccination strategies for MERS have been developed using inactivated virus, DNA plasmids, viral vectors, nanoparticles, virus like particles and recombinant protein subunit. Some have been tested on animal models.

original: The development of a safe and effective vaccine against SARS-CoV-2 for non-immune individuals is an urgent and critical task for controlling the ongoing epidemic.
simplification: It is an urgent and important task to develop a safe and effective vaccine against SARS-CoV-2 for non-immune individuals and to control the ongoing outbreak.

original: However, it is challenging to overcome the difficulty because of the long period of time (averaged 18 months) needed for vaccine development and the dynamic variations of CoVs.
simplification: The long period, averaging 18 months, needed for vaccine development and dynamic variations of CoV makes it a challenge.

original: As a novel disease, COVID-19 has just started to manifest its full clinical course throughout thousands of patients.
simplification: As a new disease, COVID-19 has just started to develop its full course throughout thousands of patients.

original: In most cases, patients can recover gradually without sequelae.
simplification: In most cases, patients can recover gradually without any consequences.

original: However, similar to SARS and MERS, COVID-19 is also associated with high morbidity and mortality in patients with severe cases.
simplification: However, similar to SARS and MERS, COVID-19 is also linked to high morbidity and mortality in patients with severe cases.

original: Therefore, building a prognosis model for the disease is essential for health-care agencies to prioritize their services, especially in resource-constrained areas.
simplification: Therefore, building a care plan model for the disease is important for health care agencies to prioritize their services, especially in areas where resources are constrained.

original: Based on clinical studies reported thus far, the following factors may affect or be associated with the prognosis of COVID-19 patients (Table ​(Table33):
simplification: Based on clinical finding report so far, the following factors may affect or be linked with the outcome of COVID-19 patients.

original: Age: Age was the most important factor for the prognosis of SARS, which is also true for COVID-19.
simplification: Similar to SARS, age was an important factor for the prognosis in COVID-19.

original: COVID-19 mainly happened at the age of 30-65 with 47.7% of those patients being over 50 in a study of 8,866 cases as described above.
simplification: In a study of 8,866 cases, COVID-19 mainly affected those aged 30-65. 47.7% of those patients were over 50.

original: Patients who required intensive care were more likely to have underlying comorbidities and complications and were significantly older than those who did not (at the median age of 66 versus 51), suggesting age as a prognostic factor for the outcome of COVID-19 patients.
simplification: Patients who require intensive care were more likely to have underlying conditions, complications and significantly older than those who do not (median age of 66 versus 51). This suggest age as recovery outcome factor for COVID-19 patients.

original: Sex: SARS-CoV-2 has infected more men than women (0.31/100,000 versus 0.27/100,000), as described above.
simplification: As described above, SARS-CoV-2 has infected more men than women (0.31/100,000 versus 0.27/100,000).

original: Without knowing answers to #1 and 2, we cannot efficiently cut the transmission, and the outbreak can relapse at any time.
simplification: Without knowing answers to #1 and 2, we cannot efficiently cut the transmission and the outbreak can return at any time.

original: Although molecular modeling and biochemical assays have demonstrated that SARS-CoV-2 binds to ACE2, how exactly does the virus enter the airway cells and cause subsequent pathological changes?
simplification: Although molecular modelling and biochemical assay have shown that SARS-CoV-2 binds to ACE2, how does the virus enter the airway cells and cause pathological changes?

original: Does the virus also bind ACE2-expressing cells in other organs?
simplification: Does the virus also bind ACE2-expressing cells in other organs?

original: Without clear answers to these questions, we cannot achieve fast and accurate diagnosis and effective treatment.
simplification: We cannot achieve quick and accurate diagnosis and effective answers, without clear answers to these questions.

original: How long will the epidemic last?
simplification: How long will the outbreak last?

original: How is the virus genetically evolving during transmission among humans?
simplification: How is the virus evolving when transmitted among humans?

original: Will it become a pandemic worldwide, die down like SARS or relapse periodically like the flu?
simplification: Will it become a pandemic worldwide, die down like SARS or reoccur seasonally like the flu?

original: It is essential but may take some time to search for answers to the above and many other questions.
simplification: It is important but it may take time to search for answers to the above and many other questions.

original: However, with whatever expense it may demand, we have no other choice but to stop the epidemic as soon as possible and bring our life back to normal.
simplification: However, with whatever expense it may demand, we have no other choice but to stop the epidemic as soon as possible and bring our life back to normal.

original: Zoonotic origins of human coronaviruses
simplification: Human coronaviruses originated from animals

original: Mutation and adaptation have driven the co-evolution of coronaviruses (CoVs) and their hosts, including human beings, for thousands of years.
simplification: Co-evolution of coronaviruses (CoVs) and their hosts, including human beings have been driven by mutation and adaptation for thousands of years.

original: Before 2003, two human CoVs (HCoVs) were known to cause mild illness, such as common cold.
simplification: Before 2003, two humans CoVs (HCoVs) were known to cause mild illness, such as common cold.

original: The outbreaks of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) and the Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS) have flipped the coin to reveal how devastating and life-threatening an HCoV infection could be.
simplification: The outbreaks of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) and the Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS) have flipped the coin to show how devastating and life-threatening an HCoV infection could be.

original: The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 in central China at the end of 2019 has thrusted CoVs into the spotlight again and surprised us with its high transmissibility but reduced pathogenicity compared to its sister SARS-CoV.
simplification: The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 in central China at the end of 2019 has placed CoVs into the spotlight again. It has surprised us with its high transmissibility, but reduced pathogenicity compared to its sister SARS-CoV.

original: HCoV infection is a zoonosis and understanding the zoonotic origins of HCoVs would serve us well.
simplification: HCoV infection is a zoonosis. Understanding the animal orgin of HCoVs would serve us well.

original: Most HCoVs originated from bats where they are non-pathogenic.
simplification: Most HCoVs emerged from bats where they are non-infectious.

original: The intermediate reservoir hosts of some HCoVs are also known.
simplification: The intermediate reservoir hosts of some HCoVs are also known.

original: Identifying the animal hosts has direct implications in the prevention of human diseases.
simplification: Prevention of human diseases is directly associated with identifying the animal hosts.

original: Investigating CoV-host interactions in animals might also derive important insight on CoV pathogenesis in humans.
simplification: Investigating CoV-host interactions in animal might also show important insight on CoV pathogenesis in humans.

original: In this review, we present an overview of the existing knowledge about the seven HCoVs, with a focus on the history of their discovery as well as their zoonotic origins and interspecies transmission.
simplification: In this review, we present an overview of the existing knowledge about the seven HCoVs. It focuses on the history of their discovery as well as their zoonotic origins and interspecies transmission.

original: Importantly, we compare and contrast the different HCoVs from a perspective of virus evolution and genome recombination.
simplification: Importantly, we compare the different HCoVs from a perspective of virus evolution and genome recombination.

original: The current CoV disease 2019 (COVID-19) epidemic is discussed in this context.
simplification: The current CoV disease 2019 (COVID-19) outbreak is discussed in this context.

original: In addition, the requirements for successful host switches and the implications of virus evolution on disease severity are also highlighted.
simplification: The requirements for successful host switches and involvement of virus evolution on disease severity are also highlighted.

original: Coronaviruses (CoVs) belong to the family Coronaviridae, which comprises a group of enveloped, positive-sensed, single-stranded RNA viruses.
simplification: Coronaviruses (CoVs) belong to the family Coronaviridae. It comprises a group of enveloped, positive-sensed, single-stranded RNA viruses.

original: These viruses harbouring the largest genome of 26 to 32 kilobases amongst RNA viruses were termed “CoVs” because of their crown-like morphology under electron microscope.
simplification: These viruses consist of the largest genome of 26 to 32 kilobases among RNA. They were termed ‘’CoV’’ as they appear with crown-like structure under an electron microscope.

original: Structurally, CoVs have non-segmented genomes that share a similar organization.
simplification: Structurally, CoVs have non-segmented genomes that share a similar organization.

original: Approximately two thirds of the genome contain two large overlapping open reading frames (ORF1a and ORF1b), which are translated into the pp1a and pp1ab replicase polyproteins.
simplification: Approximately two thirds of the genome contain two large overlapping open reading frames. ORF1a and ORF1b are translated into the pp1a and pp1ab replicase polyproteins.

original: The polyproteins are further processed to generate 16 non-structural proteins, designated nsp1~16.
simplification: The polyproteins are further processed to generate 16 non-structural proteins, designated nsp1~16.

original: The remaining portion of the genome contains ORFs for the structural proteins, including spike (S), envelope (E), membrane (M) and nucleoprotein (N).
simplification: The remaining portion of the genome contains ORFs for the structural proteins, including spike (S), envelope (E), membrane (M) and nucleoprotein (N).

original: A number of lineage-specific accessory proteins are also encoded by different lineages of CoVs.
simplification: Different lineages of CoVs were encoded by several lineage specific accessory proteins.

original: Based on the difference in protein sequences, CoVs are classified into four genera (alpha-CoV, beta-CoV, gamma-CoV and delta-CoV), among which the beta-CoV genera contains most HCoVs and is subdivided into four lineages (A, B, C and D).
simplification: Based on the difference in protein sequences, CoVs are classified into four genera - alpha-CoV, beta-CoV, gamma-CoV and delta-CoV. the beta-CoV genera contains most HCoVs and is subdivided into four lineages (A, B, C and D).

original: Phylogenetic evidence has shown that bats and rodents serve as the gene source of most alpha-CoVs and beta-CoVs, while birds are the main reservoir of gamma-CoVs and delta-CoVs.
simplification: Evidence has shown that bats and rodents serve as source of most alpha-CoVs and beta-CoVs. Birds are the main source of gamma-COVs and delta-CoVs.

original: For thousands of years, CoVs have constantly crossed species barriers and some have emerged as important human pathogens.
simplification: For thousands of years, CoVs have constantly cross barrier across species, and some have emerged as important human pathogens.

original: To date, seven human CoVs (HCoVs) are known.
simplification: To date, seven humans CoVs (HCoVs) are known.

original: Among them HCoV-229E and HCoV-NL63 are alpha-CoVs.
simplification: Among them HCoV-229E and HCoV-NL63 are alpha-CoVs.

original: The other five beta-CoVs include HCoV-OC43, HCoV-HKU1, severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus (SARS-CoV), Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) and SARS-CoV-2.
simplification: The other five beta-CoVs include HCoV-OC43, HCoV-HKU1, severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus (SARS-CoV), Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) and SARS-CoV-2.

original: HCoV-229E, HCoV-OC43, HCoV-HKU1 and HCoV-NL63 usually cause mild symptoms, like common cold and/or diarrhea.
simplification: HCoV-229E, HCoV-OC43, HCoV-HKU1 and HCoV-NL63 usually cause mild symptoms, like common cold and/or diarrhoea.

original: In contrast, SARS-CoV, MERS-CoV and the newly-identified SARS-CoV-2 are highly pathogenic, causing severe lower respiratory tract infection in relatively more patients with a higher chance to develop acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and extrapulmonary manifestations.
simplification: In contrast, SARS-CoV, MERS-CoV and the newly identified SARS-CoV-2 are highly pathogenic. It causes severe lower respiratory tract infection in relatively more patients with a higher chance to develop acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and extrapulmonary manifestations.

original: The first HCoV-229E strain, B814, was isolated from the nasal discharge of patients with common cold in mid-1960s.
simplification: The first HCoV-229E strain, B814, was isolated from the nasal discharge of patients with common cold in mid-1960s.

original: Since then, more knowledge was accumulated through extensive studies on HCoV-229E and HCoV-OC43, both of which cause self-limiting symptoms.
simplification: More knowledge was accumulated since then, through extensive studies on HCoV-229E and HCoV-OC43. Both viruses cause self-limiting symptoms.

original: Indeed, the concept had been widely accepted that infection with HCoVs is generally harmless until the outbreak of SARS.
simplification: The concept had been widely accepted that infection with HCoVs is generally harmless until the outbreak of SARS.

original: The SARS outbreak occurred in 2003 is one of the most devastating in current history, infecting over 8,000 people with a crude case fatality of approximately 10%.
simplification: The SARS outbreak in 2003 is one of the most devastating in current history. It infected over 8,000 people with a fatality of approximately 10%.

original: Ten years later, the Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS) outbreak resulted in a persistent epidemic in the Arabian Peninsula with sporadic spreading to the rest of the world.
simplification: Ten years later, the Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS) outbreak resulted in a persistent epidemic in the Arabian Peninsula with sporadic spreading to the rest of the world.

original: The 2019 novel HCoV (2019-nCoV), which has subsequently been renamed SARS-CoV-2, is the causative agent of the ongoing epidemic of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), which has claimed more than 3,120 lives and infected more than 91,000 people as of March 3, 2020.
simplification: The 2019 novel HCoV (2019-nCoV) which has been renamed SARS-CoV-2, is the causative agent of the ongoing epidemic of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19). It has claimed more than 3,120 lives and infected more than 91,000 people as of March 3, 2020.

original: The alarm has been ringing and the world has to prepare for the coming pandemic of SARS-CoV-2.
simplification: The alarm has been ringing and the world has to prepare for the coming pandemic of SARS-CoV-2.

original: All seven HCoVs have a zoonotic origin from bats, mice or domestic animals.
simplification: All seven HCoVs are originated from bats, mice or domestic animals.

original: Multiple lines of evidence support an evolutionary origin of all HCoVs from bats, where viruses are well adapted and non-pathogenic but show great genetic diversity.
