simplification: Multiple sources of evidence support that all HCoVs originate from bats. The viruses are well adapted and non-disease causing, but show great genetic diversity.

original: The COVID-19 epidemic has presented enormous medical, scientific, social and moral challenges to China and the world.
simplification: The COVID-19 epidemic has presented enormous medical, scientific, social and moral challenges to China and the world.

original: Tracing the zoonotic origins of HCoVs provides a framework to understand the natural history, driving force and restriction factors of species jumping.
simplification: Tracing the animal origin of HCoVs provides a framework to understand the natural history, driving force and factors that restrict jumping between species.

original: In this review we present an overview of the zoonotic origins, interspecies transmission and pathogenesis of HCoVs.
simplification: In this review we present an overview of the zoonotic origins, interspecies transmission and pathogenesis of HCoVs.

original: Particularly, we highlight and discuss the common theme that parental viruses of HCoVs are typically non-pathogenic in their natural reservoir hosts but become pathogenic after interspecies transmission to a new host.
simplification: We particularly highlight and discuss the common theme that parental viruses of HCoVs are typically non-disease causing in their natural hosts but become pathogenic after it jumps from one species to a new host.

original: We also review the trend of HCoV evolution in which the increase in transmissibility often comes with the decrease in pathogenicity.
simplification: We also review the trend of HCoV evolution. The increase in transmissibility often comes with the decrease in pathogenicity.

original: The outcome of the ongoing SARS-CoV-2 outbreak is also discussed in this context.
simplification: The outcome of the ongoing SARS-CoV-2 outbreak is also discussed in this context.

original: Animal CoVs have been known since late 1930s.
simplification: Animal CoVs have been known since late 1930s.

original: Before the first isolation of HCoV-229E strain B814 from the nasal discharge of patients who had contracted common cold, different CoVs had been isolated in various infected animals, including turkey, mouse, cow, pig, cat and dog.
simplification: Different CoVs had been first isolated in various infected animals including turkey, mouse, cow, pig, cat and dog. Before that, HCoV-229E Stain B814 was first isolated from a the nasal discharge of a patient who had contracted common cold.

original: In the past decades, seven HCoVs have been identified.
simplification: Seven HCoVs have been identified in the past decades.

original: A brief summary of the history of HCoV discovery in chronological order (Table ​1) would be informative and instructive.
simplification: A brief summary of the history of HCoV discovery in chronological order (Table ​1) would be informative and instructive.

original: The first HCoV-229E strain was isolated from the respiratory tract of patients with upper respiratory tract infection in the year of 1966, and was subsequently adapted to grow in WI-38 lung cell lines.
simplification: The first HCoV-229E strain was isolated from the respiratory tract of patients with upper respiratory tract infection in the year of 1966. It eventually adapted to grow in WI-38 lung cell lines.

original: Patients infected with HCoV-229E presented with common cold symptoms, including headache, sneezing, malaise and sore-throat, with fever and cough seen in 10~20% cases.
simplification: Patients infected with HCoV-229E presented with common cold symptoms such as headache, sneezing, muscle weakness and sore-throat. Fever and cough seen in 10-20% cases.

original: Later in 1967, HCoV-OC43 was isolated from organ culture and subsequent serial passage in brains of suckling mice.
simplification: Later in 1967, HCoV-OC43 was isolated from organ culture and subsequent serial passage in brains of suckling mice.

original: The clinical features of HCoV-OC43 infection appear to be similar to those caused by HCoV-229E, which are symptomatically indistinguishable from infection with other respiratory tract pathogens such as influenza A viruses and rhinoviruses.
simplification: The symptoms caused by HCoV-OC43 infection appears to be similar to those caused by HCoV-229E. They are symptomatically indistinguishable from infection with other respiratory tract pathogens such as influenza A viruses and rhinoviruses.

original: Both HCoV-229E and HCoV-OC43 are distributed globally, and they tend to be predominantly transmitted during the season of winter in temperate climate.
simplification: Both HCoV-229E and HCoV-OC43 are distributed globally. They tend to be predominantly transmitted during the season of winter in temperate climate.

original: Generally, the incubation time of these two viruses is less than one week, followed by an approximately 2-week illness.
simplification: The incubation time of these two viruses is less than one week, followed by an approximately 2-week illness.

original: According to a human volunteer study, healthy individuals infected with HCoV-229E developed mild common cold.
simplification: According to a human volunteer study, healthy individuals infected with HCoV-229E developed mild common cold.

original: Only a few immunocompromised patients exhibited severe lower respiratory tract infection.
simplification: Only a few immunocompromised patients presented with severe lower respiratory tract infection.

original: SARS, also known as “atypical pneumonia”, was the first well documented HCoV-caused pandemic in human history and the etiological agent is SARS-CoV, the third HCoV discovered.
simplification: SARS, also known as “atypical pneumonia”, was the first well documented HCoV-caused pandemic in human history. The third discovered HCoV was SARS-CoV.

original: The first case of SARS can be traced back to late 2002 in Guangdong Province of China.
simplification: The first case of SARS can be traced back to late 2002 in Guangdong Province of China.

original: The SARS epidemic resulted in 8,096 reported cases with 774 deaths, spreading across many countries and continents.
simplification: The SARS outbreak caused 8,096 reported cases and 774 deaths. The outbreak spread across many countries and continents.

original: Apart from the super-spreaders, it was estimated that each case could give rise to approximately two secondary cases, with an incubation period of 4 to 7 days and the peak of viral load appearing on the 10th day of illness.
simplification: Along with the super-spreaders, it was estimated that each case could cause two secondary cases. It may have an incubation period of 4 to 7 days and the peak of viral load appearing on the 10th day of illness.

original: Patients infected with SARS-CoV initially present with myalgia, headache, fever, malaise and chills, followed by dyspnea, cough and respiratory distress as late symptoms.
simplification: Patients infected with SARS-CoV initially present with tiredness, muscle pain, headache, fever and chills. Late symptoms such as breathing difficulty and cough can follow.

original: Lymphopenia, deranged liver function tests, and elevated creatine kinase are common laboratory abnormalities of SARS.
simplification: Common laboratory results of SARS can include reduced level of lymphocytes, abnormal liver function tests and increased level of creatine kinase.

original: Diffuse alveolar damage, epithelial cell proliferation and an increase of macrophages are also observed in SARS patients.
simplification: Diffuse alveolar damage, increased number of epithelial cell and macrophages are seen in SARS patients.

original: Approximately 20-30% of patients subsequently require intensive care and mechanical ventilation.
simplification: Approximately 20-30% of patients may need intensive care and mechanical ventilation.

original: In addition to lower respiratory tract, multiple organs including gastrointestinal tract, liver and kidney can also be infected in these severe cases, usually accompanied with a cytokine storm, which might be lethal particularly in immunocompromised patients.
simplification: Besides lower respiratory tract, the gastrointestinal tract, liver and kidney can also be infected in these severe cases. It is usually accompanied with a cytokine storm which might be dangerous in immunocompromised patients.

original: The virus was first isolated from the open lung biopsy of a relative of the index patient who travelled to Hong Kong from Guangzhou.
simplification: The virus was first isolated from a lung biopsy of a relative of the key patient who travelled to Hong Kong from Guang Zhou.

original: Since then, tremendous efforts have been dedicated to HCoV research.
simplification: Since then, great efforts have been committed to HCoV research.

original: HCoV-NL63 was isolated from a 7-month-old child from the Netherlands during late 2004.
simplification: HCoV-NL63 was found from a 7-month-old child from the Netherlands during late 2004.

original: It was initially found to be prevalent in young children, the elderly and immunocompromised patients with respiratory illnesses.
simplification: It was originally found to common in young children, the elderly and immunocompromised patients with respiratory illnesses.

original: Presentation of coryza, conjunctivitis, fever, and bronchiolitis is common in the disease caused by HCoV-NL63.
simplification: Cold, pinkeye, fever and bronchiolitis is common in the disease caused by HCoV-NL63.

original: Another independent study described the isolation of the same virus from a nasal specimen from an 8-month-old boy suffering from pneumonia in the Netherlands.
simplification: Another study described the same virus from a nasal specimen from an 8-month-old boy suffering from pneumonia in the Netherlands.

original: Although it was identified in Netherlands, it is actually distributed globally.
simplification: Although it was found in Netherlands, it is widespread globally.

original: It has been estimated that HCoV-NL63 accounts for approximately 4.7% of common respiratory diseases, and its peak incidence occurs during early summer, spring and winter.
simplification: It has been estimated that HCoV-NL63 is responsible for around 4.7% of common respiratory diseases. It peaks around early summer, spring and winter.

original: HCoV-NL63 is associated with obstructive laryngitis, also known as croup.
simplification: HCoV-NL63 is linked with obstructive laryngitis, also known as croup.

original: In the same year, HCoV-HKU1 was isolated from a 71-year-old man who had been hospitalized with pneumonia and bronchiolitis in Hong Kong.
simplification: In the same year, HCoV-HKU1 was found from a 71-year-old man who had been hospitalized with pneumonia and bronchiolitis in Hong Kong.

original: Besides community-acquired pneumonia and bronchiolitis, HCoV-HKU1 was reported to be associated with acute asthmatic exacerbation.
simplification: In addition to community-acquired pneumonia and bronchiolitis, HCoV-HKU1 was found to be linked with acute asthmatic exacerbation.

original: Similar to HCoV-NL63, HCoV-229E and HCoV-OC43, HCoV-HKU1 was found worldwide, causing mild respiratory diseases.
simplification: HCoV-229E, HCoV-OC43, HCoV-HKU1 was found worldwide causing mild respiratory diseases like HCoV-NL63.

original: All these four community-acquired HCoVs have been well adapted to humans and are generally less likely to mutate to cause highly pathogenic diseases, though accidents did occur for unknown reasons as in the rare case of a more virulent subtype of HCoV-NL63, which has recently been reported to cause severe lower respiratory tract infection in China.
simplification: All these four community acquired HCoVs have been well adapted to humans. They are less likely to mutate and cause highly infectious diseases. In rare cases, accidents may occur for unknown reasons. An example includes the contagious subtype of HCoV-NL63 which has recently been reported to cause severe lung infection in China.

original: Generally, when these HCoVs acquire the abilities to transmit efficiently and to maintain themselves continuously within humans, they also become less virulent or pathogenic.
simplification: Generally, when these HCoVs gain the abilities to spread efficiently and remain within humans, they also become less infectious.

original: MERS-CoV was first isolated in 2012 from the lung of a 60-year-old patient who developed acute pneumonia and renal failure in Saudi Arabia.
simplification: MERS-CoV was first isolated in 2012 from the lung of a 60-year-old patient who developed acute pneumonia and renal failure in Saudi Arabia.

original: Whereas most of the laboratory-confirmed cases originate from the Middle East, imported cases with occasional secondary spreads to close contacts have been reported in various European countries and Tunisia.
simplification: Unlike most of the Middle East cases confirmed in the laboratory, imported cases with infrequent secondary spreads to close contacts have been reported in various European countries and Tunisia.

original: Another secondary outbreak occurred in South Korea in 2015 with 186 confirmed cases.
simplification: Another minor outbreak happened in South Korea in 2015 with 186 confirmed cases.

original: Clinical manifestations of MERS resemble those of SARS, characterized by progressive acute pneumonia.
simplification: Symptoms of MERS is similar to SARS which is characterised by progressive acute pneumonia.

original: Unlike SARS, many patients with MERS also developed acute renal failure, which is thus far unique for MERS among HCoV-caused diseases.
simplification: The development of acute renal failure makes MERS distinct among HCoV-caused diseases, unlike SARS.

original: More than 30% of patients present with gastrointestinal symptoms, such as diarrhea and vomiting.
simplification: More than 30% of patients present with symptoms such as diarrhea and vomiting.

original: As of February 14, 2020, over 2500 laboratory confirmed cases were reported with a high case fatality of 34.4%, making MERS-CoV one of the most devastating viruses known to humans.
simplification: As of February 14, 2020, over 2500 laboratory confirmed cases were reported. The high fatality rate of 34.4%, makes MERS-CoV one of the most devastating viruses known to humans.

original: During middle to late December 2019, clusters of pneumonia patients retrospectively known to be associated with SARS-CoV-2 infection were detected in Wuhan, Hubei Province, China.
simplification: During middle to late December 2019, clusters of pneumonia patients are also known to be linked with SARS-CoV-2 infection were found in Wuhan, Hubei Province, China.

original: World Health Organization declared the ongoing outbreak of lower respiratory tract infection caused by SARS-CoV-2 a Public Health Emergency of International Concern and also named the disease COVID-19.
simplification: World Health Organization declared the ongoing outbreak of lower respiratory tract infection a Public Health Emergency of International Concern. The infection caused by SARS-CoV-2 is also named as COVID-19.

original: As of March 3, 2020, 90,053 cases have been confirmed worldwide, with a crude case fatality of 3.4%.
simplification: As of March 3, 2020, 90,053 cases have been confirmed worldwide, with a rough estimate of fatality cases of 3.4%.

original: Notably, the case fatality in Hubei, China is 4.2%, whereas the one outside of it is 1.2%.
simplification: The case fatality in Hubei, China is 4.2%, whereas the one outside of it is 1.2%.

original: SARS-CoV-2 causes severe respiratory infection like SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV, presented as fever, cough and dyspnea.
simplification: Like SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV, SARS-CoV-2 presents with fever, cough and difficulty breathing, causing severe respiratory infection.

original: Diarrhea is also seen in some patients.
simplification: Diarrhea is also seen in some patients.

original: Pneumonia is one of the most severe symptoms and can progress rapidly to acute respiratory distress syndrome.
simplification: Pneumonia is one of the most severe symptoms and can progress rapidly to acute respiratory distress syndrome.

original: Although SARS-CoV and SARS-CoV-2 are very similar due to high nucleotide sequence homology of 82%, they cluster into different branches in the phylogenetic tree.
simplification: Although SARS-CoV and SARS-CoV-2 are very similar by 82%, they differ when they branch out in the phylogenetic tree

original: SARS-CoV-2 is apparently less pathogenic but more transmissible compared to SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV.
simplification: Compared to SARS-CoV-2 and MERS-CoV, SARS-CoV-2 is less infectious but more easily spread.

original: Asymptomatic subjects infected with SARS-CoV-2 have been reported and might contribute to its rapid spreading around the world.
simplification: Subjects without symptoms of SARS-CoV-2 have been reported. They might be contributing to the rapid spreading around the world

original: Comparing and contrasting SARS-CoV-2 with the other six HCoVs reveal similarities and differences of great interest.
simplification: Comparison between SARS-CoV-2 and other six HCoVs show similarities and differences of great interest.

original: First, the incubation period and the duration of the course of HCoV disease are very similar.
simplification: The incubation period and the time of the course of HCoV disease are very similar.

original: In this regard, SARS-CoV-2 follows the general trend of the other six HCoVs.
simplification: In this instance, SARS-CoV-2 follows the general trend of the other six HCoVs.

original: Second, the severity of symptoms of COVID-19 lies between SARS-CoV and the four community-acquired HCoVs (i.e. HCoV-229E, HCoV-OC43, HCoV-HKU1 and HCoV-NL63).
simplification: The severity of symptoms of COVID-19 lies between SARS-CoV and the four community-acquired HCoVs including HCoV-229E, HCoV-OC43, HCoV-HKU1 and HCoV-NL63.

original: On one hand, SARS-CoV-2 infection exhibits features that are more commonly seen during infection with community-acquired HCoVs, including the presentation of non-specific, mild or even no symptoms.
simplification: On one hand, SARS-CoV-2 infection presents with features that are more commonly seen during infection with community acquired HCoVs. It may present with non-specific,mild,or even no symptoms.

original: On the other hand, a small subset of severe cases of COVID-19 can also be seen as in the case of SARS-CoV infection, although the ratio is a bit lower.
simplification: Although the ratio is lower, a small subset of severe cases of COVID-19 can also be seen as in the case of SARS-CoV infection.

original: Third, the transmission of SARS-CoV-2 also shows interesting patterns characteristic of both community-acquired HCoVs and SARS-CoV.
simplification: Thirdly, the spread of SARS-CoV-2 also show interesting features of both community acquired HCoVs and SARS-CoV.

original: On one hand, the transmissibility of SARS-CoV-2 is at least as high as that of community-acquired HCoVs.
simplification: Contrarily, the spread of SARS-CoV-2 is at least as high as that of community acquired HCoVs.

original: On the other hand, it remains to be verified whether the transmissibility of SARS-CoV-2 decreases after passages in humans as in the cases of SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV.
simplification: Nonetheless, it remains unknown whether the spread of SARS-CoV-2 slows down after infecting humans like in the cases of SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV.

original: Finally, same as the other HCoVs, SARS-CoV-2 can be detected in fecal samples.
simplification: Like other HCoVs, SARS-CoV-2 can be detected in stool samples.

original: Whether fecal-oral transmission of SARS-CoV-2 plays an important role as in the case of SARS-CoV at least under some circumstance remains to be clarified by future studies.
simplification: The importance and role of fecal-oral transmission of SARS-CoV-2 remains to be clarified by future studies.

original: It is also of particularly great interest to see whether SARS-CoV-2 might exhibit seasonality as in the cases of community-acquired HCoVs.
simplification: It is also particularly interesting to see whether SARS-CoV-2 are seasonal like community acquired HCoVs.

original: Nevertheless, the features of SARS-CoV-2 including its transmissibility, pathogenicity and sustainable spreading after passages in humans will be influential on the ultimate fate of the ongoing outbreak of COVID-19.
simplification: Yet, the spreadability, infectiousness and sustainable spreading after passages in humans are the features of SARS-CoV-2 that influences the ultimate fate of the ongoing outbreak of COVID-19.

original: All four community-acquired HCoVs causing mild symptoms have been well adapted to humans.
simplification: All four community-acquired HCoVs causing mild symptoms have been well adapted to humans.

original: From another perspective, it might also be true that humans have been well adapted to these four HCoVs.
simplification: From another viewpoint, it might also be true that humans have well adjusted to these four HCoVs.

original: In other words, both could be the survivors of ancient HCoV pandemics.
simplification: In other words, both could be the survivors of ancient HCoV pandemics.

original: HCoVs that cause severe diseases in humans and humans who developed severe HCoV diseases have been eliminated.
simplification: HCoVs that cause severe diseases in humans and humans who developed severe HCoV diseases have been eliminated.

original: For this to happen, HCoVs have to replicate in humans to sufficient extent to allow the accumulation of adaptive mutations that counteract host restriction factors.
simplification: For this to happen, HCoVs have to replicate extensively in humans. Then, it has to allow the accumulation of adaptive mutations that counteract host restriction factors.

original: In this sense, the longer the SARS-CoV-2 outbreak persists and the more people that it infects, the greater chance that it will fully adapt to humans.
simplification: Therefore, the longer the SARS-CoV-2 outbreak persists and the more people it infects, the greater chance that it will fully adapt to humans.

original: If it adapts well, its transmission in humans would be difficult to stop by quarantine or other infection control measures.
simplification: If it adapts well to humans, it would be be difficult to stop its spread through quarantine or infection control measures.

original: For many years, the four community-acquired CoVs circulate in human populations, triggering common cold in immunocompetent subjects.
simplification: For many years, the four community acquired CoVs circulate in human populations. They trigger common cold in subjects with normal immunity.

original: These viruses do not need an animal reservoir.
simplification: These viruses do not need an animal host.

original: In contrast, highly pathogenic SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV have not adapted to humans well and their transmission within humans cannot be sustained.
simplification: In comparison, highly infectious SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV have not adapted well to human and their spread between humans cannot be maintained.

original: They need to maintain and propagate in their zoonotic reservoirs and seek the chance to spillover to susceptible human targets, possibly via one or more intermediate and amplifying hosts.
simplification: They need to maintain and grow in their animal hosts. They then try to spillover to vulnerable human targets though one or more intermediate and amplifying hosts.

original: SARS-CoV-2 has features that are similar to both SARS-CoV/MERS-CoV and the four community-acquired HCoVs.
simplification: SARS-CoV-2 has features that are similar to both SARS-CoV/MERS-CoV and the four community-acquired HCoVs.

original: It is highly transmissible like community-acquired HCoVs, at least for the time being.
simplification: It spreads easily like community acquired HCoVs at least for now.

original: However, it is more pathogenic than community-acquired HCoVs and less pathogenic than SARS-CoV or MERS-CoV.
simplification: However, it is more infectious than community acquired HCoVs and less infectious than SARS-CoV or MERS-CoV.

original: It remains to be seen whether it will adapt fully to humans and circulate within humans without a reservoir or intermediate animal host.
simplification: It is yet to be known whether it will fully adapt to humans and circulate within humans without a reservoir or intermediate animal host.

original: Before discussing the animal origins of HCoVs, it will serve us well to discuss the definitions and characteristics of evolutionary, natural, reservoir, intermediate and amplifying hosts of HCoVs.
simplification: It will benefit us well to discuss the definition and characteristics of evolutionary, natural, reservoir and amplifying hosts of HCoVs before discussing its animal origin.

original: An animal serves as the evolutionary host of an HCoV if it harbours a closely related ancestor sharing high homology at the level of nucleotide sequence.
simplification: An animal serves as the evolutionary host of an HCoV if it has a closely related ancestor sharing high level of similar genes.

original: The ancestral virus is usually well adapted and non-pathogenic in this host.
simplification: The ancient virus is usually well adapted and non infectious in this host.

original: Likewise, a reservoir host harbours HCoV continuously and for long term.
simplification: Similarly, a reservoir host maintains HCoV continuously and for long term.

original: In both cases, the hosts are naturally infected and are the natural hosts of HCoV or its parental virus.
simplification: In bother cases, the hosts are either naturally infected, are natural natural hosts of HCoVs or its parental virus.

original: In contrast, if the HCoV is newly introduced to an intermediate host right before or around its introduction to humans, it is not well adapted to the new host and is often pathogenic.
simplification: It is often infectious and not well adapted, if the HCoV is newly introduced to an intermediate host right before or around its introduction to humans.

original: This intermediate host can serve as the zoonotic source of human infection and play the role of an amplifying host by allowing the virus to replicate transiently and then transmitting it to humans to amplify the scale of human infection.
simplification: This intermediate host can serve as the animal origin of human infection. It plays the role of an amplifying host by allowing the virus to multiply. It's the. Transmits the virus to humans and multiply into the scale of human infection.

original: An HCoV can undergo a dead-end infection if it cannot sustain its transmission within the intermediate host.
simplification: An HCoV can undergo a dead-end infection, if cannot maintain its transmission within the intermediate host.

original: On the contrary, HCoVs can also adapt to the intermediate host and even establish long-term endemicity.
simplification: On the contrary, HCoVs can also adapt to the intermediate host and even prolong the outbreak long term.

original: In this case, the intermediate host becomes a natural reservoir host.
simplification: In this case, the intermediate host becomes a natural reservoir host.

original: Epidemiological data revealed retrospectively that the index case of SARS had a contact history with game animals.
simplification: Epidemiological data revealed retrospectively that the key case of SARS had a contact history with game animals.

original: Subsequent seroprevalence investigations indicated that animal traders had a higher prevalence of anti-SARS-CoV IgG compared with that of the general population.
simplification: Subsequent study on serology showed that anti-SARS-CoV antibody was more common among animal traders than that of the general population.

original: Masked palm civets (Paguma larvata) and a racoon dog in live animal markets were first identified to carry SARS-CoV-like viruses that are almost identical to SARS-CoV.
simplification: Masked palm civets (Paguma larvata) and a racoon dog in live animal markets were first found to carry SARS-CoV-like viruses that are almost similar to SARS-CoV.

original: This was indirectly supported by the fact that no further SARS was reported after killing all civets in the markets.
simplification: This was indirectly supported as there were no new cases of SARS reported after killing all civets in the market.

original: However, it has been reported that masked palm civets from the wild or farms without exposure to the live animal markets were largely negative for SARS-CoV, suggesting that masked palm civets might only serve as the intermediate amplifying host but not the natural reservoir of SARS-CoV.
simplification: However, it has been reported that masked palm civets from the wild or farms without exposure to the live animal markets were largely negative for SARS-CoV. This suggests that masked palm civets might only serve as the intermediate amplifying host but not the natural reservoir of SARS-CoV.

original: Notably, since 80% of the different animals in the markets in Guangzhou have anti-SARS-CoV antibodies, the possibilities that multiple species of small mammals might also serve as intermediate amplifying hosts of SARS-CoV cannot be excluded.
simplification: The possibility that multiple species of small mammals might serve as intermediate host of SARS-CoV cannot be excluded as 80% of the different animals in the markets in Guangzhou have anti-SARS-CoV antibodies.

original: All of these appear to be dead-end hosts of SARS-CoV.
simplification: All of these appear to be dead-end hosts of SARS-CoV.

original: Subsequent search for the natural animal host of SARS-CoV unveiled a closely related bat CoV, termed SARS-related Rhinolophus bat CoV HKU3 (SARSr-Rh-BatCoV HKU3), which exists in Chinese horseshoe bats.
simplification: Further search for the natural animal host of SARS-CoV revealed a closely related bat CoV known as SARS-relAted Rhinolophus Bat CoV HKU3 (SARSr-Rh-BatCoV HMU3). It exists in Chinese horseshoe bats.

original: These bats are positive for anti-SARS-CoV antibodies and genome sequence of SARSr-Rh-BatCoV HKU3.
simplification: These bats are positive for anti-SARS-CoV antibodies and genome sequence of SARSr-Rh-BatCoV HKU3.

original: This and other bat CoVs share 88-92% nucleotide sequence homology with SARS-CoV.
simplification: This and other bat CoVs share 88-92% genetic similarity with SARS-CoV.

original: These studies have laid the foundation for the new concept that bats host emerging human pathogens.
simplification: These studies have laid the foundation for the new concept that bats host emerging human diseases.

original: Several SARS-like CoVs (SL-CoVs) have also been identified from bats, but none except for one designated WIV1 can be isolated as live virus.
simplification: Several SARS-like CoVs (SL-CoVs) have also been found from bats. However, none except for one designated WIV1 can be isolated as live virus.

original: Human angiotensin converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) is known to be the receptor of SARS-CoV.
simplification: Human angiotensin converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) is known to be the receptor of SARS-CoV.

original: WIV1 derived from fecal sample of bats was demonstrated to use bat, civet and human ACE2 as receptor for cell entry.
simplification: WIV1 obtained from stool sample of bats was shown to use bat, civet and human ACE2 as receptor for cell entry.

original: Intriguingly, sera of convalescent SARS patients were capable of neutralizing WIV1.
simplification: Interestingly, sera of recovered SARS patients were capable of counteracting WIV1.

original: Thus far, WIV1 represents the most closely related ancestor of SARS-CoV in bats, sharing 95% nucleotide sequence homology.
simplification: So far, WIV1 represents the most closely related ancestor related of SARS-CoV in bats. It shares 95% of genetic similarity.

original: Albeit the high homology between these two viruses, it is generally believed that WIV1 is not the immediate parental virus of SARS-CoV and bats are not the immediate reservoir host of SARS-CoV.
simplification: Although there is high genetic similarity between these two viruses, it is believed that WIV1 is not the intermediate parental virus or SARS-CoV while bats are not the intermediate reservoir host of SARS-CoV.

original: Phylogenetic analysis clusters MERS-CoV to the same group as bat CoV-HKU4 and bat CoV-HKU5.
simplification: Genetic analysis clusters MERS-CoV, bat CoV-HKU4 and bat CoV-HMU5 in the same group.

original: Bat CoV-HKU4 and MERS-CoV utilize the same host receptor, dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), for virus entry.
simplification: Bat CoV-HKU4 and MERS-CoV uses the same host receptor, dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), for virus entry.

original: RNA-dependent RNA polymerase sequences of MERS-CoV are phylogenetically closer to counterparts in bat beta-CoVs identified from Europe and Africa.
simplification: RNA-dependent RNA polymerase sequences of MERS-CoV are genetically closer to counterparts in bat beta-CoVs found in Europe and Africa.

original: Up to now, no live MERS-CoV can be found in wild bats.
simplification: Till now, no live MERS-CoV can be found in wild bats.

original: MERS-CoV and its closest relative bat CoV-HKU25 share only 87% nucleotide sequence homology.
simplification: MERS-CoV and its closest relative bat CoV-HKU25 share only 87% genetic similarity.

original: Thus, bats might not be the immediate reservoir host of MERS-CoV.
simplification: Therefore, bats may not be the intermediate host of MERS-CoV.

original: On the other hand, studies in Middle East have shown that dromedary camels are seropositive for MERS-CoV-specific neutralizing antibodies, same as camels of Middle East origin in multiple African countries.
simplification: Studies in Middle East have shown that dromedary camels and camels of Middle East origin in multiple African countries are seropositive for MERS-CoV-specific neutralising anti does.

original: Live MERS-CoV identical to the virus found in humans was isolated from the nasal swabs of dromedary camels, further indicating that camels serve as the bona fide reservoir host of MERS-CoV.
simplification: Live MERS-CoV from nasal swabs of dromedary camels were isolated identical to the virus found in humans. This further indicates that camels serve as reservoir host of MERS-CoV.

original: It is also noteworthy that generally mild symptoms but massive virus shedding were observed in camels experimentally infected with MERS-CoV.
simplification: In camels experimentally infected with MERS-CoV, mild symptoms and massive virus shedding were observed.

original: Notably, infected camels shed viruses not only through respiratory route but also through fecal-oral route, which is also the main route for virus shedding from bats.
simplification: Notably, infected camels shed viruses not only through respiratory route but also through fecal-oral route. The fecal-oral route is the main route for virus shedding from bats.

original: However, questions still remain since many confirmed cases of MERS have no contact history with camels prior to symptom onset, plausibly ascribed to human-to-human transmission or unknown transmission routes involving unrecognized animal species that harbour MERS-CoV.
simplification: However, questions still remain since many confirmed cases of MERS have no contact history with camels prior to symptoms onset. It is plausible that it is linked to human-to-human transmission or unknown transmission routes involving unrecognised animal specifies that harbour MERS-CoV.

original: SARS-CoV-2 shares 96.2% nucleotide homology with a bat CoV RaTG13 isolated from Rhinolophus affinis bats.
simplification: SARS-CoV-2 shares 96.2% genetic similarity with a bat CoV RaTG13 isolated from Rhinolophus affinis bats.

original: As in the cases of SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV, the sequence divergence between SARS-CoV-2 and RaTG13 is too great to assign parental relationship.
simplification: As in the cases of SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV, the sequence between SARS-CoV-2 and RaTG13 is far too diverged to determine parental relationship.

original: That is to say, bats might not be the immediate reservoir host(s) of SARS-CoV-2 unless almost identical bat CoVs are found in future.
simplification: Bats might not be the immediate reservoir host(s) of SARS-CoV-2 unless almost identical bat CoVs are found in future.

original: Presumably, the intermediate animal hosts of SARS-CoV-2 should be among the wildlife species sold and killed at the Huanan Seafood Wholesale Market, with which many of the initial cases of COVID-19 were associated, indicative of a probable animal-to-human transmission event.
simplification: With many of the initial cases linked to the Hunan Seafood Market, it is presumed that the intermediate hosts of SARS-CoV-2 to be among the wildlife species sold and killed in the market. This indicates a possible animal-to-human transmission event.

original: Several recent studies based on metagenomic sequencing have suggested that a group of endangered small mammals known as pangolins (Manis javanica) could also harbour ancestral beta-CoVs related to SARS-CoV-2.
simplification: Several recent studies based on metagenomic sequencing have suggested that a group of endangered small mammals known as pangolins (Manis javanica) could also cultivate ancestral beta-CoVs related to SARS-CoV-2.

original: These novel pangolin CoV genomes share 85-92% nucleotide sequence homology with SARS-CoV-2.
simplification: These novel pangolin CoV genomes share 85-92% genetic sequence with SARS-CoV-2.

original: However, they are equally closely related to RaTG13 with about 90% identity at the level of nucleotide sequence.
simplification: However, they are equally closely related to RaTG13 with about 90% similarity at nucleotide sequence level.

original: They cluster into two sub-lineages of SARS-CoV-2-like viruses in the phylogenetic tree, one of which share a more similar receptor binding domain (RBD) with SARS-CoV-2, with 97.4% amino acid sequence identity.
simplification: They cluster into two sub-lineages of SARS-CoV-2-like viruses in the phylogenetic tree.  One of which share a more similar receptor binding domain (RBD) with SARS-CoV-2, with 97.4% amino acid sequence identity.

original: In stark contrast, the RBDs of SARS-CoV-2 and RaTG13 are more divergent, albeit a higher degree of sequence homology genome-wide.
simplification: Distinctively, the RBDs of SARS-CoV-2 and RaTG13 are more divergent.

original: An earlier study on diseased pangolins also reported the detection of viral contigs from lung samples, which turn out to be similarly related to SARS-CoV-2.
simplification: An earlier study on diseased pangolins also reported the detection of viral contigs from lung samples. It turned out to be similarly related to SARS-CoV-2.

original: This study adopted different assembly methods and manual curation to generate a partial genome sequence comprising about 86.3% of the full-length viral genome.
simplification: This study adopted different assembly methods and manual curation to generate a partial genome sequence. It consisted about 86.3% of the full-length viral genome.

original: We cannot exclude the possibility that pangolin is one of the intermediate animal hosts of SARS-CoV-2.
simplification: The possibility that pangolin being one of the intermediate animal host of SARS-CoV-2 cannot be excluded.

original: This is one line of scientific research which is currently being pursued to develop safe and effective COVID-19 treatments.
simplification: This is one line of scientific research which is currently being pursued to develop safe and effective COVID-19 treatments.

original: Analyzing those binding sites provide the reasonable project of developing effective antiviral drug against COVID-19 proteins.
simplification: Analyzing those binding sites provide the reasonable project of developing effective antiviral drug against COVID-19 proteins.

original: Of the most important SARS-CoV-2 target proteins are papain-like protease, RNA dependent RNA polymerase, helicase, S protein, and ADP ribophosphatase.
simplification: Of the most important SARS-CoV-2 target proteins are papain-like protease, RNA dependent RNA polymerase, helicase, S protein, and ADP ribophosphatase

original: Hussein A A, et al studied several candidate compounds which then optimized and analyzed for their skeleton similarity with the highest similar approved drugs in order to accelerate a potent anti-SARS-CoV-2 drug development in his preclinical study to be recommended in a clinical study design.
simplification: Hussein A A, et Al, studied several potential compounds which was optimized and analysed for their skeleton similarity with the most similar approved drugs. This helped accelerate a potent anti-SARS-CoV-2 drug development in his preclinical study to be recommended in a clinical study design.

original: Chloroquine is an anti-malarial medication that is also used against some auto-immune diseases.
simplification: Chloroquine is an anti-malarial medication that is also used against some auto-immune diseases.

original: On 18 March, the WHO announced that chloroquine and the related hydroxychloroquine would be among the four drugs studied as part of the Solidarity clinical trial.
simplification: On 18 March, the WHO announced that chloroquine and the related hydroxychloroquine would be among the four drugs studied as part of the Solidarity clinical trial.

original: New York governor Andrew Cuomo announced that New York State trials of chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine would begin on 24 March.On 28 March, the FDA authorized the use of hydroxychloroquine sulfate and chloroquine phosphate under an Emergency Use Authorization (EUA).
simplification: New York governor Andrew Cuomo announced that New York State trials of chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine would begin on 24 March. On 28 March, the FDA permitted the use of hydroxychloroquine sulfate and chloroquine phosphate under an Emergency Use Authorization (EUA).

original: The treatment has not been approved by the FDA's clinical trials process and is authorized under the EUA only as an experimental treatment for emergency use in patients who are hospitalized but are not able to receive treatment in a clinical trial.
simplification: The treatment has not been approved by the FDA’s Clinical trial process. It has been authorized under the EUA as an experimental treatment for emergency use in patients who are hospitalised but not able to received treatment in a clinical trial.

original: The CDC has said that "the use, dosing, or duration of hydroxychloroquine for prophylaxis or treatment of SARS-CoV-2 infection" are not yet established.
simplification: The CDC has said that "the use, dosing, or duration of hydroxychloroquine for preventive treatment or treatment of SARS-CoV-2 infection" are not yet known.

original: Doctors have said they are using the drug when "there's no other option".
simplification: Doctors have said they are using the drug when "there's no other option".

original: A Turkish research team in Istanbul is conducting a small study on the use of chloroquine in combination with zinc, vitamin A, vitamin C and vitamin D.
simplification: A Turkish research team in Istanbul is conducting a small study on the use of chloroquine in combination with zinc, vitamin A, vitamin C and vitamin D.

original: Large studies are underway at Duke University and the University of Oxford.
simplification: Large studies are ongoing at Duke University and the University of Oxford.

original: NYU Langone Medical School is conducting a trial on the safety and efficacy of preventative use of hydroxychloroquine.
simplification: NYU Langone Medical School is conducting a trial on the safety and success of preventative use of hydroxychloroquine.

original: Chinese clinical trials in Wuhan and Shenzhen claimed to show favipiravir was "clearly effective".
simplification: Chinese clinical trials in Wuhan and Shenzhen claimed to show favipiravir was "clearly effective".

original: In a study conducted in Wuhan on 240 patients with pneumonia, half were given favipiravir and half received umifenovir.
simplification: In a study conducted in Wuhan on 240 penumia patients, half were given favipiravir and half received umifenovir.

original: The Italian Pharmaceutical Agency reminded the public that the existing evidence in support of the drug is scant and preliminary.
simplification: The Italian Pharmaceutical Agency reminded the public that the existing evidence in support of the drug is minimal and too early.

original: It may not be safe for use by pregnant women or those trying to conceive.
simplification: It may not be safe for use by pregnant women or those trying to conceive.

original: The drugs were designed to inhibit HIV from replicating by binding to the protease.
simplification: The drugs were designed to stop HIV from replicating by binding to the protease.

original: The WHO included lopinavir/ritonavir in the international Solidarity trial.
simplification: The WHO included lopinavir/ritonavir in the international Solidarity trial.

original: One issue with antiviral treatment is the development of resistance through mutations that can lead to more severe disease and transmission.
simplification: Development of resistance through mutations that can lead to more severe diseases and spread is one of the issues with antiviral treatment.

original: New York State began trials for the antibiotic azithromycin on 24 March 2020.
simplification: Trials for the antibiotic azithromycin began on 24 March 2020 at New York State.

original: Researchers from the Montreal Heart Institute in Canada are currently studying the role of colchicine in reducing inflammation and pulmonary complications in patients suffering from mild symptoms of COVID-19.
simplification: Researchers from the Montreal Heart Institute in Canada are currently studying the role of colchicine in reducing inflammation and lung complications in patients suffering from mild symptoms of COVID-19.

original: The study, named COLCORONA, is recruiting 6000 adults aged 40 and over who were diagnosed with COVID-19 and experience mild symptoms not requiring hospitalization.
simplification: The study, named COLCORONA, is recruiting 6000 adults aged 40 and over who were diagnosed with COVID-19 and experience mild symptoms not requiring hospitalization.

original: Women who are pregnant or breastfeeding or who do not have an effective contraceptive method are not eligible.
simplification: Women who are pregnant or breastfeeding or who do not have an effective contraceptive method are not eligible.

original: However, multiple professional societies and regulatory bodies have recommended continuing standard ACE inhibitor and ARB therapy.
simplification: However, multiple professional societies and regulatory bodies have recommended continuing the standard ACE inhibitor and ARB therapy.

original: A systematic review and meta-analysis published on July 11, 2012, found that "use of ACE inhibitors was associated with a significant 34% reduction in risk of pneumonia compared with controls."
simplification: Studies published on July 11, 2012, have found that the use of ACE inhibitors reduced the risk of lung infection by 34%.

original: Moreover, "the risk of pneumonia was also reduced in patients treated with ACE inhibitors who were at higher risk of pneumonia, in particular those with stroke and heart failure.
simplification: ACE inhibitors reduced the risk of lung infection among those with stroke and heart failure. They were at higher risk of getting lung infections.

original: Use of ACE inhibitors was also associated with a reduction in pneumonia related mortality, although the results were less robust than for overall risk of pneumonia."
simplification: The use of ACE inhibitors showed a reduction in pneumonia-related deaths.

original: Recombinant human ACE2 (rhACE2) is surmised to be a novel therapy for acute lung injury, and appeared to improve pulmonary hemodynamics and oxygen saturation in piglets with a lipopolysaccharide-induced acute respiratory distress syndrome.
simplification: Recombinant human ACE2 (rhACE2) is theorised to treat acute lung injury. It appears to improve lung function in piglets with a condition that causes problems in breathing.

original: The half-life of rhACE2 in human beings is about 10 hours and the onset of action is 30 minutes in addition to the course of effect (duration) of 24 hours.
simplification: The half-life of rhACE2 in human beings is about 10 hours. It takes 30 minutes to take effect. The effects last for 24 hours.

original: Several findings suggest that rhACE2 may be a promising drug for those with intolerance to classic renin-angiotensin system inhibitors (RAS inhibitors) or in diseases where circulating angiotensin II is elevated.Infused rhACE2 has been evaluated in clinical trials for the treatment of acute respiratory distress syndrome.
simplification: Several findings suggest that rhACE2 may be a promising drug. Especially for those with intolerance to classic renin-angiotensin system inhibitors (RAS inhibitor) or those with diseases that cause a high level of angiotensin II in the circulation. Clinical Trial have evaluated whether rhACE2 infusion can be used to treat acute respiratory distress syndrome.

original: b'COVID-19 apps are mobile software applications designed to aid contact tracing in response to the 2019-20 coronavirus pandemic, i.e. the process of identifying persons ("contacts") who may have been in contact with an infected individual.
simplification: COVID-19 apps are designed to help with contact tracing using a mobile. It helps with identifying people who may have been in contact with someone who was infected.

original: Numerous applications were developed or proposed, with official government support in some territories and jurisdictions.
simplification: Numerous applications were developed or proposed with the support of the official government in some regions of the world.

original: Several frameworks for building contact tracing apps have been developed.
simplification: There have several structures built for the development of contact tracing apps.

original: Privacy concerns have been raised, especially about systems that are based on tracking the geographical location of app users.
simplification: There have been concerns over privacy as the systems are based on tracking the geographical location of app users.

original: Less intrusive alternatives include the use of Bluetooth signals to log a user's proximity to other cellphones.
simplification: There are less invasive methods that use Bluetooth signals to log user's contact with other cell phones.

original: On 10 April 2020, Google and Apple jointly announced that they would integrate functionality to support such Bluetooth-based apps directly into their Android and iOS operating systems.
simplification: Google and Apple jointly announced that they would make such Bluetooth based apps compatible with Android and IOS devices.

original: In China, the Chinese government, in conjunction with Alipay, has deployed an app that allows citizens to check if they have been in contact with people that have COVID-19.
simplification: The Chinese government and Alipay have released an app that allows citizens in China to check if they have been in contact with people that have COVID-19.

original: It is in use across more than 200 Chinese cities.In Singapore, an app called TraceTogether is being used.
simplification: It is used widely in over 200 cities in China. The app is called TraceTogether in Singapore.

original: The app was developed by local IT community, released as open source and will be handed over to the government.North Macedonia launched "StopKorona!", a Bluetooth-based app to trace exposure with potentially infected persons and  provide a fast response to healthcare authorities.
simplification: The app was developed by the local IT community and will be handed over to the government. North Macedonia released an app called ''StopKorona!''. It uses Bluetooth to track any exposure to infection and inform healthcare authorities quickly.

original: The app was developed by the Ministry of Communication and Technology and Ministry of Health.
simplification: The app was developed by the Ministry of Communication and Technology and Ministry of Health.

original: b'Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is an infectious disease caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2).
simplification: b'Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is an infectious disease caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2).

original: Common symptoms include fever, cough, and shortness of breath.
simplification: Common symptoms include fever, cough, and difficulty breathing.

original: Other symptoms may include fatigue, muscle pain, diarrhea, sore throat, loss of smell, and abdominal pain.
simplification: Other symptoms may include tiredness, muscle pain, diarrhea, sore throat, loss of smell, and abdominal pain.

original: The time from exposure to onset of symptoms is typically around five days but may range from two to fourteen days.
simplification: The time from exposure to onset of symptoms is typically around five days but may range from two to fourteen days.

original: While the majority of cases result in mild symptoms, some progress to viral pneumonia and multi-organ failure.
simplification: While most of the cases result in mild symptoms, some progress to viral pneumonia and multorgan failure

original: While these droplets are produced when breathing out, they usually fall to the ground or onto surfaces rather than being infectious over long distances.
simplification: These droplets that are produced when breathing out, usually fall to the ground or onto surfaces rather than being infectious over long distances.

original: People may also become infected by touching a contaminated surface and then touching their eyes, nose, or mouth.
simplification: People may also become infected by touching a contaminated surface and then touching their eyes, nose, or mouth.

original: The virus can survive on surfaces up to 72 hours.
simplification: The virus can survive on surfaces up to 72 hours.

original: It is most contagious during the first three days after the onset of symptoms, although spread may be possible before symptoms appear and in later stages of the disease.The standard method of diagnosis is by real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR) from a nasopharyngeal swab.
simplification: It is most infectious during the first three days after the symptoms starts to appear. However, spread may be possible before symptoms appear and in later stages of the disease. Real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR) is the standard methods of diagnosing from a nasal swab.

original: The use of masks is recommended for those who suspect they have the virus and their caregivers.
simplification: The use of masks is recommended for those who suspect they have the virus and their caregivers.

original: Recommendations for mask use by the general public vary, with some authorities recommending against their use, some recommending their use, and others requiring their use.
simplification: The recommendation to the general public using mask vary. Some authorities recommended their use while some are against it.

original: Currently, there is no vaccine or specific antiviral treatment for COVID-19.
simplification: Currently, there is no vaccine or specific antiviral treatment for COVID-19.

original: Local transmission of the disease has been recorded in most countries across all six WHO regions.
simplification: Local transmission of the disease has been recorded in most countries across all six WHO regions.

original: Those infected with the virus may be asymptomatic or develop flu-like symptoms such as fever, cough, fatigue, and shortness of breath.
simplification: Those infected with the virus may not show any symptoms or develop flu-like symptoms such as fever, cough, tiredness, and difficulty breathing

original: Emergency symptoms include difficulty breathing, persistent chest pain or pressure, confusion, difficulty waking, and bluish face or lips; immediate medical attention is advised if these symptoms are present.
simplification: Immediate medical attention is advised if emergency symptoms are presents. These symptoms includes difficulty breathing, constant chest pain or pressure, confusion, difficulty waking and bluish face or lips.

original: Less commonly, upper respiratory symptoms such as sneezing, runny nose or sore throat may be seen.
simplification: Upper respiratory symptoms such as sneezing, runny nose or sore throat may be less commonly seen.

original: Gastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea, vomiting and diarrhoea have been observed in varying percentages.
simplification: Symptoms involving the gastrointestinal tract such as nausea, vomiting and diarrhoea have been observed in varying percentages.

original: Some cases in China initially presented only with chest tightness and palpitations.
simplification: Some cases in China initially presented only with chest tightness and palpitations.

original: In some, the disease may progress to pneumonia, multi-organ failure, and death.
simplification: In some, the disease may progress to pneumonia, multi-organ failure, and death.

original: This is called the incubation period.
simplification: This is called the incubation period.

original: The incubation period for COVID-19 is typically five to six days but may range from two to 14 days.
simplification: The incubation period for COVID-19 is typically five to six days but may range from two to 14 days.

original: 97.5% of people who develop symptoms will do so within 11.5 days of infection.Reports indicate that not all who are infected develop symptoms.
simplification: Reports show that not all who are infected develop symptoms. 97.5% of people will develop symptoms within 11.5 days of infection.

original: Both sputum and saliva can carry large viral loads.
simplification: Both sputum and saliva can carry large quantity of viruses.

original: Loud talking releases more droplets than normal talking.
simplification: Talking Loudly releases more droplets than talking normally.

original: A study in Singapore found that an uncovered cough can lead to droplets travelling up to 4.5 meters (15 feet).
simplification: A study in Singapore found that coughing without any mouth cover, can lead to droplets travelling up to 4.5 meters (15 feet)

original: Some medical procedures such as intubation and cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) may cause respiratory secretions to be aerosolised and thus result in airborne spread.
simplification: Some medical procedures such as intubation and cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) may cause secretions. These respiratory secretions can be aerolised that result spread through air.

original: The European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) says while it is not entirely clear how easily the disease spreads, one person generally infects two to three others.The virus survives for hours to days on surfaces.
simplification: The European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) says while it is not entirely sure how easily the disease spreads, one person generally infects two to three others.The virus survives for hours to days on surfaces.

original: Specifically, the virus was found to be detectable for one day on cardboard, for up to three days on plastic (polypropylene) and stainless steel (AISI 304), and for up to four hours on 99% copper.
simplification: The virus was found to be detectable for one day on cardboard, for up to three days on plastic (polypropylene) and stainless steel (AISI 304), and for up to four hours on 99% copper.

original: This, however, varies depending on the humidity and temperature.
simplification: This, however, varies depending on the humidity and temperature.

original: Soap and detergent are also effective if correctly used; soap products degrade the virus' fatty protective layer, deactivating it, as well as freeing them from skin and other surfaces.
simplification: Soap and detergent are also effective if used correctly. Soap products degrade the virus' fatty protective layer, killing it and freeing from skin and other surfaces.

original: ACE2 receptors are highly expressed in the heart and are involved in heart function.
simplification: ACE2 receptors are found in the heart and involved in heart function.

original: The WHO has published several testing protocols for the disease.
simplification: The WHO has published several testing protocols for the disease.

original: The standard method of testing is real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR).
simplification: Real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR) is the standard method of testing.

original: Results are generally available within a few hours to two days.
simplification: Results are generally available within a few hours to two days.

original: The Chinese experience with testing has shown the accuracy is only 60 to 70%.
simplification: The Chinese experience with testing has shown the accuracy is only 60 to 70%.

original: In those most severely affected, COVID-19 may rapidly progress to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) causing respiratory failure, septic shock or multi-organ failure.
simplification: COVID-19 may rapidly progress to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) causing respiratory failure, septic shock or multi-organ failure in those most severely affected.

original: Complications associated with COVID-19 include sepsis, abnormal clotting and damage to the heart, kidneys and liver.
simplification: Sepsis, abnormal clotting and damage to the heart, kidneys and liver are complications associated with COVID-19.

original: Clotting abnormalities, specifically an increase in prothrombin time, have been described in 6% of those admitted to hospital with COVID-19, while abnormal kidney function is seen in 4% of this group.
simplification: Among those admitted to the hospital with COVID-19, 6% had clotting abnormalities with an increase in prothrombin time. 4% had abnormal kidney function.

original: Approximately 20-30% of people who present with COVID-19 demonstrate elevated liver enzymes (transaminases).
simplification: Approximately 20-30% of people who present with COVID-19 showed elevated liver enzymes, transaminases.

original: According to the same report, the median time between onset of symptoms and death was ten days, with five being spent hospitalised.
simplification: According to the same report, the median time between onset of symptoms and death was ten days, with five being spent hospitalised.

original: However, patients transferred to an ICU had a median time of seven days between hospitalisation and death.
simplification: However, patients transferred to an ICU had a median time of seven days between hospitalisation and death.

original: In a study of early cases, the median time from exhibiting initial symptoms to death was 14 days, with a full range of six to 41 days.
simplification: In a study of early cases, the median time from exhibiting initial symptoms to death was 14 days, with a full range of six to 41 days.

original: In a study by the National Health Commission (NHC) of China, men had a death rate of 2.8% while women had a death rate of 1.7%.
simplification: In a study by the National Health Commission (NHC) of China, men had a death rate of 2.8% while women had a death rate of 1.7%.

original: Histopathological examinations of post-mortem lung samples show diffuse alveolar damage with cellular fibromyxoid exudates in both lungs.
simplification: Histopathological examinations of post-mortem lung samples show alveolar damage with discharges in both lungs.

original: Viral cytopathic changes were observed in the pneumocytes.
simplification: Viral cytopathic changes were observed in the lung cells.

original: The lung picture resembled acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
simplification: The lung picture resembled acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).

original: In 11.8% of the deaths reported by the National Health Commission of China, heart damage was noted by elevated levels of troponin or cardiac arrest.
simplification: In 11.8% of the deaths reported by the National Health Commission of China, heart damage was noted by elevated levels of troponin or cardiac arrest.

original: According to March data from the United States, 89% of those hospitalised had preexisting conditions.Availability of medical resources and the socioeconomics of a region may also affect mortality.
simplification: According to March data from the United States, 89% of those hospitalised had pre-existing conditions. Availability of medical resources and the socioeconomics of a region may also affect mortality.

original: Estimates of the mortality from the condition vary because of those regional differences, but also because of methodological difficulties.
simplification:
Estimates of the mortality from the condition vary 
 because of regional differences and methodological difficulties.

original: The under-counting of mild cases can cause the mortality rate to be overestimated.
simplification: The underestimation of mild cases can cause the death rate to be overestimated.

original: However, the fact that deaths are the result of cases contracted in the past can mean the current mortality rate is underestimated.
simplification: However, the fact that deaths are the result of cases contracted in the past can mean the current mortality rate is underestimated.

original: Smokers were 1.4 times more likely to have severe symptoms of COVID-19 and approximately 2.4 times more likely to require intensive care or die compared to non-smokers.Concerns have been raised about long-term sequelae of the disease.
simplification: Smokers were 1.4 times more likely to have severe symptoms of COVID-19. They are approximately 2.4 times more likely to require intensive care or die compared to non-smokers. Concerns have been raised about long-term sequelae of the disease.

original: The Hong Kong Hospital Authority found a drop of 20% to 30% in lung capacity in some people who recovered from the disease, and lung scans suggested organ damage.
simplification: The Hong Kong Hospital Authority found a drop of 20% to 30% in lung capacity in some people who recovered from the disease. The lung scans suggested organ damage.

original: This may also lead to post-intensive care syndrome following recovery.
simplification: Following recovery, this may also lead to post-intensive care syndrome.

original: As of March 2020, it was unknown if past infection provides effective and long-term immunity in people who recover from the disease.
simplification: As of March 2020, it was not known if past infection provides effective and long-term immunity in people who recover from the disease.

original: Immunity is seen as likely, based on the behaviour of other coronaviruses, but cases in which recovery from COVID-19 have been followed by positive tests for coronavirus at a later date have been reported.
simplification: Based on the behaviours of other coronaviruses, immunity is seen as likely. However, positive tests for coronaviruses at a later date have been reported in cases which have recovered from COVID-19.

original: These cases are believed to be worsening of a lingering infection rather than re-infection.
simplification: These cases are believed to be worsening of a lingering infection rather than re-infection.

original: The virus is thought to be natural and have an animal origin, through spillover infection.
simplification: The virus is thought to be natural and have originated from animal, through spill over infection.

original: The actual origin is unknown, but by December 2019 the spread of infection was almost entirely driven by human-to-human transmission.
simplification: The actual origin is unknown. However, but by December 2019 the spread of infection was almost entirely driven by human-to-human transmission.

original: A study of the first 41 cases of confirmed COVID-19, published in January 2020 in The Lancet, revealed the earliest date of onset of symptoms as 1 December 2019.
simplification: A study of the first 41 cases of confirmed COVID-19, published in January 2020 in The Lancet, revealed the earliest date of onset of symptoms as 1 December 2019.

original: Official publications from the WHO reported the earliest onset of symptoms as 8 December 2019.
simplification: Official publications from the WHO reported the earliest onset of symptoms as 8 December 2019.

original: Several measures are commonly used to quantify mortality.
simplification: Several measures are commonly used to quantify death rates.

original: These numbers vary by region and over time and are influenced by the volume of testing, healthcare system quality, treatment options, time since initial outbreak and population characteristics such as age, sex and overall health.
simplification: These numbers vary by region and time. They are influenced by the volume of testing, healthcare system quality, treatment options, time since initial outbreak and population characteristics such as age, sex and overall health.

original: In late 2019, WHO assigned the emergency ICD-10 disease codes U07.1 for deaths from lab-confirmed SARS-CoV-2 infection and U07.2 for deaths from clinically or epidemiologically diagnosed COVID-19 without lab-confirmed SARS-CoV-2 infection.The death-to-case ratio reflects the number of deaths divided by the number of diagnosed cases within a given time interval.
simplification: In late 2019, WHO assigned the emergency ICD-10 disease codes U07.1 for deaths from lab-confirmed SARS-CoV-2 infection and U07.2 for deaths from clinically diagnosed COVID-19 without lab-confirmed SARS-CoV-2 infection.The death-to-case ratio reflects the number of deaths divided by the number of diagnosed cases within a given time interval.

original: Based on Johns Hopkins University statistics, the global death-to-case ratio is 6.9% (153,822/2,240,191) as of 17 April 2020.
simplification: Based on Johns Hopkins University statistics, the global death-to-case ratio is 6.9% (153,822/2,240,191) as of 17 April 2020.

original: The number varies by region.Other measures include the case fatality rate (CFR), which reflects the percent of diagnosed individuals who die from a disease, and the infection fatality rate (IFR), which reflects the percent of infected individuals (diagnosed and undiagnosed) who die from a disease.
simplification: The number varies by region. Other measures include the case fatality rate (CFR) and the infection fatality rate (IFR). CFR reflects the percent of diagnosed individuals who die from a disease. IFR reflects the percent of infected individuals (diagnosed and undiagnosed) who die from a disease.

original: These statistics are not time bound and follow a specific population from infection through case resolution.
simplification: These statistics are not time restricted. It follows a specific population from infection through recovery of a case.

original: While not all infected people develop antibodies, the presence of antibodies may provide information about how many people have been infected.
simplification: While not all infected people develop antibodies, the presence of antibodies may provide information about how many people have been infected.

original: In the epicentre of the outbreak in Italy, Castiglione d'Adda, a small village of 4600, 80 (1.7%) are already dead.
simplification: In the epicentre of the outbreak in Italy, Castiglione d'Adda, a small village of 4600, 80 (1.7%) are already dead.

original: In Gangelt, the disease was spread by Carnival festivals, and spread to younger people, causing a relatively lower mortality, and not all COVID-19 deaths may have been formally classified as such.
simplification: In Gangelt, the disease was spread by Carnival festival. It’s spread to younger people resulted a relatively lower mortality, and not all COVID-19 deaths may have been formally classified as such.

original: Furthermore, the German health system has not been overwhelmed.
simplification: Furthermore, the German health system has not been overwhelmed.

original: In the Netherlands, about 3% may have antibodies, as assessed from blood donors.
simplification: As assessed from blood donors in the Netherlands, about 3% may have antibodies.

original: 69 (0.004% of the population) have been confirmed to have died from COVID-19.
simplification: 69 (0.004% of the population) have been confirmed to have died from COVID-19.

original: The impact of the pandemic and its mortality rate are different for men and women.
simplification: The impact of the pandemic and its death rate are different for men and women.

original: Mortality is higher in men in studies conducted in China and Italy.
simplification: Death rate is higher in men in studies conducted in China and Italy.

original: The highest risk for men is in their 50s, with the gap between men and women closing only at 90.
simplification: The highest risk for men is in their 50s, with the gap between men and women closing only at 90.

original: In China, the death rate was 2.8 percent for men and 1.7 percent for women.
simplification: The death rate was 2.8 percent for men and 1.7 percent for women in China.

original: The exact reasons for this sex-difference is not known, but genetic and behavioural factors could be a reason.
simplification: The exact reasons for the difference in sex is unknown. However, genetic and behavioural factors could be a reason.

original: Sex-based immunological differences, lesser prevalence of smoking in women and men developing co-morbid conditions such as hypertension at a younger age than women could have contributed to the higher mortality in men.
simplification: High mortality rate in men could have due sex-based based immunological differences, lesser prevalence of smoking in women and men developing co-morbid conditions such as hypertension at a younger age than women.

original: In Europe, 57% of the infected individuals were men and 72% of those died with COVID-19 were men.
simplification: In Europe, 57% of the infected individuals were men and 72% of those died with COVID-19 were men.

original: As of April 2020, the US government is not tracking sex-related data of COVID-19 infections.
simplification: As of April 2020, the US government is not tracking sex-related data of COVID-19 infections.

original: Research has shown that viral illnesses like Ebola, HIV, influenza and SARS affect men and women differently.
simplification: Research shows that men and women are affected differently by viral illness like Ebola, HIV, influenza and SARS.

original: A higher percentage of health workers, particularly nurses, are women, and they have a higher chance of being exposed to the virus.
simplification: A higher percentage of health workers, particularly nurses, are women. They have a higher chance of being exposed to the virus.

original: The World Health Organization announced on 11 February 2020 that the official name of the disease would be "COVID-19".
simplification: The World Health Organization announced on 11 February 2020 that the official name of the disease would be "COVID-19".

original: WHO chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus explained that CO stands for corona, VI for virus, D for disease, and 19 for when the outbreak was first identified: 31 December 2019.
simplification: WHO chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus explained that CO stands for corona, VI for virus, D for disease, and 19 for when the outbreak was first identified which was on the  31 December 2019.

original: The name had been chosen to avoid references to a specific geographical location (e.g. China), animal species or group of people, in line with international recommendations for naming aimed at preventing stigmatisation.The virus that causes COVID-19 is named severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2).
simplification: In line with international recommendations for naming aimed at preventing stigmatisation, the name had been chosen to avoid references to a specific geographical location (e.g. China), animal species or group of people. The virus that causes COVID-19 is named severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2).

original: The WHO additionally uses "the COVID-19 virus" and "the virus responsible for COVID-19" in public communications.
simplification: The WHO additionally uses "the COVID-19 virus" and "the virus responsible for COVID-19" in public communications.

original: Both the disease and virus are commonly referred to as "coronavirus".
simplification: Both the disease and virus are commonly referred to as "coronavirus".

original: During the initial outbreak in Wuhan, China, the virus and disease were commonly referred to as "coronavirus" and "Wuhan coronavirus".
simplification: During the initial outbreak in Wuhan, China, the virus and disease were commonly referred to as "coronavirus" and "Wuhan coronavirus".

original: In January 2020, WHO recommended 2019-nCov and 2019-nCoV acute respiratory disease as interim names for the virus and disease in accordance with 2015 guidance against using locations in disease and virus names.
simplification: Based on the 2015 guidance using locations in disease and virus name, WHO recommended 2019-nCov and 2019-nCoV acute respiratory disease as interim names in January 2020.

original: The official names COVID-19 and SARS-CoV-2 were issued on 11 February 2020.
simplification: The official names COVID-19 and SARS-CoV-2 were issued on 11 February 2020.

original: Due to capacity limitations in the standard supply chains, some digital manufacturers are printing healthcare material such as nasal swabs and ventilator parts.
simplification: Due to limitations in the standard supply chains capacity, some digital manufacturers are printing healthcare material such as nasal swabs and ventilator parts.

original: In one example, when an Italian hospital urgently required a ventilator valve, and the supplier was unable to deliver in the timescale required, a local startup reverse-engineered and printed the required 100 valves overnight.
simplification: In one example, a local start up reverse-engineering and printed 100 valves overnight when a supplier was unable to deliver to the urgent need of an ventilator valve in a Italian hospital.

original: After the initial outbreak of COVID-19, conspiracy theories, misinformation and disinformation emerged regarding the origin, scale, prevention, treatment and other aspects of the disease and rapidly spread online.
simplification: After the initial outbreak of COVID-19, conspiracy theories, misinformation and disinformation regarding the origin, scale, prevention, treatment and other aspects of the disease emerged and rapidly spread online.

original: Humans appear to be capable of spreading the virus to some other animals.
